Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars. The EU's creation dates back to the Rome Treaty of 1957, which created the European Economic Community between the six founding EU member states (France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg). After four enlargements in 1973 (UK, Denmark, Ireland), 1981 (Greece), 1986 (Spain and Portugal) and 1995 (Austria, Finland and Sweden), the EU counted 15 members. The collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU. The UK formally left the bloc in January 2020 and a transition period will end on December 31st 2020. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than those of other east European countries. The effects of war in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped changes in south-eastern Europe. In the Commonwealth of Independent States, many countries continue to have deep economic and political ties with Russia.
Political structure: All 27 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular, the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Fiscal and monetary policy levers are currently being used to the full across Europe to counter the damaging economic impact of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and lockdown measures. Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-notably those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at EU level. A total of 19 EU members share the euro as their currency and are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank. They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have sometimes been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis, several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) received financial support from the EU and the IMF in return for fiscal and economic reforms. Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster-and more successfully-with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary Political stability
- The political fallout from the coronavirus crisis could be far-reaching and political risk will remain high in Europe during the forecast period (2020-24).
- As the crisis continues through 2020-21 it will exacerbate existing fault lines within the bloc and may over the medium term lead to greater ruptures.
- Popular disaffection with traditional mainstream parties will persist, leading to a more fragmented political landscape and fractious coalitions.
- The European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, put forward an ambitious policy agenda in 2019, but the coronavirus emergency, and political divisions in the EU, will delay progress in many areas.
- The UK left the EU on January 31st 2020 and is in a transition period until the end of this year. There will not be an extension of the transition. A minimal free-trade deal is still possible, but the risk of no deal has increased.

Economic policy
- Extraordinary monetary and fiscal policy levers are being used to counter the damaging economic impact of the pandemic and national lockdowns.
- The European Central Bank (ECB) is playing an important role in maintaining market sentiment, keeping access to financing open even for the most indebted members of the euro zone and limiting the risk of a debt crisis.
- At the national level, emergency fiscal plans have been rolled out rapidly, with liquidity support for companies and households, but disagreement has delayed progress on an EU-wide recovery fund.

Economic growth We expect the euro zone to contract sharply in 2020, by 8% as a consequence of the supply- and demand-side shock resulting from the coronavirus pandemic.

- East European economies will also experience a deep economic slump in 2020, and commodity producers will be badly affected by an oil price crash.
- The recovery will be slow. We do not expect any European economy to regain 2019 real GDP levels until 2022; many will do so in 2023; some in 2024.

Business environment rankings
- The negative economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic will result in a deterioration in business environments in most European countries.

EU27: EU14 plus EU13
Political outlook: Political stability The political fallout from the coronavirus (Covid-19) crisis is likely to be far-reaching, with implications for government stability and EU unity. As the crisis continues through 2020-21 we expect that it will exacerbate existing fault-lines within the bloc and may over the medium term lead to ruptures.
Political ramifications of the crisis are likely to be far-reaching During the first phase of the pandemic in Europe, which started in February 2020, public support for governments rose, as tends to be the case during times of crises. However, this did not last everywhere. The polarisation of government and opposition has for the most part continued in most countries in the face of the public health emergency. In some countries, especially those that have imposed harsh lockdowns-notably in France, Italy and Spain-existing public dissatisfaction with governments may have intensified. The eruption of protests in European cities in June in response to the brutal police killing of George Floyd (a civilian) in the US may, to some extent, have been a vehicle for the release of pent-up anger and frustration with the domestic authorities after months of being in lockdown.
It is unlikely that political peace will reign for long once countries emerge from the first phase of the public health crisis, if only because the economic and social challenges confronting them will be enormous. Afterwards, governments will face intense scrutiny of their response. Nationalist parties that oppose globalisation are likely to make renewed calls for curbs on migration and reshoring of supply chains, and can expect a bump in popularity. This is likely to worsen the fragmentation of European politics, which has made forming stable and cohesive coalitions difficult in recent years.
Europe divided: schisms between north and south sharpen The crisis has brought underlying tensions and conflicts in the EU bloc to the surface, and is likely to accentuate them. One example is the acrimonious debate over what kind of rescue package and recovery fund would be suitable in the current circumstances. Negotiations over a financial package in April led to ill-tempered public exchanges and soured the mood in the bloc. A compromise was eventually reached to provide EUR540bn in credit lines, but this was of limited help to countries that lacked fiscal space. Talks on a more ambitious response were deadlocked until a Franco-German proposal for a EUR500bn recovery fund in mid-May. This marked a major shift in the German position, with the acceptance of joint debt issuance and grants for the worst-hit countries, and opened the door to the European Commission's EUR750bn proposal, which is currently under discussion. It faces resistance from some northern countries, and must receive unanimous backing from all 27 governments (and parliamentary ratification) to pass. The magnitude of economic support provided is of less importance than the political statement made: this fund could set a precedent for a fiscal economic stabilisation tool in the EU.
Intra-bloc disagreements will persist, however-and not just regarding fiscal integration. An early May ruling by Germany's constitutional court in Karlsruhe (a German city) openly questioned the authority of the European Court of Justice (ECJ) and the soundness of its 2018 judgement over actions taken by the European Central Bank (ECB) in 2015. The episode highlighted long-standing uncertainty in the EU legal order over the prerogatives of European institutions versus those of national legal bodies and could lead to further challenges.
Other threats to European political stability over the medium term include the damaging impact of the UK's decision to leave the EU; the impact of the "America First" policies put in place by the US president, Donald Trump; disagreement over how to manage migration policy and the proper balance between national sovereignty and "pooled sovereignty"; and increased divergence over values between political elites and electorates.
Brexit will present a major challenge to the unity of the EU in the medium term The UK's departure from the EU in January 2020 will pose a major challenged to the unity of the bloc in years to come. The country's departure has left a hole in the EU budget, which will be difficult to overcome without generating antagonism within the bloc. Brexit resulted in increased European solidarity, because leading member states such as France and Germany were keen to send a strong political message that a departure from the bloc would be more damaging for the exiting member state than for the EU. However, over the medium to longer term such unity could fray, especially if the UK thrives outside the EU.
Building consensus for strategic change at the European level will be difficult The coronavirus crisis presents a huge challenge for the new European Commission, which took office on December 1st 2019 after a protracted process of appointing candidates to the top jobs following the European Parliament elections in May 2019. In July EU heads of state reached a compromise on Ursula von der Leyen as European Commission president; Christine Lagarde as the president of the European Central Bank (ECB); Charles Michel as president of the European Council; and Josep Borrell as high representative for foreign affairs and security policy. After presenting an ambitious policy agenda in late 2019, Ms von der Leyen's Commission has so far performed poorly in response to the coronavirus crisis.
The deep recession confronting the entire bloc in 2020 and a focus on the post-coronavirus economic recovery are likely to sideline much of Ms von der Leyen's policy agenda. This was supposed to address issues such as climate change, technology and demographics, with a European Green Deal that aims to make the EU carbon neutral by 2050 to be presented in the first half of 2020. We expect the Commission to face significant challenges-in the first instance from policy disagreements over the funding of the recovery phase. Negotiations on the seven-year multi-annual financial framework are likely to be even more acrimonious in the context of the economic damage done by the pandemic. Building consensus on difficult issues within a fragmented European Parliament will be a tough task.
Political outlook: Election watch General elections across Europe since 2017 have confirmed rising disaffection with the political establishment, which has been reflected in the decline of the two-party system and the rise of insurgent populist parties. Increasing political fragmentation across the region has resulted in a more complicated policymaking outlook, but has also made forming governments more difficult and given rise to some unusual coalitions. The snap election held in Ireland in February 2020 was not an exception to this trend, with the incumbents and traditional opposition parties trailing an insurgent Sinn Fein in terms of the popular vote. The two traditional government parties, Fine Gael and Fianna Fail, are trying to assemble a very broad coalition government involving some smaller parties.
A few elections were held in the first few months of 2020, but several were postponed in the wake of the crisis, including two scheduled for April in Serbia and North Macedonia. Serbia's rescheduled parliamentary election on June 21st resulted in a landslide victory for the ruling Serbian Progressive Party of the president, Aleksandar Vucic, and will deepen concerns about creeping authoritarianism there. The postponed election in North Macedonia will be held in July, and Montenegro has brought its parliamentary election forward to August. Five presidential elections and four other parliamentary elections are due to be held in 2020. All except a presidential election in Iceland are in eastern Europe It is not yet clear whether they will all occur, raising troubling questions about how to ensure the continuation of democratic politics and the accountability of governments during the pandemic.

Political outlook: Intra-and inter-regional tensions The EU would like to play a stronger international role in the context of a less predictable global environment, in which the US is a less reliable partner for Europe and China has become a "systemic rival". However, we are sceptical about how much the EU will be able to achieve, given its lack of military capabilities and differences in foreign policy interests among its member states. The EU's slow response to the flare-up of US-Iran tensions in January was indicative of the difficulties that it faces in responding to developing situations. The pandemic may result in an accelerated bifurcation of US and Chinese supply chains, pushing the EU into having to choose between the two.
With the US more domestically focused, geopolitical dynamics are changing Russia has also sought to play a greater role in global affairs over the past decade, and has taken advantage of the vacuum left by the US as that country has retreated from the world stage. In civil conflicts in Syria, Ukraine, Libya and Yemen, the US and Russia, as well as their regional allies, such as Saudi Arabia and Turkey (for the US) and Iran (for Russia), have backed opposing sides and established themselves as critical partners for making war and seeking peace. As such, relations between the EU and Russia, although thorny, will remain pragmatic. Economically, Russia faces a hit this year from both the coronavirus and the oil price crash, and its economy will contract.
Hungary and Poland will continue to clash with the EU over illiberal policies The governments in Hungary and Poland have come into conflict with the EU over the EU's refugee-relocation policy, and have also clashed over values, counterposing their own nationalist, socially conservative outlook with the cosmopolitican, liberal values espoused by the EU. The European Commission has criticised the Hungarian and Polish governments for curbing the independence of the judiciary, establishing government control over the public-service media and clamping down on civil society groups. The Commission has referred several of these measures to the ECJ, but has so far struggled to find an effective response. Steps taken by the Commission and the European Parliament since December 2017 to invoke Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, possibly resulting in the suspension of a member country's voting rights, are unlikely to succeed, as they require the unanimous vote of all members, and Hungary and Poland have made clear that they would support one another in such an event.
Turkey's foreign policy with the EU and US will be increasingly confrontational Turkey's relationships with the EU and the US have shifted under the Justice and Development Party (AKP) since the early 2000s. Declining trust in the US and the EU, and an ambition to make Turkey a regional power have incentivised the AKP to pursue a "Turkey First" approach to foreign policy. By putting its interests first, the country has started to establish transactional co-operation with countries with which it was previously a rival or had limited relations, such as Russia and China. On the downside, Turkey's foreign policy will leave the country strategically isolated, and Turkey's relationship with the US will become increasingly transactional.
The EU has labelled China a systemic rival, and the BRI divides opinion The EU has labelled China a "systemic rival" and has adopted a regulation setting up a framework to scrutinise foreign investments from non-EU countries, a move that is widely understood to be directed towards foreign direct investment (FDI) from China. Since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, EU and national-level screening processes have been tightened. The EU supports improving connectivity between Europe and Asia (as pointed out in the EU Connectivity Strategy), but it has not formally come out in support of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)-China's flagship foreign policy initiative that aims to create a "New Silk Road" of trading routes and to expand China's economic and diplomatic ties. However, despite the EU's reluctance to support the BRI, several European countries have signed up to it, including Italy, Portugal, Greece and a number of countries in the western Balkans.
One of the points of concern for the EU regarding the BRI is the near monopoly that Chinese companies enjoy in implementing these projects. Until transparency regarding the terms of BRI funding improves and the procurement processes are made more inclusive and competitive (allowing for participation from European companies), the EU is unlikely to change its stance on the BRI.
Macroeconomic policy The policy response will be substantial, both at national and regional levels Fiscal and monetary policy levers are being used to the full across Europe to counter the damaging impact of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and lockdown measures on the economies of the region.
At the national level, emergency fiscal plans were rolled out rapidly, with liquidity support for companies and measures to prevent a spike in redundancies. Germany, which has long stood by its "balanced budget" rule, has presented the biggest financial assistance programme in the EU, with up to EUR1.2trn (35% of German GDP) to be made available. EU-level fiscal action is being hotly discussed, with concerns about moral hazard being weighed against the imperative of providing economic support.
After lengthy negotiations, euro zone finance ministers reached an agreement on April 9th on a EUR540bn European financial package. The measures are significant, but given the magnitude of the crisis, they are insufficient. The European Council discussed a more ambitious plan at its meeting on April 23rd, but failed to reach a conclusion, instead instructing the European Commission to work on a comprehensive recovery plan.
The Commission is negotiating an EU-wide fiscal package that will comprise joint debt issuance and fiscal transfers. The current proposal involves EUR500bn in grants and EUR250bn in loans for 2021-24; it has the support of France and Germany-after a substantial shift in the German position-but still faces resistance from some north European member states. The size of this fund is less important than the political statement that it makes: should it be approved, it would set a precedent for an EU fiscal economic stabilisation tool.
Negotiations on the 2021-27 multiannual financial framework (MFF), which started two years ago, had made little progress before Europe was hit by the coronavirus pandemic. Following the UK's departure from the EU, disagreements have centred on the size of the budget contribution (1% versus 1.1% of gross national income) and the allocation of the budget. The European Commission now wants to turn the MFF into the centre-piece of the post-coronavirus economic recovery fund.
ECB plays a pivotal role, but the scale of crisis is much bigger than in 2008 The European Central Bank (ECB) as until now been the main player maintaining market sentiment, keeping access to financing open across the bloc and dampening the risk of a debt crisis. With the policy rate already at -0.5%, the ECB has expanded its existing asset-purchase programme, adding a EUR1.35trn emergency programme (10% of euro zone GDP), and loosened the rules so that it can comfortably expand its balance sheet, front-load purchases and target economies with acute funding needs. This has pushed the ECB to its institutional limits, fuelling existing political opposition, most notably from Germany. In the UK, in contrast, the Bank of England (the central bank) is enjoying unprecedented monetary policy co-operation with the British government.

In the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, the conservative fiscal bias that has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis of 2008-09 has had to be abandoned. The outbreak of the public health crisis triggered a cascade of policy responses by European governments, which converged on a suite of radical fiscal measures designed to keep businesses afloat for a closure period of several months and to provide basic support for individuals, under the expectation that unemployment is likely to spike to unprecedented levels. For businesses, these initiatives generally include tax holidays or deferments, aid to targeted sectors and, most critically, business loans in the hundreds of billions of euros. For households, governments have mostly adopted some combination of two initiatives: either providing direct cash grants to households (generally, or for individuals such as the self-employed); or agreeing to pay the wages of employees who are furloughed during the period of lockdown.
Although a surge in bankruptcies has been avoided for now, this will not necessarily be the case once governments start to unwind their packages. Once the acute phase of the crisis is over and businesses are no longer receiving exceptional support, it is likely that a significant portion of firms will fail, and that governments will be presented with a difficult choice between preventing a corporate debt crisis-and a potential surge in unemployment-and not supporting "zombie" firms that are unsustainable and will stymie future economic growth.
The public debt accrued during the coronavirus crisis will be substantial, well above levels achieved after 2008, and debt/GDP ratios will be much higher as well. In addition to funds already pledged for relief, governments will probably need to engage in further demand-side stimulus once the acute phase of the crisis has passed-probably later this year. Even if funding conditions are favourable for governments and corporates, they will still weigh on balance sheets. Actions to preserve economic activity during the crisis have been enacted largely without regard to the fiscal impact, but Keynesian fiscal stimulus in the second half of the year will be easier to contemplate for countries that had more fiscal space going into the crisis.
In the light of the populist backlash against austerity that followed the 2008-09 crisis, governments are all too aware that it would be politically costly to return to austerity. Furthermore, central banks' actions in recent weeks have normalised previously unthinkable levels of monetary-fiscal co-operation. As a result of these political and economic forces, a return to "normal" (involving shrinking central bank balance sheets or higher interest rates) now appears impossible. We expect that the role of central banks in backstopping government debt to continue in the medium term. More broadly, in the EU and the UK higher debt levels underpinned by low interest rates will become the new normal for the 2020s.
Macroeconomic policy: Monetary policy and exchange rates Interest rates (av; %) 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
Euribor -0.4 -0.4 -0.4 -0.3 -0.2 -0.1
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate 2.2 1.2 0.8 0.5 0.9 1.4
US 10-year government bond yield 2.1 1.1 1.4 1.9 2.3 2.6
10-year German government bond yield -0.2 -0.4 -0.2 0.3 0.7 1.1
Monetary policy in the euro zone had already become much more accommodative from September 2019, when the ECB launched an open-ended quantitative easing programme (QE2) at a monthly EUR20bn and lowered the deposit rate to -0.5%. However, in response to the coronavirus crisis, the ECB has extended its anti-crisis policy tools.
Among the most effective is the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP), designed to be temporary and flexible, allowing the ECB to expand its sovereign bond holdings, front load purchases and take more risk on to its balance sheet (by buying short-term corporate debt of sufficient quality and Greek government bonds). Starting with an initial size of EUR750bn, the PEPP was then increased to EUR1.35trn (10% of euro zone GDP) and extended until mid-2021. The ECB has also preserved an ample degree of liquidity in the banking system. First, it made some refinancing operations cheaper-the interest rate for longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) was lowered to -1%-and others more accessible for non-bank financial intermediaries. Second, it eased the rules around the collateral that banks can use in exchange for central bank liquidity, effectively preventing a wave of asset-price devaluations from constraining bank lending to the economy.
At its current pace of EUR30bn per week, PEPP will be exhausted by February 2021. The ECB may slow the rate of purchases, but it may also increase the size of the programme once again. Other options on the table for the ECB involve incorporating high-yield debt into its asset purchases or cutting its deposit rate further, from -0.5% currently (especially given the recent appreciation of the euro). Overall, the ECB is strongly committed to preventing financial fragmentation in euro zone funding costs, which minimises the risk of a sovereign debt crisis in highly leveraged economies. Its willingness to act as a lender of last resort dates back to 2012, when the then president, Mario Draghi, vowed to do "whatever it takes" to preserve the currency union. The ECB will continue to play a major supportive role, but the size of the crisis requires large-scale fiscal intervention by governments and EU-led regional transfers. Political and legal risks stemming from conservative German opponents of the ECB's actions are significant, but do not represent an immediate threat to monetary policy.
The coronavirus has exposed the limits of monetary policy in the context of an ultra-low interest rate environment. However, central banks have pursued non-conventional measures aimed at ensuring adequate liquidity in response to the crisis. Central banks in advanced economies already had interest rates at, or close to, zero. Other banks, including the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank), have cut their rates to zero, in effect exhausting their interest-rate tool. Central banks' primary policy objective now is to step up their role as the buyer of last resort for government and corporate debt. This will allow fiscal policy to expand as necessary to backstop businesses-and households-for as long as quarantines and lockdowns persist, and at the same time to prevent a spike in interest rates that would normally accompany this level of spending. The BoE announced massive government and corporate bond-buying schemes, of £200bn, to facilitate this.
The euro will remain weak until the end of 2021 The euro:US dollar exchange rate has been volatile since February. Growing concerns about the economic prospects of euro zone countries caused the euro to fall below US$1.1:EUR1 between mid-March, when many European governments started to impose lockdowns, and mid-May. The euro recovered in the second half of May, after the French and German governments put forward a proposal to issue EU debt up to EUR500bn and use that money to support the most-affected member states via grants. The euro strengthened further on the back of additional monetary stimulus by the ECB, which boosted investors' confidence by increasing the volume of asset purchases under its pandemic emergency purchase programme to EUR1.35trn (US$1.52trn). The euro is likely to firm slightly against the US dollar in the second half of the year, but we do not expect a sustained recovery in the European currency before 2022.
Brexit and weak fundamentals will hold back the sterling over the medium term The British pound experienced high volatility in March as the global run on the US dollar caused it to fall by more than 12% against the US currency, to its lowest level in 35 years. Although it partly recovered in April, its value over the short term will remain sensitive to concerns about the impact of the coronavirus on the domestic economy and to developments in EU-UK trade negotiations, and it will remain volatile in 2020-21. From 2022 onwards the pound will appreciate gradually against major currencies, but its value over the medium term will be held back by weak fundamentals. These include a large current-account deficit, which implies vulnerability to external funding conditions, and the UK's withdrawal from the EU, which led to a structural decline in the underlying value of the currency.
Turkey faces a risk of another sharp depreciation of the lira The Central Bank of Turkey in April 2020 slashed its main policy rate by a total of 1,525 basis points, to 8.75%. On May 21st it slashed rates by a further 50 basis points, to 8.25%. This dovish bias reflects political pressure to lower interest rates. Inflation is relatively high, which has pushed real policy rates deep into negative territory. The recent interest-rate cuts have put substantial downside pressure on the lira. We expect lira volatility to continue in the remainder of this year, leading to a nominal depreciation of 19.8%, to TL7.07:US$1 on average and TL7.75:US$1 at the end of the year. Our bearish outlook for the lira is a result of a combination of factors, including deep negative real interest rates, a wide fiscal and current-account deficit, continued credit expansion and the central bank's dovish bias.
Russia is operating an accommodative monetary policy to counter the crisis The Central Bank of Russia (CBR) cut its main policy rate-the one-week repurchase (repo) rate-by 50 basis points, to 5.5%, on April 24th. This was the seventh consecutive rate cut since June 2019, bringing the total to 225 basis points. We expect additional 50-basis-point cuts to 5% by end-2020. However, we believe that the CBR will refrain from cutting rates too aggressively as positive real rates will be critical to support the rouble. The CBR has played a crucial role in stabilising the rouble since March. In March-May the CBR sold about US$6.5bn to support the rouble. The currency depreciated by 23% from January 1st to March 21st, to Rb80:US$1, but has been on an appreciatory trend since. By early June the rouble had dipped back to under Rb70:US$1, largely because of the CBR and Ministry of Finance's foreign-currency sales, but also because of Russia's robust fiscal backdrop and real positive yields, making Russian assets attractive to foreign investors. We forecast that the rouble will average Rb71.3:US$1 in 2020, a 9.2% annual depreciation against the dollar.
Currencies risk in eastern Europe has risen in the wake of the crisis Macroeconomic risks for much of eastern Europe are firmly tilted to the downside. With the exception of the Baltics, Slovakia and Slovenia-all of which use the euro-increased exchange-rate volatility in the light of deeply negative interest rates will burden countries with large external debt overhangs. External debt ratios are particularly high in Kazakhstan, Croatia and Ukraine, exposing them to currency depreciation and rising borrowing costs. Currency weakness combined with wide current-account deficits in Kazakhstan, Romania and Serbia raises the risk of balance-of-payments crises. Fiscal deficits are expansive in Romania, Turkey and Ukraine; Croatia and Hungary exhibit high public debt levels, weakening their ability to implement large-scale stimulus measures. With the exception of Russia, all countries in the region have negative net international investment positions, making them more vulnerable to sudden portfolio outflows.

The coronavirus will result in a sharp economic contraction in 2020 Europe is heading for a historic recession, with both production and consumption collapsing in the first half of 2020 as a consequence of the pandemic and containment measures. We expect Italy and Spain to see the deepest contractions in western Europe, given their heavy caseloads and comparatively long and strict lockdowns. We forecast a bounce-back from the third quarter, but this will reflect base effects rather than a robust return of economic activity. Global supply chains will remain disrupted, unemployment and business failures will continue to rise and consumers will remain cautious. Southern Europe, which depends on tourism, will struggle for longer as quarantines and weak confidence hold back holidaymakers.

Growth rates will pick up in 2021, but will still only allow a partial recovery: we forecast that GDP in western Europe will not return to its 2019 level until 2023. This is a noticeably slower trajectory than the one we expect in the US, reflecting greater dependence on global export demand and a slower structural adjustment in the wake of the crisis (reflecting a reliance on furlough schemes in addition to unemployment benefits). Variations across the bloc will be determined by fiscal starting positions. Germany has presented the largest fiscal assistance plans in the EU and accounts for almost half of emergency state aid packages in the bloc (the European Commission's fiscal and state aid rules have been temporarily relaxed). Italy, by contrast, has much less fiscal room and higher financing costs, and is struggling to channel fiscal support efficiently to recipients. UK growth was already slowing in 2018-19, but the coronavirus crisis will cause a severe contraction in 2020, when we forecast that real GDP will contract by 8.7%. Brexit uncertainty is likely to slow the recovery in 2021.
Economic resilience to the crisis diverges across eastern Europe The countries of eastern Europe that implemented strict containment measures at an early stage (such as the Czech Republic and Poland) registered comparatively few cases and will make a faster economic recovery than western Europe. However, this recovery will be limited by these countries' dependence on export demand. From 2021 they may benefit from some "near-shoring" of supply chains as west European manufacturers look to reduce their reliance on China. Some countries (such as Romania) have experienced reverse migration, which could also provide an economic boost.
In contrast, the countries that initially downplayed the threat of the virus (such as Russia and Turkey) have had more severe outbreaks and will recover more slowly. We forecast that real GDP in Turkey will contract by 5.9% in 2020, which would be a worse recession than that following the global financial crisis, before rebounding by 4.3% year-on-year in 2021; but we project that real GDP will surpass its fourth-quarter 2019 level only by end-2022. Oil producers such as Russia will also struggle with low oil prices and low demand from western Europe, raising financial stability risks. Russia's economy will endure a deep recession in 2020, as the coronavirus pandemic is weighing heavily on the local economy and external demand for crude oil. However, after an initial tepid government response, fiscal policy is turning more supportive.
Faced with high external debt obligations and wide fiscal and current-account deficits, many non-EU countries in the region are turning to the IMF for emergency support. The poor economic outlook warrants aggressive monetary policy responses, but the available monetary policy tool kits differ across the region. Most EU members are able to resort to unconventional easing measures, but most countries in south-east Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) that have less policy credibility or are prone to inflation will refrain from using unorthodox tools.

Consumer price inflation in the euro area will be dampened in 2020 by the oil price crash in mid-March (we now expect Brent crude to average US$38.1/barrel this year, with a risk that it will go much lower), and the hit to demand from the coronavirus and associated containment measures. This will be offset only slightly by shortages resulting from supply-chain bottlenecks and a surge in demand for some goods, such as medical supplies. We expect annual inflation to remain subdued in 2020, with inflation strengthening gradually from 2021 as economic activity recovers, and further supported from 2022 by a rise in oil prices. We forecast an annual average inflation rate of about 1.5% in 2021-24.
Inflation across eastern Europe has, in general, been muted in recent years, despite relatively strong macroeconomic backdrops. In commodity-dependent Central Asia and Russia, inflation has been higher, reflecting the cyclicality of global oil prices and exchange-rate movements. Turkey is an outlier in the region and tends to have higher inflation because of the Central Bank of Turkey's dovish bias, a steadily weakening currency and an economic structure that is dependent on rapid credit expansion for growth. Supply-side disinflation from low commodity prices and muted domestic demand will suppress price pressures in 2020. This means that deflationary pressures will be notable across eastern Europe in the coming months, similar to in 2015-16, after the previous oil price crash and weak economic growth. However, the coronavirus crisis has resulted in a synchronised monetary easing cycle across eastern Europe (except in some Central Asian economies), despite most local currencies experiencing sharp depreciations against the US dollar and euro. As a result, unconventional monetary policies and large fiscal-stimulus programmes, together with disrupted supply chains and possibly a quick recovery in household demand towards the end of the year, could fuel inflationary pressures later on.

Business environment rankings cover 82 countries The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of 11 categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into a total of 11 categories.
The negative economic fallout from government measures to mitigate the coronavirus pandemic will become clear in coming quarters and is likely to result in a deterioration in business environments in most European countries in the forecast period (2020-24), especially in the first few years, compared with the historical period (2015-19). This will reverse the improvements made during the post-2009 crisis period. Apart from having a negative impact on macroeconomic policy and market opportunities, the pandemic is likely to have far-reaching implications for policy toward private enterprise and competition, trade and investment policies, taxation, labour markets and infrastructure.
Western Europe is ranked second globally out of six regions, after North America, and eastern Europe is ranked fourth, after North America, western Europe, and Asia and Australasia, but ahead of Latin America and the Middle East and Africa.
EU countries and Nordics score particularly well in our rankings EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of countries in western Europe in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (social and political tensions notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Business environment in eastern Europe has improved since 1990s The investment climate of central and eastern Europe has improved considerably in recent years. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even there. Factors such as a low-cost, but well-qualified, labour force, proximity to developed markets, and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region over the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges, including high levels of emigration, a declining workforce and a high social security burden. Meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. Throughout the region, the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable. In Russia, the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the Russian government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. However, low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to seek to open up and diversify their economies.
Data sources and definitions Methodology The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - Ahead of the general election in February 2021, the centre-left president, Lenín Moreno, will struggle to manage the fallout from languishing global oil prices and the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Mr Moreno's administration will seek to stabilise the public finances and pursue reforms under the auspices of the IMF. Fiscal prudence amid a harsh recession will significantly raise the risks of political instability and social unrest. Although The Economist Intelligence Unit currently expects a centrist candidate to win the presidency, the outlook is highly nebulous, partly owing to the fallout from the pandemic. Our election forecast is underpinned by our view that there is insufficient support for a far-left government to win, even in a second-round run-off. However, worsening economic conditions raise the risk of a populist government winning. Regardless of the outcome, sizeable barriers to governability and stability will persist, considering the highly fragmented political landscape.

Ecuador--highlights: Business environment outlook

4.64 5.42 69 67 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.

- Some improvements in the business environment have begun to materialise since a shift to a more market-friendly government in recent years, particularly in terms of official policy towards foreign investment and private enterprise. However, economic volatility on the back of the coronavirus pandemic and political instability will force the government to back-pedal in some areas, hampering the overall pace of improvement. Structural impedi-ments, such as inadequate access to local finance and the small market size, will remain difficult to tackle. We assume that the next administration will retain broadly similar policies, but political risk remains elevated, and there is a possibility of policy reversals. The risk of a disorderly debt default will also constrain investment in the near term.

- The coronavirus crisis will pummel Ecuador's state finances and engender a severe recession that will weigh heavily on the economic outlook in the forecast period (2020-24). A retrenchment in public spending to stabilise government finances will feed through indirectly to private consumption, which will be hindered by a deterioration of the labour market. Even assuming that the virus is contained and that domestic and global economic conditions improve, the medium-term economic recovery will be sluggish. Dollarisation provides a basis for macroeconomic stability, but absent significant improvements to the business environment, a more robust economic trajectory is unlikely.

- A falling birth rate is contributing to slower population growth, but at an annual average rate of 1.3% per year in 2020-24, Ecuador's population growth will be on a par with that of its Andean neighbours. In this period the growth of the labour force will exceed that of the country's overall population and the labour force growth of more advanced countries, giving rise to a demographic dividend that could provide some upside to convergence with more developed economies in the region.

- Ecuador is one of the smallest markets in our business environment rankings. We expect the domestic market to grow only sluggishly after 2020. Significant mineral reserves will attract oil and mining investors, but opportunities outside these sectors will remain restricted by low purchasing power measured in terms of GDP per head. Persistent income inequality and poverty will hinder robust growth in household consumption.

- Low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador to catch up with more developed countries, provided that policies are implemented to transform its resource wealth into productive investment in other sectors. Ecuador will benefit from dollarisation and incremental improve-ments to the business environment. However, poor prospects for significant improvements to institutions do not bode well for a more stable economic policy direction. Assuming persistent structural deficiencies and inconsistent policymaking decisions, we forecast that long-term investment will be lacking and that income levels will continue to trail OECD levels in the long term.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions remain fragile. External economic shocks have contributed to the ousting of three presidents by popular protest since 1997. The current president, Lenín Moreno, took office in May 2017, succeeding Rafael Correa (2007-17)-the longest-serving president in Ecuadorean history. In February 2018 a series of constitutional reforms introduced by Mr Moreno (including the reintroduction of a two-term limit for the presidency) were approved by referendum. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation, persistent social and fiscal challenges will continue to weigh on governability.
Political structure: The 2008 constitution increased executive power, but has done little to foster institutional capacity to tackle problems such as a politicised judiciary, powerful business lobbies, and mobilised grassroots and indigenous groups. The political system is fragmented. Mr Moreno retains strong executive powers, but his party, Alianza País, lost considerable standing after it splintered following the results of the 2018 referendum.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided macroeconomic stability but exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitive-ness. Modest oil prices during the 2020-24 forecast period, relative to the previous decade, have necessitated fiscal adjustments. The Moreno administration secured a three-year IMF agreement-along with other multilateral financing-in March 2019 to meet various objectives, including putting the public finances on a sustainable trajectory, but programme performance has been lacking. The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will further complicate the government's reform agenda, especially given the lack of fiscal space to counter the hit to the economy and financial system.
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador recorded a trade surplus of US$1bn in 2019; petrol export earnings averaged 39% of total export revenue, compared with over 50% during the commodity boom in the 2000s.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Ecuador has a multi-party democracy. The centre-left president, Lenín Moreno of Alianza País (AP), took office in May 2017 for a four-year term (ending in May 2021), after winning a run-off vote against Guillermo Lasso of the centre-right Creando Oportunidades (Creo). AP had a legislative majority at the onset of Mr Moreno's term, but following a power clash with his predecessor, Rafael Correa (2007-17), the party split in 2018, with Mr Correa's supporters forming a new political bloc, Revolución Ciudadana (RC), which has not yet secured official registration as a political party. Lacking a majority, Mr Moreno counts on support from opposition parties on a piecemeal basis.
Cross-party support is difficult to achieve, however, considering that the political party landscape system is fragmented and fluid. In mid-2019 the biennial reorganisation of the National Assembly gave rise to a novel legislative pact between the AP, Creo and two blocs consisting of legislators from smaller parties, but this fell apart in early 2020 following disagreements between Creo and the AP. Ahead of elections in February 2021 the RC and the conservative Partido Social Cristiano (PSC) will be highly obstructive. However, in the redistribution of legislative committees last May the RC was removed from the Consejo de Administración Legislativa (the legislative administrative committee, a powerful panel that vets incoming legislation), preventing the party from presiding over any legislative panel and thereby curtailing Mr Correa's influence in Congress.

Political outlook: Political stability The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic presents Mr Moreno with two immense challenges before his term ends in May 2021. First, his administration must manage the current health crisis with limited resources. Despite the swift imposition (in mid-March) of strict national lockdown measures, including a daily curfew from 2pm to 5am, the virus has spread rapidly, with more than 37,355 cases reported as at May 25th. A gradual, region-by-region easing of restrictions began on May 4th, but the process will be slow and will raise the risk of a second wave of infections.
The president's second challenge is to stabilise the economy as oil prices languish, lockdown measures stifle activity and external demand shrinks. With no fiscal space to mount a countercyclical response (Mr Moreno has announced aggressive cuts to public spending), the political opposition will be emboldened and the risk of social unrest will be significantly heightened.
These immense challenges will prove awkward for the president to overcome. His party, AP, has 42 seats in the legislature, 27 short of the threshold for a majority. Considering that a general election is approaching (due in February 2021) and that the government is implementing austerity measures amid a crisis, the opposition will offer limited support, and some members of Mr Moreno's party will be reluctant to support his policies. The conservative PSC and the left-wing RC, the faction loyal to Mr Correa, will be overtly obstructionist. Mr Moreno's popularity will provide little upside; his approval rating stood at 14.7% in May, down from 24.7% a year earlier.
Despite this-and although political jockeying will be a constant undercurrent as elections draw near-The Economist Intelligence Unit expects cross-party support for some government policies to materialise. In particular, the conservative Creo may yet extend further support to the government, as it did in mid-May, after Mr Moreno abandoned plans to raise taxes as part of the government's emergency economic legislation. However, even assuming that the government secures enough support to facilitate policymaking, political uncertainties will prevail (rather than dissipate) in the short to medium term, as the economy enters a sharp recession.
There is a high probability that protests will occur in the next few months. Informal employment as a percentage of total non-agricultural employment is over 60%, and there is little relief coming from the government, which does not have the fiscal capacity to help to offset losses faced by informal workers, let alone formal businesses. Austerity measures on top of the worsening economic conditions will amplify the likelihood of unrest. In particular, labour unions and indigenous groups, including the Confederation of Indigenous Nationalities of Ecuador (CONAIE), which was largely responsible for intense protests in October 2019, will pressure the government to change course.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Deeply politicised institutions, an inefficient bureaucracy, a complex and archaic tax system, and corruption have long undermined institutional effectiveness. Although the former administration (led by Mr Correa) initially increased government effectiveness by allowing the executive to bypass a deeply fragmented legislature, Mr Correa's constitutional amendments in 2008 and 2015 tilted discretional power in the executive's favour, reducing accountability.
Mr Moreno has made moderate progress in addressing institutional weaknesses. The 2018 referendum enabled him to restructure the judicial appointment process, introduce term limits for the executive, enact stricter penalties for corruption, move to rationalise real-estate taxation and introduce market-friendly regulations regarding mining investment. Challenges to greater political and institutional effectiveness remain, however; bureaucratic inefficiencies persist, governability is weak and lawmaking is subject to the demands of an array of vested interests, while enforcement is inadequate. These obstacles will be compounded by risks of social unrest. Social groups have the ability to effectively veto government policy, as evidenced by indigenous groups' ousting of three presidents in the run-up to Mr Correa's presidency and, more recently, in the widespread unrest in October 2019 that forced the government to reverse its elimination of fuel subsidies.
Deep-rooted institutional shortcomings will remain a hindrance Since taking office in 2017 Mr Moreno has attempted to remove political interference from the judiciary and curb graft. Results have been mixed. Mr Moreno successfully installed a new panel of judges to the Constitutional Court after the previous court was terminated amid a cloud of allegations of wrongdoing; investigations into alleged malfeasance (including money laundering and other financial crimes) intensified the court's already poor reputational standing due to perceptions of favouritism towards the incumbent political leadership. Nonetheless, inefficiency and corruption remain deeply rooted in the judicial system. The Council of the Judiciary has shown little progress in handling corruption cases, access to legal protection and law enforcement remains flawed, and the lack of effective protection of rights persists.
Although Ecuador has historically had a relatively low crime rate, the security environment has deteriorated over the past decade. There is little chance of marked improvement unless measures are adopted to advance the competence and effectiveness of law-enforcement agencies. There are no home-grown terrorist organisations, but violence has spilled over from Colombia owing to a rise in drug trafficking and related money laundering by groups of dissident guerrillas from the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (FARC), who oppose the peace deal signed in 2016 with the Colombian government. Mr Moreno has bolstered Ecuador's existing international security co-operation efforts, through closer co-operation with the US, as well as organisations such as Interpol and the Financial Action Task Force of Latin America (a regional financial intelligence and anti-money laundering network). However, anti-corruption initiatives have yielded few tangible results. Mr Moreno-and the government that takes over in May 2021-will struggle to make sweeping progress in combating pervasive corruption, which will continue to weigh on political effectiveness.
Political outlook: Election watch The February 2021 general election outlook is highly nebulous at this stage, owing to obscurity caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Notwithstanding uncertainties, we do not expect any party to garner 50% of the first-round vote, or secure 40% with a 10-percentage-point margin of victory over its rivals, which it would need to secure the presidency without a run-off. Mr Moreno has signalled that he does not intend to run. Given his government's commitment to unpopular economic measures and his low approval rating, it is unlikely that a member of his centre-left AP would secure enough support to win outright. A first-round victory for Mr Lasso (the leader of Creo) or for candidates from the PSC or RC is equally unlikely, considering the fractured nature of the political landscape. However, as Mr Correa has the enduring support of about 20% of the electorate, a candidate backed by him (probably from the RC) is likely to play a significant role and reach the second round.
In the event of a second round, we believe that a candidate pursuing broadly centrist economic policies would be most likely to take the presidency. Although a Correa-backed candidate would be well poised to reach the second round, factors (most notably corruption) weigh on Mr Correa's appeal; the former president was sentenced to eight years in prison on bribery charges in April. Meanwhile, the PSC performed well in municipal elections in March 2019, and the appeal of Creo may grow as the party attempts to improve its image through a renewed focus on governance. The vice-president, Otto Sonnenholzner of the AP, may also run, having risen to prominence through his role in spearheading the government's pandemic response. A deepening of the economic crisis-leading to political instability-is a major risk to our outlook.
Political outlook: International relations In the short term, the coronavirus pandemic will encumber Mr Moreno's liberalising trade agenda. We expect limited progress on free-trade agreement (FTA) discussions with the US and on Ecuador's accession to the Pacific Alliance (a regional trade bloc) for the remainder of his presidency. The absence of an existing bilateral agreement with Mexico will present a challenge beyond the near term; before the crisis the two parties ambitiously set February 7th 2021 (the date of general election in Ecuador) as the deadline for an FTA. This appears increasingly unfeasible, and the chances of Ecuador entering the bloc by 2024 have declined considerably, despite support from the presidents in the Alliance and Mexico's foreign minister. In addition to the pandemic, changes in government and policy direction may hinder the accession process.

Ecuador scores poorly in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings and-despite moderate improvements in the country's underlying score and in its global and regional positions-it will remain towards the bottom of our global rankings (67th out of 82 countries) in the 2020-24 forecast period. The improvements mainly relate to changes introduced by the president, Lenín Moreno. His policy stance has proven notably more market-friendly than that of his predecessor, Rafael Correa (2007-17). Although Mr Correa was only in office for the first half of the 2015-19 historical period, it took time for Mr Moreno to reorientate policy away from that of his predecessor, explaining why the average score for 2015-19 remains weak.
The main categories in which Ecuador sees the most marked improvements are those related to government policy; the country's global ranking rises for policy towards private enterprise and competition, foreign investment and taxes. However, further progress (and a sharper improvement in the country's rankings) will be hampered by the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and a collapse in global oil prices, which will impair the economy severely, deepen political divisions and fuel social unrest. Against this backdrop, measures to foster competition, improve the country's regulatory framework and lift foreign investment will take a back seat.
Our forecasts are based on the assumption that the next administration, which will take office in May 2021, retains a broadly similar policy stance to the current government, thereby preserving the gains that Mr Moreno has made in terms of shifting policy away from a state-led development model. However, the outcome of next year's election remains extremely unclear at this early stage; if a more populist administration takes office (a high risk considering the harsh recession this year), policy orientation could alter more radically, prompting a downgrade in the business environment rankings. Regardless of who wins the election, the business environment's long-running structural weaknesses-including the small size of the market, financing constraints and difficulties arising from bloated government bureaucracy-will continue to weigh heavily on Ecuador's investment climate.

Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
