Ecuador's score for the macroeconomic environment category-its strongest area of the business environment by some distance-will remain stable in the forecast period, although its global ranking slips by seven places, to 32nd. However, the country's score is flattered by dollarisation, which keeps inflation low, reduces the risk of periods of sharp currency volatility and reduces (but does not eliminate) the risk of a balance-of-payments crisis. Other areas of the macroeconomic environment, including the quality of official policymaking and strength of economic institutions, score much more poorly. The public finances are also a weak area; large fiscal deficits have resulted in a sharp rise in public debt in recent years, during which time real GDP has either registered low growth or has contracted.
Almost all major performance indicators will weaken, at least during the first half of 2020-24. We expect Ecuador's recession in 2020 to be one of the deepest of all Latin American economies, as the already difficult situation before the coronavirus pandemic reduces the policy levers available to the authorities to cushion the impact of weaker domestic and external demand. Tighter fiscal policy management will fail to prevent a sharp widening of the budget deficit and a further rise in public debt levels, and the current-account deficit is also likely to widen. Financing needs will rise sharply in 2020, highlighting the government's limited access to external sources of finance. We assume that the government's efforts to improve the transparency of the public finances and bolster its fiscal framework will help to secure greater multilateral support, but it is likely to need to reach a restructuring agreement with creditors to avoid a disorderly debt default.
The recovery from the coronavirus-induced recession will be slow and gradual. Oil prices are likely to remain modest in 2020-24 (we forecast that West Texas Intermediate prices, a proxy for Ecuadorean oil export prices, will recover from an average of US$32.2/barrel in 2020 to US$36.5/b in 2021, before averaging US$54.2/b in 2022-24), and production volumes are set to rise only marginally. Likely fiscal retrenchment will hamper the pace of economic recovery. More dynamic overall GDP growth would require faster sustainable rates of growth in non-oil sectors. In turn, this would require greater legal stability and improvements in the regulatory environment, as well as expanded access to foreign markets. Investment and structural reforms in electricity, telecoms and fuel refining would also be needed to reduce the cost of these goods and services to competitive levels. Few of these developments appear likely to materialise in 2020-24.
Business environment outlook: Ecuador's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Fuel subsidies are partially lifted. Implementation of anti-trust policies is subject to politicisation. Select industries (such as mining) benefit from policies promoting supply-side growth.
2022-24: Government continues to scale back state's role in development. Nonetheless, regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector firms. A new public-private partnership model is trialled.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Overtures to foreign firms and pro-business reforms partly offset the government's continual interventionism.
2022-24: Inadequate property rights protection and questions regarding access to foreign arbitration deter investment. New mining projects attract investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Government maintains capital outflows tax and increases import tariffs to protect dollarisation. Efforts to pursue free-trade agreements (FTAs) flounder amid a collapse in global trade and growing protectionism by major trading partners.
2022-24: Supply-side reforms enhance national competitiveness and government begins to phase out capital outflows tax.
Taxes 2020-21: Government implements tax reform to expand tax base and improve collection. Certain exemptions are eliminated, and other burdensome regulations are simplified.
2022-24: Efforts to increase tax collection and tackle tax evasion continue, supporting revenue growth. Tax system remains complex.
Financing 2020-21: Deposit and credit growth weaken amid sharp economic recession, raising risks to banking sector stability.
2022-24: Financing is still below potential, as public-financing needs curb growth of long-term lending to private sector.
The labour market 2020-21: Government takes steps to reduce public wage bill and reduce labour market rigidities.
2022-24: Quality of workforce remains poor. Labour reforms are slow to take effect. Educational outcomes remain weak.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Fiscal constraints lead to cancellation of several projects. Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment achieve little success.
2022-24: Renewed interest in port and airport development sustains new cycle of investment.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Investment to expand fourth-generation (4G) broadband availability.
2022-24: Increasing adoption of civic technologies by government. Fifth-generation (5G) technology remains in its infancy.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.0 5.0 66 58 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and ranking for policy towards private enterprise and competition improve in the 2020-24 forecast period. The moderate improvements reflect Mr Moreno's efforts to shift policy orientation away from a preference for creating or developing state-owned companies in favour of development led by private investment. A full reversal of state ownership is not in prospect, but there has been an increase in the scope for private-sector participation in some regulated sectors of the economy, including infrastructure and mining. However, a deeper liberalisation of policy towards private enterprise and competition is unlikely; monopolies and oligopolies will remain features of Ecuador's business environment, particularly in some sectors (such as the cement, financial, supermarket and steel industries). Although some modest reform progress has been achieved, further progress is unlikely until the coronavirus pandemic has eased. As such, high levels of bureaucracy will continue to constrain private investment and competition in 2020-24.
Price controls persist as government seeks to ease fuel subsidy burden
- Certain goods and services-such as electric power, agricultural chemicals, pharmaceuticals and telephone tariffs-are subject to government price controls. Limited price controls for some basic foodstuffs also exist. However, government subsidies for fuel have proven particularly costly, with the 2020 budget ring-fencing just under US$2bn for these. Mr Moreno has sought to scale back these subsidies but has faced opposition from lawmakers, business interests and the general public. In October 2019 Mr Moreno implemented an executive decree ending fuel subsidies in an effort to help the government to meet its IMF-mandated fiscal targets. However, the move prompted sharp increases in retail petrol prices and caused intense social unrest in Quito, the capital, forcing the administration to withdraw the reform just ten days later. In May, amid the collapse in global oil prices, the government revisited efforts to reduce fuel subsidies, on the basis that a shift in the subsidy regime would not result in a sharp hike in retail petrol prices. The new regime will take effect in July; the authorities will set retail petrol prices, with retailers allowed to sell fuel within 5% of this fixed rate. The rate will be determined by global prices and will reduce the burden of subsidies on state finances. As global market prices remain low, domestic resistance will be less marked than in October 2019, but there could be much more significant public opposition once global prices increase more noticeably (from 2022).
- Although the government has indicated that it is considering welcoming foreign concessions in some state companies, we do not expect any significant moves towards the full (or even partial) privatisation of state-run assets in the forecast period. The main area identified so far by the government is the Corporación Nacional de Telecomunicaciones (CNT, the state-owned telecoms company); in early 2019 the authorities stated that they were looking to launch a tender for a 20-year concession licence to operate CNT, targeting a completion date of the end of that year. The goal is for the state to retain ownership of the company while receiving US$4bn from the investor over the licence period in exchange for operating rights. However, as at May 2020 the tender had not been launched and, given the broader uncertainty amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has sent the country's risk premium skyrocketing, the sale of the concession is highly unlikely, at least in 2020-21. The government has indicated that it is considering the sale of other concessions, including the Sopladora hydroelectric complex and Banco del Pacífico (a state bank); we remain similarly sceptical that these will materialise in the near term. Even assuming that the economy stabilises in the wake of the pandemic, there will be significant public opposition to the sale of stakes in state assets. Moreover, it is unclear whether significant demand exists, as foreign firms may be deterred by mismanagement of state-run companies in recent years, as well as the fact that many lack fully audited accounts (which will complicate estimates of market value).
- The government is pushing for all major infrastructure projects to be developed with private-sector investment, primarily using public-private partnership (PPP) agreements The current PPP legislative framework is based on the Regulations for the Public-Private Partnership Regime, the Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment, and the General Regulations for the Application of the Framework Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment. These were all introduced in 2015-16 and essentially consist of tax breaks-including breaks from import tariffs and value-added tax (VAT) during project construction-as well as a ten-year reprieve from income tax and a reprieve from tax on the repatriation of profits. However, shaky investor confidence will hamper the uptake of PPPs in the near term, and institutional barriers will remain a structural constraint in the medium term. A lack of staff with necessary resources to promote and support PPP development will constrain international interest in potential projects, and ongoing legal insecurity will also remain a cause for concern for investors.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.2 6.0 73 57 10 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Interventionism and a burdensome bureaucracy will persist Ecuador's score for policy towards foreign investment improves firmly in the 2020-24 period, and its position in the global ranking rises from 73rd to 57th. The Moreno government has proven much more willing to engage with foreign investors than its predecessor; it has launched a vigorous drive against wide-spread corruption in government and private business, and has adopted investor-friendly legislation. Broadly speaking, government commitment to crafting policy that provides transparency, clarity and predictability to foreign investors will be moderately stronger in 2020-24 than in 2015-19. However, securing legislative support for deeper structural reforms to improve the business environment is unlikely in the context of the coronavirus pandemic. Ecuador's still relatively weak ranking reflects the likelihood of ongoing government intervention in major sectors, powerful domestic vested interests that will resist some of the government's reform efforts and a weak legal framework. There are risks to the score, particularly if a less market-friendly administration takes office in 2021, or if there is a messy external debt default.

- The state's still considerable role in the economy-combined with a preference for domestic over foreign investment and frequent changes to laws-fostered general uncertainty regarding the security of foreign investments and contractual agreements in the country, particularly under Mr Correa. Under Mr Moreno, the promotion of foreign investment has been much more noticeable, driven in large part by economic expediency. In 2018 legislation came into force that stipulates that disputes over investment agreements must be resolved through arbitration. Even international arbitral decisions are now deemed immediately enforceable in Ecuador, without the need for any further approval by domestic courts. Nevertheless, investors will remain wary regarding judicial security, as the situation could change quickly under a different government. Under Mr Correa Ecuador faced a number of claims at the World Bank's International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) relating to legal disputes between the government and foreign companies; the proceedings dragged on for several years and most cases have only recently been concluded.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.4 6.9 59 60 8 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's economy has traditionally been one of the more open in the region, but foreign trade as a share of GDP fell from close to 70% in 2006 to about 47% in 2019, owing to repeated import and capital-account restrictions, as well as shifts in the government's stance on trade openness. Ecuador's underlying score will inch up only marginally in the forecast period, but its global and regional rankings will both slip. Efforts to diversify export markets to Asia, and to Europe through a free-trade agreement (FTA), have made limited progress and will flounder as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, which will lead to an abrupt fall in global trade flows and spark a growth in protectionism. Ecuador is seeking to join the Pacific Alliance (an integration project that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico) and to sign an FTA with Mexico, but the pandemic is likely to delay both developments. Sporadic trade spats with regional partners are likely to continue, dragging down Ecuador's score in this area.

- Ecuador's trade integration with the US, its biggest export partner, will remain adversely affected by Ecuador's unilateral decision in 2013 to withdraw from the Andean Trade Promotion and Drug Eradication Act (ATPDEA). ATPDEA was an agreement that granted tariff-free access to the US market for about 6,000 goods. The government failed to secure an alternative trade agreement, forcing many non-traditional sectors (such as cut flowers, fruit and vegetables) to lose competitiveness against other Latin American countries that maintained FTAs with the US. Bilateral ties have improved under Mr Moreno; the US and Ecuador were set to meet in April to discuss a potential trade agreement, but the meeting has been postponed on the back of the coronavirus outbreak. Even assuming that talks resume later in 2020, there is little indication that a new FTA is likely within the 2020-24 forecast period.
- There has been some progress in streamlining custom procedures in order to improve efficiency in recent years, although corruption and drug smuggling via overseas shipments remain a problem. A number of electronic procedures and automation processes have helped to speed up the delivery of goods. However, frequent changes to custom duties have acted as a major disincentive for legitimate businesses and will continue to fuel contraband trade in 2020-24.
- The Impuesto a la Salida de Divisas (ISD, a 5% tax on capital outflows) applies to all non-cash, hard-currency transactions of repatriated capital and transfers from banks to external accounts exceeding US$5,000. The authorities have indicated that they will phase the tax out once economic stability improves and the reserves position strengthens, but this is unlikely to happen before the second half of the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.3 6.6 60 47 7 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and ranking for taxation improve dramatically in the forecast period. In the historical period official tax policy stance was volatile and prone to abrupt changes in legislation to meet short-term financing needs. This fuelled uncertainty and was a major impediment to investment. However, under the auspices of the IMF, the current government has made some progress in recent months, passing a tax reform-albeit watered down-in December. The IMF will put pressure on the government to press on with other measures to strengthen the tax system, including boosting the powers of the tax administration to combat widespread evasion and abuse of tax avoidance schemes. Given that these measures will be less politically controversial than hikes in tax rates, there is a reasonable chance that the administration will be able to secure support for this. Assuming that the next government retains these measures, it is likely that, in time, the Servicio de Rentas Internas (Ecuador's tax authority) will begin to establish a better reputation in terms of efficiency.

- The recently approved tax reform raises much less revenue than initially targeted, but it will help to retain IMF backing and could lay the foundations for further amendments to the tax system during the 2020-24 forecast period. The government initially expressed the hope that a new tax reform would lift revenue by 1.5-2 percentage points of GDP, but as the bill was progressively watered down, targeted revenue levels were scaled back. In the end the legislation that passed in December is likely to increase tax revenue by just 0.5% of GDP in both 2020 and 2021. Most of the increase relates to two separate measures: an increase of 0.2% on the income tax rate of companies with revenue in excess of US$50m; and levying income tax on dividends distributed by resident companies to non-resident businesses or individuals. Changes to some consumer taxes, for example levying VAT on digital services such as Netflix or Uber that are charged to credit cards issued in Ecuador, will also raise revenue. The new reforms ease some filing rules and taxes for specific sectors such as agriculture.
- At 12%, the VAT rate is more than five percentage points below the average rate in South America and three percentage points below the average rate in Latin America and the Caribbean. Mr Moreno has so far resisted pressure from the IMF to raise the VAT rate, but renewed efforts to increase VAT during 2020-24 are possible. We view marked VAT hikes as unlikely, owing to the high risk of domestic backlash, but there may be other changes to personal income taxes and consumption taxes in order to lift the tax take, including reducing personal allowances and deductions.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.6 4.8 73 68 9 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for financing in 2020-24 improves noticeably (from a low base), but with similarly ranked countries also making improvements, its rankings improve more moderately. State intervention in the banking sector was a feature of the business environment under Mr Correa but is unlikely to pose a significant risk during 2020-24, explaining the increase in Ecuador's score in this area. Mr Moreno's policy stance has engendered greater confidence among commercial banks as well as their customers, with deposit and credit growth picking up, albeit from a low base. However, many structural problems will continue to complicate corporate access to finance. The country's banking sector remains underdeveloped compared to the size of the economy; financial services are relatively rudimentary, with a small secondary market and two stock exchanges (in Quito, the capital, and Guayaquil) vying with each other for a limited pool of bond and equity issuances. In this context, financing is-and will remain-dominated by bank loans, with only large companies able to secure the lowest rates of about 7%. Smaller companies face rates upwards of 12%, with loan maturities often capped at three years. Long-term bank finance and capital market finance remain underdeveloped and difficult to secure.

- An expected sharp recession in 2020 (and a weak forecast recovery thereafter) poses risks to the financial sector during 2020-24 that could affect companies' ability to access credit. Financial soundness indicators remain reasonable for now, but are likely to deteriorate over the course of 2020. With profit ratios already relatively low, firms could find it more difficult (or costly) to borrow if banks become more cautious about lending. This risk would be elevated if banks experience a run on deposits (the vast majority of which are still held in instant-access accounts).
- Confidence in the banking system is tied to the management of reserve requirements at the Banco Central del Ecuador (the central bank), which is central to sustaining dollarisation but has been the target of regulatory changes. With the government's dollar liquidity needs likely to rise in the forecast period, there is a risk of more aggressive control on bank deposits, with potentially damaging effects on lending and market confidence. The government will continue to seek broad stability in the banking sector, reducing the risk of directed lending policies in 2020-24. However, regulatory changes made since 2014 mean that the possibility of these policies still exists, as the Junta Monetaria (the monetary board) technically retains important discretionary powers. Although it is not part of our central forecast (given the current government's more market-friendly stance), further changes to the regulatory environment cannot be discounted during 2020-24.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.8 5.0 77 76 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Despite marginal improvements in the underlying score in 2020-24, the labour market will remain one of the weakest areas of Ecuador's business environ-ment. An increase in spending on education and training programmes during the oil boom years failed to raise skills levels or productivity, with lower oil prices necessitating subsequent cutbacks. Skills shortages and mismatches remain a problem, compounded by a lack of effective training programmes in both the public and private sectors. Although recent moves to increase flexibility in labour market regulation are positive, the need for fiscal adjustment will cap public investment in education, meaning that long-running and structural problems (such as skills shortages) are unlikely to be tackled. Access to social security has improved for some sectors of the population, but the labour market remains highly informal, which will be difficult to tackle. In comparative terms, labour costs will edge down slightly in 2020-24 but will remain high, particularly relative to productivity.

- The government had been seeking to table a reform bill to increase labour market flexibility and promote job creation, but plans were pushed back as negotiations between the authorities and unions and pressure groups dragged on. However, the government has incorporated most of the planned changes into a broader "humanitarian support" law that was passed by emergency decree in early May in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The changes make it easier to renegotiate labour contracts between employers and employees. Both sides can now agree to salary reductions to avoid lay-offs and can negotiate changes in the number of working hours (and how these are spread, allowing employees more flexibility), with social security obligations and benefits adjusted accordingly. The initial limit for this flexibility in contracts is two years, but contracts can be renewed annually for two more years. There is likely to be domestic resistance, given the public perception that the changes are designed to benefit companies rather than protect jobs, and there is a risk that the law may be reversed (although this does not form part of our baseline forecast). Regardless, the measures are unlikely to stimulate job creation-or even prevent job losses-given the extremely weak underlying investment climate.
- The strength of the US dollar will compound competitiveness problems with other countries in the region in the short term (Ecuador's minimum wage is among the highest in Latin America in dollar terms, although its productivity lags that of most of its neighbours). Although we expect some depreciation of the US dollar during 2021-24, this will be mild and insufficient to boost competitiveness significantly.
- Efforts to improve education will flounder, at least in 2020-21, reflecting the government's difficult fiscal position, which will preclude an increase in public spending. Pledges to construct 40 new universities will not materialise given the current economic climate. As part of the borrowing agreement with the IMF, the government has committed to drawing up an action plan that focuses on ways of improving the efficiency and quality of primary education (although the target date for this plan has been repeatedly pushed back, most recently to the end of June). Aside from uncertainty regarding the source of funding for such investment, long-standing educational challenges will not be addressed. Although net secondary school enrolment has risen in recent years, student results continue to trail those of other countries in the region. Improving results will require a sustained and long-term commitment from the government; even assuming improved quality of education policies, student results would be unlikely to improve until towards the end of (or beyond) our forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.5 5.5 60 59 6 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure was one of Ecuador's stronger areas in the business environment rankings in the historical period, owing to major capital spending by the Correa administration. Although some further improvements in 2020-24 are likely, these will be moderate (reflecting fiscal constraints), resulting in only a marginal improvement in Ecuador's global ranking in this area. A large public investment programme put in place by Mr Correa means that multiple projects are likely to reach completion during the forecast period, given that financing has already been agreed and in many cases, the projects are under way (some, however, have been cancelled owing to project mismanagement, and others have been subject to large cost overruns). These changes mean that after decades of underinvestment-and frequent electricity shortages-the quality of transport, energy and road infrastructure is now comparable to the Latin American median, and telecoms development (measured in mobile and internet penetration) is above the regional average. However, given the need for fiscal consolidation, government efforts to modernise infrastructure will be reined in sharply. The authorities will seek to attract private investment for infrastructure projects, but Ecuador lacks the solid track record of fostering successful PPPs that have helped to upgrade infrastructure in other countries in the region. Weak investor sentiment amid the coronavirus pandemic will also deter private-sector interest, at least during the first half of the forecast period.

- A major focus of the government's infrastructure programme has been the development of new hydroelectric power plants to avoid importing costly energy for gas-fired and thermoelectric plants. In the medium term, there is potential not only to close the supply-demand gap but also, potentially, to allow the country to export energy. On the downside, there are some concerns that projects will fail to reach expected generation levels owing to problems during construction or insufficient government investment in transmission and distribution facilities, which could lead to supply bottlenecks.
- Recent investment has led to road infrastructure improvements and the creation of new road networks. This is helping to boost domestic and intraregional trade, but has also created challenges including congestion, as advances in traffic management have been more limited. Moreover, seasonal heavy rains that are costly and difficult to fully mitigate continue to cause seasonal disruption in some areas. The difficult topography adds an additional obstacle, and there are concerns about misuse of funds. There has been much slower progress on developing mass transport systems to relieve urban congestion, including a much-delayed underground rail system in Quito, which was still not operational as at May 2020, and a tram project in Cuenca (Ecuador's third-largest city), which has been delayed but is now expected to start operations in June.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.0 3.5 73 75 9 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Although Ecuador's score for technological readiness improves in 2020-24, its global and regional rankings are set to slip as other similarly ranked countries make more substantial progress during the forecast period. Its global ranking of 75th makes this area one of the weakest of the business environment, reflecting low smartphone penetration and a lack of spending on research and innovation, which undermine the overall score. However, Ecuador scores relatively well in areas such as preparedness for e-commerce and cyber-security.
The government has set targets to grow the telecoms and information technology sectors. Internet access through mobile phones will drive wider mobile-phone usage during the outlook period as handsets and data tariffs become more affordable and mobile phones are used increasingly in place of personal computers (PCs). We expect data services to be the fastest-growing segment of the mobile market. However, coverage remains inadequate and costs are high, limiting access. Efforts to loosen foreign-owned firms' grip on the mobile market may boost competition, but the investment climate and a complicated regulatory environment for foreign companies will remain impediments. Internet penetration, particularly broadband, has been limited, but we expect it to grow over the forecast period as technology becomes more widely available and connectivity improves. In line with this, the number of overall internet subscriptions will continue to grow.

- The expansion of fourth-generation (4G) technology has so far been limited to a few hub areas. The Correa government imposed high costs on new contracts for mobile-telephony firms in 2008, which slowed roll-out as companies worked to recover costs. Smartphone adoption was relatively late, reflecting low income levels and high tariffs on imported handsets (classified as luxury goods under Mr Correa). In July 2019 the Moreno government launched its Ecuador Digital programme, which aims to increase penetration indicators (particularly in rural areas), improve internet speeds, expand 4G broadband and accelerate the allocation of new telecoms bandwidth, with a view to beginning fifth-generation (5G) testing. The government is also seeking to develop the use of digital identification, implement cyber-security measures and boost e-commerce.
- Rising internet penetration and smartphone usage will help to foster growth in online retail, albeit from a low base. According to the Ecuadorean Chamber of Electronic Commerce (CECE), e-commerce generated US$1.2bn in sales in 2019, up from US$1bn in 2018. In 2020 it anticipates sales of US$1.5bn as rising numbers of Ecuadoreans become regular e-commerce customers, although the coronavirus pandemic is likely to mean that e-commerce sales rise even more strongly.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The coronavirus outbreak will push Ecuador closer to a disorderly default and a balance-of-payments crisis. Avoiding this will require, more than ever, support from the IMF (and other actors), but meeting the conditions required to access these funds will be extremely complicated politically, heightening risks in the coming months. Political pressure to loosen fiscal policy and suspend external debt payments is mounting and will persist, but Mr Moreno will try to maintain fiscal discipline and work to improve the country's credibility. Having made an agreement with private creditors in April to defer interest payments of US$811m due between late March and August 15th, the government will seek an amicable restructuring of its debt with its creditors, rather than trigger a disorderly default.
Mr Moreno's stance will catalyse much-needed multilateral financial assistance. Although the targets of the government's three-year, US$4.2bn extended fund facility (EFF) with the IMF (accompanied by US$6bn in additional multilateral financing, intended to be disbursed between March 2019 and December 2021) are all but feasible, the government was able to access US$643m through the IMF's rapid financing instrument (RFI) in early May. The RFI comes with little conditionality and was disbursed after the government published unflattering data corrections and submitted public financial management reforms to the legislature. In turn, this has facilitated further financing from the World Bank (US$500m) and the Latin American Development Bank (US$300m).
Bearing in mind that the government is working to establish a successor arrangement with the Fund, we expect its commitment to fiscal discipline to be resolute. Negotiations to secure a new agreement will be buoyed not only by fiscal pragmatism amid the coronavirus crisis, but also by the passage of emergency economic legislation in May that goes beyond the immediate necessities of the pandemic; approved reforms to public financial management will reduce discretionary budget changes considerably and help to improve Ecuador's medium-term fiscal framework. The reforms, including a savings fund, will aid talks with the Fund and bondholders alike.
Although the objectives of the government's IMF-backed economic programme have been overshadowed by the policy response to the economic and health crises, the government's policy agenda has not been derailed entirely. The government successfully passed legislation in mid-May that temporarily loosened labour market regulations and in late May announced that fuel imports would be fully liberalised, with prices for consumers guided by global market prices. Unlike the drastic elimination of fuel subsidies in October (which was quickly reversed after protests), a system of price bands with 5% ceilings is to be introduced (on July 1st) to avoid swift increases in fuel prices.
Assuming that a centre-right or centre-left government takes office in May 2021 and provides for policy continuity, we expect that the EFF's four primary objectives will continue to be prioritised in the medium to long term. These are improving competitiveness, tackling fiscal imbalances, protecting the poor and fighting corruption. Moreover, under our political assumptions-and in the light of the unfolding crises-we view IMF assistance beyond 2021 as highly probable. This suggests a piecemeal advancement of business-friendly policies and complementary reforms in 2021-24. Nonetheless, limited progress will be made in diversifying the economy away from oil (the country left OPEC in January to free itself from quotas).
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

Budget balance -2.8 -6.1 -4.1 -2.3 -1.8 -1.3
The government will have some (albeit limited) success in cushioning the blow to the fiscal accounts from the drastic halt to domestic economic activity and lower oil revenue than previously anticipated in the budget. Nevertheless, we expect a widening of the fiscal deficit. Even assuming that spending cuts materialise and that new, extraordinary multilateral and bilateral assistance is forthcoming, this will not be enough to plug the fiscal hole produced by the collapse in oil prices.
On the expenditure side, the government plans to accelerate the downsizing of the state and to reduce spending by a total of US$4bn (about 4% of GDP and 15% of the original 2020 budget) this year. The government intends to reduce the wage bill by US$980m, spending on goods and services by US$400m and capital expenditure by US$1.3bn. It also plans to save a total of US$1.3bn in debt service costs from (previously announced) bond renegotiations. On the revenue side, the government is facing a substantial drop in income; we forecast that falling oil and tax revenue will lead to US$8bn less in revenue for the non-financial public sector (NFPS) compared to last year. The government's targeted fiscal savings are likely to be overly optimistic, however, considering its struggle to dial back spending in recent months and the National Assembly's opposition to increasing taxes amid an economic crisis.
On balance, we forecast that the NFPS deficit will widen to 6.1% of GDP in 2020, assuming that the cut to public spending is much less than the drop in revenue. Public debt as a percentage of GDP will rise from an estimated 46.9% in 2019 to 57.2% in 2020. The fiscal targets set in the government's EFF are not feasible; an improvement of 4 percentage points in the non-oil primary balance/GDP ratio (including subsidies) from 2019 to 2021 and a reduction in the public debt/GDP ratio to 40% by 2024 will not be achieved.
The successor IMF agreement will shed light on how fiscal targets and fiscal policymaking adapt to the looming economic recession. Irrespective of the changes, programme implementation risks will be glaringly high, as social and political challenges to reforms exceed their pre-crisis levels. Without details of a new deal, and assuming policy continuity, we expect that the NFPS deficit will narrow gradually in 2021-24, to 1.3% of GDP by 2024, and that the public debt/GDP ratio will stabilise at about 61%.
We are cautiously optimistic that that the government will avoid a disorderly default, owing to bilateral and multilateral financing-the government estimates that it will receive about US$2bn from multilateral creditors and China-and prudent debt-management operations. Following a final US$325m payment on the capital of a 10.5%, five-year bond in mid-March, the government successfully launched a consent solicitation in mid-April to defer US$811m in interest payments due between late March and mid-August. Although it is not yet our baseline forecast, there is a substantial risk that Ecuador will be forced into a debt restructuring this year, or will fall into disorderly default ahead of larger payments in the second half of 2020.

As a dollarised economy, Ecuador lacks independent monetary policy and will not be able to foment a monetary policy response to the economic crisis. Monetary conditions will continue to be determined largely by external factors, but real local rates will remain elevated, owing to Ecuador's high risk premium. Monetary growth will hinge on foreign-exchange inflows, as well as the confidence of domestic lenders, both of which will be markedly undermined by the rapid deterioration of the economy. The threat of de-dollarisation will sustain the risk of capital flight, which raises the risk of preventative measures being implemented in the short term to protect domestic liquidity levels.

Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts are built on a series of epidemiological assumptions on the novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Without rapid access to a vaccine, we expect that the disease will eventually infect up to 30% of the world's population. We assume that about 15% of symptomatic cases will be severe and that up to 1% of symptomatic cases will prove fatal. Death ratios will depend on a country's ability to detect, track and contain the virus, and the capacity of the national health system. Governments are lifting restrictions on freedom of movement gradually in countries where the number of cases is falling and where there is sufficient spare capacity in the healthcare system. Some countries may be forced to re-impose measures if cases spike again. Based on previous viral outbreaks and the progress made on other coronavirus vaccines (such as that for severe acute respiratory syndrome-SARS), we expect a vaccine to be available by end-2021.
In economic terms, we forecast that global output will contract by 4.2% year on year in 2020 and that global trade will decline by 24.8%. Global GDP will not recover to pre-coronavirus levels before at least 2022; 2020 and 2021 will be lost years for growth. Real GDP will contract in all regions of the world, but the drop in output will be especially severe in OECD countries. All G7 countries and almost all G20 countries will experience a full-year recession in 2020. We expect China's real GDP growth to slow sharply to 1% this year, and forecast a full-year recession in the US, with a contraction of 4%. We assume that oil prices will decline by more than 40% this year, to average US$38/barrel. Most countries have responded with huge fiscal expansion to support businesses and households, raising the risk of sovereign debt crises in the medium term. Central banks have cut interest rates and, more importantly, have stepped up as buyers of last resort for government and corporate debt.
The infection curve in Latin America is about four to six weeks behind that of European countries and about two to three weeks behind that of the US. Most countries in the region, with a few notable exceptions, responded swiftly to the public health threat and implemented strict containment measures. However, by and large, governments were unable to use the time bought by the lockdowns to adequately test, trace and isolate those infected. As a result, Latin America is emerging as a new epicentre for the virus; although the region makes up just over 8% of the world's population, it accounts for close to 14% of confirmed coronavirus cases globally. Despite this, even as the coronavirus caseload continues to grow, policymakers have been left with little option but to evaluate possible exit strategies. The sudden stop to activity has precipitated a dramatic economic collapse, and most governments lack the fiscal space and the institutional capacity to provide support to consumers and business during a more protracted lockdown. Although exit strategies will vary from country to country, most governments are phasing out restrictions in a gradual manner to ensure that the numbers of coronavirus cases and deaths remain under control, health services can cope and public confidence in the handling of the crisis remains strong. Nonetheless, there is a high risk that even a gradual and phased easing will expose countries to a second wave of infections (as has happened in Singapore and South Korea).
The coronavirus pandemic will have a severe economic impact. We forecast a Latin American recession in 2020, with an aggregate contraction of over 7% and output in all of the major economies contracting by 4-10%. Some Caribbean countries, which depend on tourism, will be hit even harder. Quarantine measures will result in a sharp supply-side shock, hitting working hours and productivity, and manufacturers will suffer from a disruption to global supply. Supply-side disruptions will be short-lived, but demand effects will be long-lasting. A decline in confidence is likely to persist after quarantine measures are lifted. For fear of contagion, people may continue to avoid public spaces, and tourism may not resume immediately. Households will limit their consumption in response to a loss of income, and businesses will delay investment.
The longer-lasting political and geopolitical impact of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, with limited parliamentary oversight. Elections have been cancelled, or delayed, in some countries. When the pandemic has passed, governments will face intense scrutiny on their response. A failure to address the humanitarian crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. A severe global economic crisis, followed by renewed fiscal austerity and large-scale unemployment, will fuel a new wave of popular protests. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. The competition for global leadership between China and the US will intensify as a result of the crisis, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other regions. This will provide a challenging environment for Latin America over the medium term as the region tries to grapple with the debt overhang from the extra spending measures and the hit to revenue, as well as lower potential growth rates, owing to the damage to productive sector value chains, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

We expect real GDP to contract by 9% in 2020. Net exports are still likely to contribute positively to growth despite a large drop in export volumes; we expect these to decrease by 15% as external demand falls markedly. However, this drop will be overshadowed by a sizeable 25% decline in import volumes, which will reflect a significant deterioration in domestic demand.
Low oil receipts will lead to a retrenchment in government consumption, indirectly feeding through to private consumption, which will be constrained by a worsening labour market. Economic and political uncertainties will weigh on private investment, which will decline for a second consecutive year. Assuming that the coronavirus outbreak is controlled by end-2020-prompting a recovery in external and domestic demand-we expect real GDP growth to rebound in 2021, but it will remain below 2019 levels.
Political uncertainties will be elevated by the February 2021 general election; this will preclude a more robust pick-up in domestic demand. We expect growth to be tepid in 2022, considering the 2021 rebound, but it should slowly improve thereafter as policy uncertainties wane, oil prices rise and moderate improvements to the business environment materialise.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Notwithstanding the oil price shock and pipeline damage in early 2020, the oil sector will remain of critical importance to the Ecuadorean economy. Oil export earnings comprise about 40% of total export revenue and a third of government revenue. Although oil production will fall below ambitious government targets owing to delays and pressure from environmental and social groups, production will creep up in the 2020-24 forecast period. Increasing public-sector production (accounting for about 80% of national production) will be driven by domestic fiscal needs that precipitated the government's departure from OPEC (to free the country from quotas) at the start of 2020. Private-sector production will expand, aided by a return to a production-sharing contract model, but more robust growth in the private oil industry will be slow, as the government continues to struggle to attract major exploration activities (partially owing to indigenous anti-oil activism).
Growth in the oil sector will primarily emanate from increased production at the 1.6bn-barrel, heavy crude Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini oil field. However, problems in receiving environmental permits have impeded a faster expansion of production. This has also hampered investment in some privately operated fields, which would help to lift production if allowed to proceed. The government has set January 2021 as a target date for the complete merger of the two state-owned oil companies, Petroecuador and Petroamazonas, which is likely to support future production. Petroecuador is currently the downstream company, whereas Petroamazonas is responsible for upstream production. Petroecuador assets could potentially be under consideration in the medium term for a concessionary model, whereby a private firm would administer operations and pass on a portion of the net profits to the state.
Mining sector enters growth phase, albeit with stumbling blocks The mining sector will rise in prominence over the medium term. The sector is another major sector of importance for state finances and is poised to expand, as two major, foreign investor-driven mining projects came online in late 2019: Fruta del Norte (a gold mine) and Mirador (primarily a copper mine). At the beginning of the year the government projected that Fruta del Norte would generate nearly US$500m in export earnings in 2020 (up from US$46m in 2019) and Mirador about US$450m (an 800% year-on-year increase). Earnings will be weaker than the government expected owing to a standstill in mining activity at the height of the pandemic and weaker demand from energy-hungry industries such as construction and manufacturing. Over the medium term, however, the sector will continue to expand (buoyed by the 2019 removal of a 70% "windfall tax" on mining profits) as a series of further projects attract major mining companies that compete for stakes. This contrasts with the oil industry, where top-level interest is limited.
Lingering legal uncertainties and local resistance will, however, clip Ecuador's aspirations to be a mining major. Friction between local communities and mining firms in particular will slow investment. Many mineral deposits are located in environmentally sensitive areas, close to communities that have lodged complaints with local courts alleging that mining firms have failed to undergo consultation processes. A lack of cohesion among anti-mining activists and differences in opinion within Ecuador make the imminent cancellation of major mining projects currently under construction and under advanced exploration unlikely. Our view is that the mining sector will continue to face difficulties that will prevent a more dramatic rise in extractive production.

Tumbling commodity prices, weak demand and a strengthening US dollar will produce deflation this year. Consumer prices were flat in 2019, and we expect them to fall by an average of 0.3% this year. We expect inflation to pick up slightly, to an annual average of 0.9% in 2021-24, as import costs rise owing to renewed dollar weakness and an increase in commodity prices. Dollarisation will help to contain inflation, but the economy will remain vulnerable to increases in food and energy prices.

Risks to dollarisation have risen and remain elevated in the short term. The economic crisis presents major problems of financing and liquidity, as oil prices have crashed and access to global financing remains limited. These problems are likely to be compounded by a short-term strengthening of the US dollar (hurting competitiveness) and a dip in reserves.
Nevertheless, we currently assume that dollarisation will be retained in 2020-24, as the government's commitment to its IMF agreement and to fiscal discipline allows for greater multilateral financing. The real effective exchange rate will remain stronger than its long-term, pre-dollarisation average but in real, trade-weighted terms, there will be some depreciation as the US dollar begins to weaken in 2021-24.

The current-account deficit will widen in 2020 as the macroeconomic back-drop deteriorates. Diminishing oil revenue will weigh significantly on the trade balance in the short term as oil prices languish and external demand withers. Non-oil export earnings will be hit hard, with shrimp and mining exports in particular suffering from domestic restrictions on business operations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus and a retraction of demand in major export markets, including China and the US. Deterioration of the trade balance will be softened by collapsing domestic demand, which will produce import compression. However, remittances are also likely to suffer, as economic activity has ground to a halt outside Ecuador, dragging down the current-account deficit. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will suffer in 2020-21 and remain below 1% of GDP. They will pick up thereafter and average 1% of GDP in 2022-24.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Ecuador Stocks and flows Ecuador has historically attracted relatively little foreign direct investment (FDI). Annual inflows of FDI averaged US$700m in 1994-2008, driven mainly by the oil sector (which accounted for 80% of total FDI). After barely breaching US$1bn in 2008 (1.8% of GDP), FDI inflows fell to only US$165m in 2010. They recovered somewhat to average US$774m (0.8% of GDP) in 2011-17, the final seven years of leadership by the former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), whose policies led to a deterioration in investor confidence. FDI inflows jumped in 2018 and reached US$1.5bn, up by 127% year on year, reflecting the more conciliatory approach to the private sector of the current president, Lenín Moreno. FDI inflows moderated in 2019, reaching US$966m (0.9% of GDP). The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the total stock of inward FDI at US$19.7bn at end-2019. This is one of the smallest stocks among the major Latin American economies, equating to 18.3% of GDP. Ecuador's stock is also small on a per-head basis, estimated at US$1,138 in 2019.
Origin and distribution The US, historically the main source of FDI inflows into Ecuador, went through a period of disinvestment in the country between 2008 and 2010, largely owing to uncertainty surrounding oil contract renegotiations and the global financial crisis. Investment from the US has since moderated, totalling US$76m in 2019 and averaging 7% of total inflows in 2016-19. FDI from China rose after Ecuador established closer trade and diplomatic ties with that country in 2011, but inflows have tapered off recently. In 2019 Chinese FDI accounted for 3% of total inflows, down from 15% in 2016. Foreign investment is primarily directed towards oil, mining and infrastructure projects, as evidenced by the origin of inflows; in 2019 25% of foreign investment originated from Canada (the Fruta del Norte gold mine commissioned last year is owned by a Canadian firm). The manufacturing, agri- and aqua-culture, and retail sectors all attract foreign investment, but extractive industries account for the lion's share of foreign investment, totalling about 50% of FDI inflows in 2018-19.
Determinants Although Ecuador has a wealth of natural resources, policy uncertainty and an unreliable business environment deter investment. Mr Moreno's administration has taken a more active role than its predecessor in attracting private foreign investment; his government has focused on fomenting investment in the extractive sectors, reintroducing production-sharing contracts and eliminating the 70% "windfall tax" on profits in mining. However, stronger interest from foreign investors has not materialised, as the uncertain regulatory and legal environment persists and acts as a conspicuous deterrent. Global prices, also a major determinant, have been soft, discouraging interest. Moreover, Ecuador's weak institutions, small domestic market, relatively high cost of labour and low income levels still deter FDI in most non-extractive sectors.
Impact The impact of inward FDI on productivity and export competitiveness has been limited because most investment has been directed towards capital-intensive natural resource sectors, which have weak links to the rest of the economy. However, FDI has helped to boost export earnings in the energy sector.
Potential The country's strong endowments of natural resources will be a major source of attraction for foreign investors. There are notable FDI opportunities in Ecuador's petroleum, mining, manufacturing and services sectors. Although policy uncertainty, infrastructure deficiencies and low levels of labour productivity persist, we expect incremental improvements to the business environment under the auspices of the IMF, improving the country's competitiveness. A more pragmatic approach to attracting private foreign capital and a shift away from the unorthodox macroeconomic policies of Mr Correa's government will also provide upside to the country's medium-term attractiveness. Still, ingrained opposition from powerful domestic interest groups will continue to complicate efforts to open up investment opportunities in the oil sector. Sluggishness in consumption and tepid recovery after the pandemic in 2020 will also deter investment.

Population growth is slowing In 2019 the population reached an estimated 17.3m, and is expected to rise by 1.2m people by 2024. With a falling birth rate and continued-albeit lower-emigration, the rate of population growth is slowing. However, at an annual average of 1.3% per year in the 2020-24 forecast period, growth will be high compared with developed-country standards and on a par with neighbours in the Andean region. The rate of urbanisation is relatively high; about 64% of the population lives in urban centres, compared with 55% in 1990. This percentage is expected to rise to about 65% by the end of the forecast period. Almost half of city dwellers reside either in the capital, Quito, or in the largest city and main business centre, Guayaquil. Rapid urbanisation over the past 50 years has increased the level of informality, as the creation of full-time jobs has risen at a much slower pace. The unemployment rate was 3.9% at end-2019, which is low by historical standards (and has remained stable year on year), although underemployment remains high, affecting more than half of the workforce. The labour force is expected to continue to expand more rapidly than the overall population during the forecast period, with about 800,000 new labour market entrants in 2020-24. In view of the coronavirus pandemic, the administration of the president, Lenín Moreno, has temporarily increased the flexibility of the labour market; this is positive, but the formal economy will continue to struggle to absorb new entrants, particularly as diversification away from the energy-dominant labour market will be slow (and will focus primarily on mining and agriculture). Informal employment, estimated by the government at 46.7% of the labour force as at December 2019, is therefore likely to stay high.
Although inflows of illegal migrants from Colombia have fallen in recent years, inflows from Venezuela will put strain on the domestic labour market. Ecuador has received more than 400,000 migrants from Venezuela, and the government will struggle to integrate them into the formal market, especially in the wake of the coronavirus-induced recession. The economic fallout from the pandemic and the subsequent slow recovery may well lead to a reversal of Venezuelan migration, with Venezuelans attracted to stronger neighbouring economies.
In 2020-24 The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Ecuador's crude birth rate to fall to an annual average of 19.1 per 1,000 population (down from 20.6 in the 2015-19 historical period). The crude death rate will remain steady, at an annual average of 5.2 per 1,000 population in 2020-24. The old-age dependency ratio, which will rise slightly, reaching 0.13 by 2024, will remain low by developed-country standards. However, given constraints on public spending, an ageing population will place growing pressure on an already heavily indebted social security system, especially as the coronavirus pandemic has laid bare the many deficiencies in the healthcare system. Although the government plans to reduce its divestments from the state-run social security institute, we expect the state-run social security system to encounter difficulties in ending its debt woes.
Slow progress in improving education and healthcare standards The precarious state of the country's public finances will hinder improvements in education and healthcare standards. Strong oil revenue in the 2000s commodity boom allowed for improvements in poverty levels and social indicators following decades of underinvestment in these areas-public expenditure on health services and education doubled as a percentage of GDP under the previous administration. However, low standards and outcomes persist. Some gains receded because of the 2015-16 recession, which led to a spike in underemployment. Regular labour conflicts with public healthcare and education workers, often resulting in industrial action, further hampered improvements in the quality of services. The 2008 constitution promised free universal healthcare and education but-considering its fiscal difficulties in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic-the government will struggle to achieve these goals during the forecast period. Improvements in education and healthcare standards will be only gradual, with progress crippled by narrow opportunities to raise spending in these areas.

Ecuador is one of the smallest markets included in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings, accounting for about 0.1% of global GDP and a similar share of global exports. Its oil and mineral reserves will continue to attract interest from foreign investors, although questions about policy reliability and doubts regarding the business environment, combined with tepid global commodity prices, will deter many private investors, with foreign state-owned companies securing a stronger position.
Market will expand modestly after coronavirus recession Boosted by a rising population but hindered by anaemic economic growth, Ecuador's market size will expand modestly in the 2020-24 forecast period. Although it has risen in recent years, GDP per head, estimated at US$6,206 in 2019, will fall sharply in 2020 and is forecast to only reach US$6,080 in 2024. This tepid growth in GDP per head will restrict business opportunities. Moreover, Ecuador's per-head income figures will continue to disguise wide inequalities. Despite a rise in consumption after the crisis in 2020, we expect reductions in income inequality to be marginal at best in 2020-24, as rates of unemployment-and in particular underemployment-will decrease only moderately in the wake of the crisis. Cutbacks in the rate of minimum-wage increases will also weigh on consumption.
The government of the former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), invested the proceeds of the oil price boom in upgrading the country's underdeveloped infrastructure. Substantial improvements were made, particularly to the road system, but significant gaps remain. The current administration, led by Lenín Moreno, has been more accommodative to private-sector investors, and we expect that a centrist government taking office in May 2021 will work to improve the legal framework to provide a moderate boost for investment (domestic and foreign), notably in the export-oriented energy and mining sectors, and related services. However, despite a strong natural resource endowment, growth in exports will remain below potential, and Ecuador's share of world exports will stagnate at about 0.1%.
As a result of dollarisation and successive years of guaranteeing a "living wage" (essentially a minimum wage), Ecuador is no longer a cheap-labour investment location. In US dollar terms, the country's minimum wage is one of the highest in Latin America. Also weighing on the country's competitiveness are low skills levels. However, dollarisation facilitates greater overall macroeconomic stability for businesses to assess investment opportunities, particularly by reducing inflation and exchange-rate risks. Investment in most areas outside the oil sector will be slow to arrive, as improvements to the business environment will be incremental, given political hurdles amid a highly fragmented political landscape. At the same time, advancements in the transparency and efficiency of the judicial system will be unhurried and slow to take effect.

Business opportunities limited by low level of development As the coronavirus pandemic produces a marked decline in disposable incomes, a shift in consumer attitudes towards cheaper brands and lower-cost, high-volume outlets is likely in the immediate term. Over the medium to long term, however, we expect a gradual rise in the proportion of income spent on food, beverages and tobacco, housing and household fuels, and transport and communications. This assumes that purchasing power picks up from a trough in 2020 amid improved labour market conditions. Ecuador's market will, however, remain comparatively small. We currently expect a centrist govern-ment to be elected in 2021, auguring the advancement of business-friendly policies. Nevertheless, progress will be incremental, as robust support will be absent in what is likely to be a fragmented legislature. Development will be slow, but dollarisation will provide price and exchange-rate stability.

Ample scope for catch-up but challenges persist Ecuador's wealth of natural resources, a young and expanding middle class and a push to improve educational standards offer scope to catch up with more developed countries over the next four decades. However, a series of challenges need to be addressed over the short and medium term to build on these positive conditions. Although the investment rate has improved considerably, it remains overly reliant on public-sector spending, which in turn is vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. Private investment is scant and overall savings are low, two factors that are only likely to improve moderately in the coming years, holding down productivity growth. Despite a more stable policy framework, Ecuador's institutions are likely to remain weak, and progress in tackling a large informal sector will be limited. Nevertheless, higher spending on health and education should help to improve labour productivity growth in 2031-50. In this context-and barring a sharp and prolonged deterioration in the country's terms of trade or a return to severe political instability-The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the economy to expand more robustly in 2031-50 (2.2%), after posting tepid GDP growth in the wake of the coronavirus crisis (averaging 0.7% in 2020-30).
Initial conditions: Rapid urbanisation in the past 30 years and faster integration into the world economy have produced few long-term benefits for the population. Political instability, weak institutions and high levels of poverty and inequality-combined with an economy overly dependent on oil-have yielded a rent-seeking and unproductive economy, plagued by low education levels and productivity, and high labour informality. The government of Rafael Correa (2007-17) made efforts to address low social indicators and improve infrastructure, but failed to boost private investment and savings. The Correa government also harmed the legal framework for investment by constantly changing regulations and putting up hurdles to capital. Although dollarisation has brought macroeconomic stability since 2000, it has also made Ecuador less competitive and has accentuated the risks of inadequate fiscal management.
Demographic trends: Population growth is set to fall gradually over the long term, from an average of 1.2% in 2020-30, to 0.8% in 2031-50. The main cause will be lower fertility rates, in addition to some net migration. On the upside, we project that the growth of the working-age population will continue to outstrip overall population growth until 2040, providing a major demographic boom and keeping the dependency ratio low. The main challenge facing the country will be to create enough formal jobs for entrants to the labour market, so as to reduce informality. There has been some progress in expanding education across all levels to improve labour quality, but the lack of dynamism in the private sector means that there is a substantial risk of labour informality remaining high in the long term. An additional challenge is to tackle the pension needs of an ageing population, which could increase strains on the country's vulnerable social security system.
External conditions: As a small, open economy, Ecuador has benefited from rising global trade. At the same time, it remains vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. This in turn causes significant external and fiscal volatility, as evidenced by the coronavirus crisis. The potential for stronger integration with industrialised nations or blocs like the US and EU (traditionally Ecuador's main trade partners) will remain constrained by long geographical distances and the lack of a consistent trade policy. Rising trade integration with neighbouring countries could boost growth, but progress will be slow, owing to sporadic trade spats, lack of supply chain strategies and infrastructure constraints. Export diversification towards the Middle East, Russia and Asia has seen some success, but Ecuador's small and distant market will drag its competitiveness profile, particularly in relation to other emerging markets in Asia. With the economy likely to remain heavily dependent on hydrocarbons and some mineral and agricultural products, the external sector and GDP growth will be highly dependent on the direction of terms of trade.
Future governments will struggle with a weak institutional framework Institutions and policy trends: Ecuador's institutions have long suffered from periods of instability, and despite a growing sense of macroeconomic and political stability in the past couple of years, they remain fundamentally weak. Inconsistent policymaking remains a major problem, both in conceiving and implementing new legislation. Successive administrations have changed policy directions. The current government, under Lenín Moreno, does not enjoy the wide support of workers in all state institutions or a clear majority of the population, tailwinds that future governments will also find elusive. Although power is concentrated in the hands of the executive, a highly fragmented political and social landscape will complicate governability. In the short term, this will be tangible as the current (and next) government endeavour to restore health to the public finances after a period of fiscal profligacy under the previous administration of Rafael Correa. Regardless of their ideological inclination, future governments will continue to struggle with a weak legal framework, corruption and distorted policy priorities (such as oil subsidies that have proven difficult to eliminate) that either favour special interest groups or act as a major drag on the public finances.
Dollarisation will be protected by its persistent popularity Dollarisation: The policy of dollarisation will be retained, as it garners wide support for delivering price and exchange-rate stability. Moreover, the costs of abandonment-in particular the fear of stoking social unrest-are very high. However, an abandonment of the system cannot be ruled out, especially as the coronavirus pandemic pushes Ecuador closer to a disorderly default and a balance-of-payments crisis. Notwithstanding risks, we expect commitment to an IMF-backed economic programme to strengthen the foundations of dollarisation. The government will endeavour to build up international reserves throughout the duration of its agreement with the Fund (ending in 2021). This is likely to occur alongside pragmatic adjustments to monetary policymaking that reinforce a dollarised regime and the central bank's independence. Recent legislation to bolster the country's medium-term fiscal framework and continued IMF support also augur a more sustainable fiscal trajectory that is congruent with a fully dollarised economy. We are cautiously optimistic that, although reform progress will be slow, the long-term sustainability of dollarisation will be reinforced and Ecuador's fiscal stance will be more stable.
Long-term performance: Unattractive investment conditions and the lack of a competitive, skilled labour force will make Ecuador a relatively unappealing destination for foreign investment in labour-intensive or manufacturing activities. However, sustained improvements in education levels, topped with productive investment in non-oil sectors and technology transfer, could make Ecuador more competitive and boost long-term growth. For this to occur, there the country would need to strengthen its institutional framework and improve its business environment. Although Mr Moreno's administration (and the next government) is likely to pursue policies that strengthen private-led growth, our forecast suggests that the advancement of structural reforms will be slow and insufficient for Ecuador to catch up, income-wise, with OECD countries in the long term.
