Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Prone to earthquakes, the country will continue to suffer from natural disaster risk, but its adaptation and readiness will improve following a particularly devastating earthquake in 2016. Climate change preparedness, however, is more lacking. Ecuador's geographical location and diversity renders it particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Owing to the near constant temperature year-round, a rising temperature has threatened the development of glaciers, which have not been able to replenish lost density during colder seasons. Indeed, Ecuador has experienced a significant reduction in the size of its glaciers in the two main mountain ranges-the Cordillera Oriental and the Cordillera Occidental-which in aggregate have seen a reduction of about a third over the past 50 years. By 2050 this trajectory will jeopardise the water sources for the country's major urban centres, such as the capital, Quito. Rising temperatures will also negatively affect agricultural production, as warmer winters cause crops to sprout prematurely and greater volatility in precipitation rates will also disrupt production.
Sustainability concerns will take centre stage in the medium to long term. Despite failing to reach the ambitious goal of generating 90% of electricity from renewable sources by 2017 (renewable energy currently accounts for about 65% of electricity generation, with hydroelectric power accounting for nearly all of this), hydroelectric and geothermal power primarily, and wind and solar power secondarily, will play an increasingly important role in the medium to long term. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the government will incrementally roll back its high fuel subsidies to make way for these renewable sources, which will offer increasing business opportunities. However, in the short term, the government will continue to promote oil and mining production-particularly in the Yasuní region-which may pose long-term threats to environmental stability.
Migration and urbanisation Urbanisation in Ecuador is a relatively recent phenomenon and comparatively low for Latin America. The majority of the population has traditionally lived in rural communities in the mountainous region (sierra). Since crossing the 50% threshold in 1990, the percentage of people living in cities has grown slowly, from about 62% in 2006 to 64% in 2018. The establishment of a middle class under a social spending and consumption-driven economic policy in the 2000s, particularly by the administration of Rafael Correa (2007-17), will sustain a large urban population. Meanwhile, security concerns in the north and environmental degradation in the sierra are likely to accelerate the pace of migration from rural areas to cities in the medium term. The country's infrastructure and natural resources will be strained in the process, necessitating greater investment. There will be opportunities for public-private partnerships for infrastructure investment, but internal migration will also invite limited bouts of social unrest.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IMF, IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import prices
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IMF, IFS; The Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Costa Rica to prices in the US
Population and growth: CELADE
General government debt: includes debt of the non-financial and financial public sectors
Lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on non-preferential loans. The rate is weighted by loan amounts
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IMF, IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI), 2006=100
Real exchange rate: The Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations CELADE: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - The election held in September 2017 produced a victory for the centre-right bloc. Parties in the ruling coalition since then have changed frequently, with the current government comprising the centre-right Conservatives and two centrist parties, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats, which entered government in January 2018 and January 2019, respectively. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further changes in the government until the next election in September 2021, as the outbreak of coronavirus has largely suspended normal political activity. With the initial phase of the outbreak largely contained, policy efforts will be focused on gradually re-opening the economy from its March-May lockdown and on mitigating the economic fallout of the crisis. A revival in transmission of the virus in the winter of 2020-21 is highly likely.

- The disruption caused by the coronavirus has yet to be reflected in business environment scores, but in current data, its regional ranking does improve slightly over the forecast period, and its position in regional and global rankings rises to 7th and 12th respectively. Solid economic fundamentals (high GDP per capita, low inflation) should weather the short-term disruption caused by the coronavirus. Norway's high political effectiveness has been proved in a robust response to the crisis, and the country's sound institutions will support recovery from 2021 onwards. Structural advantages, such as recent tax reforms and the country's holdings through its oil wealth, will remain. Nevertheless, high labour costs (a result of the oil sector's influence on the economy) and limited market size will ensure that Norway is outperformed by other Scandinavian economies, such as Denmark and Sweden.

- The coronavirus crisis will lead to a contraction of 5.5% in GDP in 2020. The domestic lockdown imposed from March-May, and its subsequent withdrawal, will curtail economic activity on the mainland. The fiscal support to the labour market will blunt the force of the contraction, but demand will be significantly damaged. The disruption to the mainland economy will be compounded by weakness in the offshore economy. The decline in oil prices in early 2020 will impede investment and weigh on export growth, reducing the current-account surplus in 2020-21. The economy will recover from the second half of 2020 onwards, but real GDP will not return to pre-crisis levels until 2023.

- The demographic outlook is expected to steadily worsen as migration from both eastern Europe and outside Europe wanes in the coming years. Slowing migration will accelerate the steady aging of the population. Nonetheless, net migration will remain positive, with migrants attracted by Norway's high wages and robust social safety net. Compared with other Scandinavian countries, Nor-way's demography is better suited to future growth, with the share of the working-age population higher than in peer countries. Still, the ageing population will put pressure on the pensions and healthcare systems, and the costs of both will steadily climb over the forecast period.

- Market opportunities are constrained by the small size of the population (5.4m in 2019). However, Norwegian households are the sixth-wealthiest in the world, with GDP per head of US$69,213 in 2019 measured in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms. Despite this high wealth, consumption growth will remain sluggish compared with neighbouring economies, as investment takes a greater lead in driving growth over the 2020-24 forecast period. Connection to nearby markets is limited, as it is few land borders with its trading partners, preventing it from taking a role as a business or commercial hub for the rest of Europe.

- High labour market participation means that future growth will depend on gains in productivity and investment, both of which will steadily accrue over the forecast period. Diminishing oil and gas reserves will force continued reform of the healthcare and pension systems, with the vast Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund) supporting the fiscal balance over this period. Further integration of technology and the steady improvement in the skills of the population will encourage long-term growth.

Background: The Labour Party governed almost continuously in 1935-65 and largely dominated politics until 2001, when a minority coalition comprising the Conservatives, the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals swept to power. In 2005 Labour returned to office in a centre-left coalition with the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party (Sp)-the first majority government for two decades. This coalition lasted until 2009. The September 2013 election led to a regime change, with a minority right-of-centre coalition of the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) taking office. The centre right was re-elected in 2017. The Conservatives and the FrP were joined by the Liberals in January 2018 and by the KrF in January 2019.
Political structure: A general election is held every four years and there is no right of dissolution between elections. Norway uses a modified proportional representation system where 150 out of the 169 members of the unicameral Storting (parliament) are "district mandates" elected by open-list proportional representation. The remaining 19 seats, the "levelling mandates", are distributed only between the parties that get more than 4% of the national vote and whose initial seat count (out of 150) is not proportional to their share of the vote.
Policy issues: The centre-right government will try to mitigate the fallout from the coronavirus crisis on the wider economy and public health. Efforts will also be focused on reducing the negative spillover effects of the lower oil price on wider economic activity and on strengthening the mainland economy. Spending from Norway's oil fund is expected to rise, and withdrawals will exceed the country's fiscal guidelines. Despite a cross-party agreement on tackling climate change, tensions will persist in the Storting over the balance between industrial development and environmental protection.
Taxation: At the start of 2016 most parties agreed on a multi-year corporation tax reduction (from 27% to 23% by 2018) to improve competitiveness in the economy. The government has further reduced this to 22% for 2019. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration of oil and gas. The capital-gains tax was cut from 28% to 27% in 2014. The ordinary rate of value-added tax is 25%. The top marginal income tax rate is 54.3% (including employers' social security contributions).
Foreign trade: Oil and gas output and prices greatly affect Norway's trade flows. The petroleum industry contributes about half of total goods export revenue. In 2016 the trade account registered its lowest level since 1999, but has been recovering since. The current-account surplus increased to US$16.1bn in 2019, down from US$31.1bn in the previous year. The trade and current-account balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period (2020-24).

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Norway is a multiparty parliamentary democracy, with minority governments, supported by one or more parties in opposition, the norm. The constitution, the second-oldest in the world after the US, provides for a single legislative chamber (Storting; the parliament) of 169 members, with elections every four years. Similar to other Nordic countries, there is a marked left-right divide amongst political parties, and the political system has consolidated into blocs of parties with similar views. Despite this divide, domestic politics is highly collaborative, and produces remarkably stable governments compared with other developed countries. This is in part because parliament does not have the right to call an early election, so spikes in political instability never result in a change of parliamentary arithmetic. Moreover, the Storting uses a committee system for passing legislation, with an emphasis on building cross-party consensus, and only the most contentious policies lead to a parliamentary vote. Extensive powers are also devolved to the 18 counties and 422 municipalities, although a recent "municipal reform" seeks to reduce their number. The centre-right bloc, consisting of four parties-the Conservatives, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-has led government since the 2017 election. Although the coalition fragmented in January 2020, losing its majority, the onset of coronavirus means we expect no government split before the next election, in September 2021.

Political outlook: Political stability The current ruling coalition, comprising the centre-right Conservatives and two small centrist parties-the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-is coming to the end of its term in September 2021. The coalition rules as a minority government, with just 61 members in the 169-seat parliament, after the far-right Progress Party (FrP) withdrew from government in January 2020. Owing to the short time until the next general election, the advent of the coronavirus and a consensual political culture, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a change in government until after the upcoming election.
Despite the government being a minority in parliament, it is able to pass legislation with the backing of the FrP (which has pledged to support it in significant parliamentary votes). The ruling coalition can also rely on the support of other opposition parties (such as the centre-left Labour Party). Although the FrP will probably withdraw its support for the government on most matters, the damage to political stability would be low, as the constitution prohibits a pre-term dissolution of parliament, and therefore a snap election.
In the near term the outbreak of the novel coronavirus has strengthened the stabilising influences on the political outlook. The government is in the process of steadily unwinding its restrictions on social interaction, after being among the first group of European countries to experience a substantial outbreak of the disease. Public support for the ruling parties has strengthened markedly during the crisis, and parliamentary support for the social-distancing legislation has been wide-ranging. Looking ahead, there is a risk that the economic hardship imposed by the lockdown will spur the growth of disruptive, populist move-ments as voters become disenchanted with traditional parties. However, we believe that this would only have a marginal impact on political stability, as the domestic political culture is highly consensus-driven, with frequent collaboration between the government and opposition parties on a range of issues.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Norway's multiparty structure and consensual style of politics tends to deliver well-designed legislation that meets government objectives. Elections are transparent, free and fair, conducted with universal suffrage, and transfers of power have always been accepted. Government institutions are largely free of corruption, with Transparency International, an anti-corruption watchdog, ranking Norway as the seventh-least corrupt country in the world, according to its 2019 Corruption Perceptions Index. These factors make the political system highly effective, characterised by high levels of public trust and political legitimacy.
We expect Norway to retain its high score for government effectiveness, and the country's apparatus to design and implement policy will remain one of its strengths. However, the consensus-driven nature of Norwegian politics curtails the extent of liberal, pro-business reform, and the overweening extent of bureaucracy can stifle government effectiveness.
There is a large amount of devolved power to regional authorities. As European integration has proceeded since 2007, the Storting has taken a more strident role in scrutinising European rules transposed into law as part of Norway's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA). In the context of the UK's exit from the EU, there is clamour in some sections of parliament for a more distant relationship with Europe, particularly within the FrP. However, despite the FrP's support for the ruling coalition within the Storting, we view a substantial revision of Norway's relationship with the EU, either for or against future integration, as unlikely.
Policymaking is centred in Norway's capital, Oslo, but implementation is largely left to regional authorities, which decentralises the government's functions. The system works well, with sub-national government comprised of municipalities and counties that have equal rights and responsibilities, regardless of their size. Functions are divided between these regional branches. Municipal government supervises junior education, health and social care, and town planning and infrastructure. County government oversees development and planning region-wide, including roads, public transport and adult education. The rising role of digital administration has contributed to a steady reduction in red tape across all aspects of government, and successive governments have attempted to make central and municipal administrations more efficient. Despite these efforts, the there remains some differences in digital capabilities amongst the various local governments, with more populous regions, such as Oslo, providing greater digital services than rural regions, such as Troms.
Streamlined regional government has been implemented as of January 2020 A substantial reform of local government was implemented on January 1st 2020 by the Conservatives-led government. Known as "municipal reform" (kommunesammenslaing), it merged Norway's 428 municipalities into 354 and reduced the country's 18 counties into 11, with the intention of reducing the cost and improving the quality of local government services by allowing local government to exploit economies of scale. The measure is similar to that implemented by Denmark in 2007, which was broadly effective in streamlining government administration. Political opposition to the reform remains high, especially in rural areas, and will likely persist until the system is well-established in the coming years. Opposition to the reform is led by the Centre Party, which has increased its popular support since the reforms were announced in 2017. The reforms destabilise some aspects of regional government (such as separating the administrative functions from the governor's office) in the near term, potentially jeopardising effectiveness, but we expect these repercussions to be gradually remedied in the years ahead.
Political outlook: Election watch The next general election will be held in September 2021. The Storting cannot be dissolved before completing a full four-year term, meaning that there is no risk of a snap election.
Although the handling of the coronavirus crisis is likely to shape political preferences in the run-up to the election, it is unclear how much of an effect it will have by September 2021. The governing parties have seen their popular support increase in the wake of the pandemic, a feature common to most countries, but we expect this support to steadily decrease later in the year as the economic fallout from the virus persists. We expect the Labour Party to emerge as the largest party after the election, as is usually the case, but the shape of the eventual government remains uncertain, as cross-party talks after the election largely decide which party will enter government.
Political outlook: International relations Diplomatically, Norway has been untouched by the souring of US-European relations since the election of Donald Trump as US president. Both the US's bilateral trade surplus with Norway and the country's position within NATO as an important member in the North Atlantic region aid relations.
Relations with the EU will remain one of the main foreign policy issues, particu-larly in the light of the UK's vote to leave the bloc. As a member of the European Economic Area, Norway has access to the single market (in exchange for contri-butions to the EU budget), but must accept relevant EU regulations while having limited influence over them. Nevertheless, the trading outlook remains uncertain as the effects of coronavirus dampen demand in Norway's major trading partners.

Norway's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises from 7.99 in the historical period (2015-19) to 8.28 in the forecast period (2020-24). This lifts the country two places in the global rankings, to 12th position, and one place to, seventh, among its 17 regional peers, although it remains behind Denmark, Sweden and Finland. This projected improvement in the rankings is based on a quarterly assessment made prior to the rapid spread of the coronavirus pandemic across Europe; since then, global business cond-itions and economic prospects have weakened considerably. This implies that some scores for the forecast period may be revised down in future, although we still expect Norway's to improve in the rating, owing to its resilient macro-economic fundamentals, stable and transparent regulatory environment, skilled workforce and the lagged impact of reforms, particularly in taxation.
The fallout from the coronavirus pandemic will deliver a significant negative shock to the global economy in 2020; Norway will experience its share of disruption. The length of the crisis and effectiveness of policy support measures will determine how different parts of the economy are affected, but it is likely to have medium-term implications for most parts of the business environment. In the near term planned reforms will be postponed amid a focus on crisis-response measures, particularly in labour markets.
Norway will remain one of the world's best locations for businesses Difficulties related to political turbulence, comparatively high labour costs, an elevated personal tax burden (albeit supporting high-quality public services and social welfare) and limited market opportunities will persist. Nevertheless, Nor-way will remain among the world's leading business locations, underpinned by a strong record of pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, a low regulatory burden and excellent transport, energy and digital infrastructure.

Business environment outlook: Norway's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Low regulatory burden, but probable rise in already high level of state influence in the economy, following emergency policy measures in response to the coronavirus pandemic and related temporary lockdown.
2022-24: A strategic plan guides the Norwegian Competition Authority to raise sectoral competition and procurement rules.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Generally positive attitude towards attracting foreign direct investment, but capital inflows constrained by weak global economy and new domestic investment screening regime that can block investment on national security grounds.
2022-24: The economy further diversifies investor countries beyond Europe, although to limited effect.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Absorbing the shock to global trade from the coronavirus will be a major theme, with a discussion around "reshoring" strategic industries away from China likely to follow the immediate crisis.
2022-24: No change in policy towards joining the EU or leaving the European Economic Area (EEA). A reassessment of EEA membership is possible, but unlikely. Efforts to promote bilateral trade deals continue.
Taxes 2020-21: Temporary stimulus measures and easing of tax-payment requirements for firms in response to coronavirus.
2022-24: Government investigates reform of subsidy regime for oil and gas exploration. Expansion of environmental taxes to meet climate change goals.
Financing 2020-21: Significant expansion of central bank liquidity to support functioning of financial markets. Policy interest rates remain at record-low level. Private-sector balance sheets weakened by economic fallout from the crisis.
2022-24: Credit demand likely to remain subdued following the crisis, but opportunities could emerge for growth of non-bank financing channels, including private equity and venture capital. Tighter anti-money-laundering rules.
The labour market 2020-21: The coronavirus shock leads to a substantial reversal in labour market performance.
2022-24: Improvements in employment and wages follow the crisis. Skills shortages remain an issue in some sectors.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Government applies 12-year transport plan (2018-29) and raises funds available for maintenance and construction of infrastructure projects. Gradual roll-out of fifth-generation (5G) mobile services.
2022-24: Investments in new road and rail transport links are made, with upgrades to transport infrastructure. Digital infrastructure upgrades continue.
Technological developments 2020-21: Implementation of Norway's cyber-defence strategy, after cyber-attacks on national infrastructure.
2022-24: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning AI preparedness..
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
9.2 9.2 1 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The coronavirus outbreak will generate a substantial contraction in GDP The Norwegian economy, like its peers, has been severely affected by the global coronavirus pandemic and the impact of temporary lockdown measures, with the country more exposed than most to the related slump in oil prices. A period of higher unemployment, greater business caution, lower oil-sector investment, weakened private-sector balance sheets and subdued global demand is expected in the near term. However, there was firm momentum in the economy prior to the shutdown, supported by competitiveness gains and a robust labour market, and solid macroeconomic fundamentals such as healthy public finances (backed by the Government Pension Fund Global, or GPFG, the vast sovereign wealth fund), a large external surplus, substantial corporate and household savings, low inflation, a resilient financial sector and strong institutional underpinnings. These imply that the Norwegian economy is better positioned than most of its regional peers to recover over the coming years, with limited permanent "scarring effects" from the crisis.
Structurally weaker aspects of the economy are elevated household indebtedness, a frothy housing market, ageing demographics and a still significant dependence on the oil sector (and thus exposure to sudden falls in global demand and the oil price). Against a global backdrop of rising protectionism and trade tensions, as well as shifting environmental perspectives, prospects for medium-term growth are likely to become more closely tied to economic diversification away from oil.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.3 8.3 13 13 6 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
State ownership of strategic assets is higher than other countries Norway offers a robust environment for private enterprise, with a low burden of regulation, strong property rights protection, an effective legal system and support for entrepreneurship. An established framework of competition law was revised in 2016 to harmonise merger control with EU law. The Norwegian Competition Authority (NCA) has proved reasonably effective in its policing of cartels and abuse of market dominance. However, opportunities for private enterprise are more limited than in most other regional economies, reflecting a still fairly high level of direct state ownership in Norway.

- There are about 70 companies under majority state control, including the country's largest oil group (Equinor), largest telecommunications provider (Telenor) and largest financial services institution (DNB). Since 2018 there have been modest divestments of state shareholdings in the air transport and agriculture sectors, where the government has seen no need for continued ownership, but on the whole there will continue to be a significant degree of state influence across the economy. Partly as a result of this, levels of regulation in services vary considerably by sector (although this is also common in many EU countries). According to the OECD, Norway compares favourably in terms of legal, accounting and rail freight transport services, whereas there are fairly high barriers to competition in the insurance, air transport, road freight and const-ruction sectors. Although scope for private enterprise in some product and services markets is restricted, the administrative burden for companies operating in Norway is generally low. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2020 report, the number of procedures and costs involved to establish a new business in Norway are less than the average for high-income OECD countries (as is also the case in Sweden, Finland and Denmark). Administrative processes involved with the payment of taxes, property registration, cross-border trading, contract enforcement and the process of insolvency also compare favourably with most advanced economies, with some room for improvement in accessing utilities and credit (mostly among small- and medium-sized enterprises, SMEs).

Emergency measures will lead to a large increase in state influence.
- The level of state influence in the economy will increase, at least in the near term, reflecting the emergency policy measures implemented in response to the pandemic. Most measures are designed to be temporary, supporting liquidity for companies and income protection for households, but other schemes-such as state-backed guarantees for the airline sector and state-funded loan support for the wider business sector-imply a longer-term affiliation, raising questions over how this increased level of state involvement will evolve.
- The centre-right government will remain open to the divestment of non-strategic state-owned assets, although market conditions in 2020-21 are unlikely to be that favourable and there are no specific privatisation plans. The state retains significant holdings in major sectors, including Equinor (formerly Statoil, 67%), Telenor (54%); DNB (34%); Yara (36.2%), a fertiliser manufacturer; and Norsk Hydro (34.3%), an aluminium producer. Statkraft, a renewable-energy company, and Statskog, a forestry and land-management company, remain fully public.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.7 8.7 10 11 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
There is a slight improvement in Norway's regional ranking for policies toward foreign investment, mostly driven by a protectionist turn among other European economies. Given its small economy, Norway has long adopted a co-operative stance towards foreign investors, abiding by its obligations as an EEA member and broadly welcoming foreign capital and expertise. Mirroring global trends, political and public resistance to foreign influence is on the rise, but restrictions on foreign ownership are fairly limited, applying mainly to strategic industries (including parts of fisheries, maritime and transport) and some natural resources. The gradual long-term depletion of offshore hydrocarbon reserves and recent oil-price slumps have given some impetus to efforts to attract FDI as a means of diversifying the economy and complementing the offshore energy sector with new sources of wealth. Focus areas for Invest in Norway, the official investment promotion agency, include renewable energy, "cleantech", biotechnology and a growing professional services sector, especially ICT. There have been pockets of progress, but on the whole diversification efforts have not been as fruitful as the government had hoped, with the hydrocarbon sector still among the most appealing for foreign investors. Norway does not offer significant tax benefits to investors (domestic or foreign), but selective start-up grants and R&D support are available, with additional incentives for projects in less populated areas of the country.
National security will play a larger role in foreign investment decisions
- Most FDI inflows to Norway originate from EU countries, with Sweden and the Netherlands the two biggest investors. An increased emphasis in recent years on attracting FDI from the US, China and other parts of Asia is expected to continue over the forecast period, although prospective inflows will face greater scrutiny than before following the government's adoption of a new investment screening regime in 2019. This gives the authorities power to investigate and block foreign acquisitions (from EU and non-EU investors) on the grounds of national security, national financial stability and autonomy. This is similar to a new FDI screening framework in the EU, where there has been a steady pushback in recent years against non-EU inflows, mainly from China, amid gears over the transfer of intellectual property and the involvement of state-owned actors in strategic infrastructure assets. Broadly, the changes reflect a general trend in many countries of rising political interference in business acquisitions.

Privatisation programmes will steadily increase over the forecast
- Privatisation of certain railway routes will continue over the forecast period. In 2018 a British transport provider, Go-Ahead, won the first competitive tender for Norway's rail operations, covering the Sorlandet line to Stavanger and Arendal line services for a ten-year period. In mid-2019 a Swedish operator, SJ, won the rights to an additional seven routes. We expect a gradual widening of public-private collaboration in Norwegian infrastructure, including rail infrastructure, in accordance with the 12-year transport plan (2018-29).
- Support for foreign investment on the Norwegian continental shelf is likely to remain generous, especially in light of the coronavirus-related slump in oil prices and likely postponement of some oil-investment projects. Foreign and domestic investors receive equal treatment in the awarding of new blocks for exploration and production of oil and gas, based on annual licensing rounds that cover more mature parts of the shelf (awards in predefined areas, APAs) and licensing rounds held every two years in more risky frontier areas. Regarding the latter, in June 2018 the government offered 12 new production licences to 11 companies in the 24th licensing round, with nine of the licences focused on the Barents Sea and three in the Norwegian Sea. The number of applicant companies fell to 11, from 26 in the previous round in 2016. A coalition agreement that enforces a ban on exploring for oil off the Lofoten, Senja and Vesteralen islands will continue to be upheld through the parliament's term to 2021.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
9.1 9.1 13 17 8 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Energy exports comprise the bulk of Norway's trade in Europe As Norway is a net energy exporter, with a small domestic market and limited manufacturing capacity, governments of all persuasions have adopted broadly pro-free-trade policies, despite a long-standing reluctance to join the EU and the protectionism afforded to home-produced agriculture. The deterioration in the regional and global rankings reflects not only the progress made in some other countries and the lack of improvement in Norway's trade openness owing its remote location and undiversified export base, but also the steady worsening in global trading conditions amid increased protectionism and weaker demand. Trade openness notwithstanding, Norway's institutions are largely welcoming to trade. Except in extremis, investors in Norway are guaranteed the absence of foreign-exchange controls, with an independent central bank overseeing a free-floating krone. Profits and dividends earned in all economic sectors, including oil and gas, may be repatriated, with no restrictions on capital flows. Through Norway's membership of the EEA, Norwegian and foreign-owned companies in Norway gain full access to the single market, which accounts for around 60% of all Norwegian exports. EU access guarantees the free movement of persons, goods, services and capital between Norway and member states. Norway adopts around three-quarters of all single-market legislation, with notable exceptions being laws that govern agriculture and fisheries (the fisheries industry is among the biggest in Europe). Trading outside the EU is promoted mainly through the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA) by negotiating free-trade agreements (FTAs). As of June 2020 there were 29 FTAs covering 41 countries, with talks ongoing over future deals with India, Malaysia and Thailand, among others. After a six-year hiatus, in 2016 Norway resumed negotiations with China over a bilateral FTA. Norway followed the EU's lead in placing sanctions on Russia since 2014, resul-ting in a Russian ban on EU (and Norwegian) food imports.

- Norway's position on the fringe of European institutions is unlikely to change. It is not a member of the EU and will not consider joining over the forecast period, as an increasing number of parties oppose membership. There have been calls by the far-right FrP to renegotiate the terms of Norway's EEA membership, but centrist parties within the ruling coalition and the example of Brexit make the prospect of wider renegotiation unlikely.

Bilateral trade agreements will remain the priority for both Norway and the EU
- We expect a more volatile and strained global trading environment over the forecast period. The fallout from the coronavirus pandemic will not only impart a severe negative shock to the world economy and trade flows in 2020, but is also likely to exacerbate many existing geopolitical trends, such as growing US-China tensions, the rise in nationalist anti-globalist policies and the shift in the economic balance of power from West to East. This implies a risk of a rise in EU-US trade tensions and a more challenging backdrop in which to manage EU-China relations, as well as expected disruption to trade from a "hard" Brexit.
- Amid a fraying multilateral trade system, the focus of the EU and Norway will be on bilateral deals. In recent years the EU has finalised FTAs with Canada, Singapore, Vietnam and Japan, upgraded its deal with Mexico and launched trade talks with Australia and New Zealand. A provisional agreement was reached in mid-2019 between the EU and Mercosur (the South American trading bloc) to create the world's largest free-trade market of almost 800m people, after 20 years of talks. However, amid concerns in some member states over aspects of the deal (mostly on agriculture and climate), there are doubts as to whether the agreement will be finalised and implemented from 2021, as first intended. Prior to the pandemic, progress in Norway-China FTA negotiations had raised the prospect of a deal by end-2020, but this is now less certain.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.0 7.4 45 20 13 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Tax reforms have made Norway more competitive in recent years The tax regime has tradionally been among the weaker areas of the business environment, but reforms over recent years have improved the country's relative standing at a global and regional level. The focus has been on developing a more competitive tax system and shifting part of the overall burden from direct to less distortionary indirect taxation, via reductions to personal and corporate income tax rates, introduction of a new financial activities tax (in 2017) and a sugar tax (in 2018) and changes in excise duties. In 2018 Norway had a tax-to-GDP ratio of 39%, down from an average of around 42% in 2000-15 and the ninth highest in the OECD.

- The share of total tax receipts from personal and corporate income taxes and social security contributions remains moderately higher than the OECD average, whereas the proportion of revenue from taxes on property and non-VAT indirect taxes is below average. Between 2014 and 2019 the headline corporate income tax rate was lowered from 27% to the current 22%, which is close to the effective tax rates among Norway's regional peers and broadly on a par with the OECD. Further corporate income tax rates are levied on offshore petroleum companies (56% in 2020) and on hydropower production (37%). These headline rates have risen moderately in recent years, but effective tax rates have remained largely unchanged, as the tax rate of investment-based depreciation, the "rate of uplift", has been gradually lowered. The income tax system for individuals was reformed in 2016, with a progressive four-tier framework replacing a surtax that was levied only on the highest earners. This has been accompanied in recent years by a reduction in the flat tax rate levied on all net income, from 27% to the current 22%, an increase in the personal allowance and a tightening of various exemptions. As at January 2020 the four income tax rates ranged from 1.9% above personal income of Nkr180,000 (US$18,650) to 16.2% on income above Nkr999,550. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 25%, but reduced rates of 15%, 12% and 0% apply to a wide range of goods and services.
- The centre-right minority government had targeted further modest downward pressure on the tax burden in 2020-21, but reform plans are now highly uncertain amid the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. As part of its policy response to the crisis, the government temporarily deferred some corporate tax payments, offered tax relief to the airline sector and reduced the "lower" VAT rate from 12% to 8% until October 2020.

Further tax cuts could form part of any fiscal stimulus later this year
- Additional tax-cutting stimulus is possible in the near term to support the hardest-hit sectors and prompt a broader recovery in demand. The scale and timing of such measures will be influenced by the future path of the virus and also global oil prices. Norway is less dependent on the hydrocarbons sector than a decade ago, but this remains an important driver of tax revenue and activity in the mainland economy. Tax incentives for the sector could be introduced, aimed at mitigating an anticipated decline in oil investment. Norway has more fiscal space than most countries, but the crisis could lead to policymakers seeking new sources of tax revenue over the coming years. This could include a withholding tax on interest and royalty payments, a broadening of the VAT base or a tightening of generous housing tax incentives.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.5 9.3 3 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Financial stability is guaranteed by well-supervised and funded banks Financing conditions for business are favourable, with Norway ranked highest on a regional basis and sharing the top spot with two other countries at a global level. This reflects the underlying resilience of its banking sector, comparatively modest risk exposure, access to a range of financing channels and recent improvements to the regulatory framework. Prior to the Covid-19 pandemic, annual stress tests showed the banking sector to be more profitable than most regional peers, with strong capital and liquidity buffers (an average common equity Tier 1 ratio of near 16% in mid-2019 was comfortably above minimum capital requirements under Basel III) and a low level of credit losses. Risks to financial stability mainly stem from banks' exposure to the oil and gas sector, overvalued domestic housing and commercial real estate markets and elevated levels of household debt.

- Banks also remain fairly reliant on wholesale funding and the tightly integrated nature of the Nordic-Baltic banking system implies a moderate spillover risk. In recent years macroprudential measures aimed at strengthening capital buffers and tightening rules on consumer credit and higher-risk mortgage lending (particularly in the largest cities, such as Oslo) have been introduced, which have contributed to slower growth in bank lending and house prices. Since late 2018 revelations of a major money-laundering scandal involving some of the largest Nordic-Baltic banking groups have prompted a tightening of anti-money laundering and terrorism financing legislation across the region. Foreign companies have access to the same capital sources as domestic companies, but often work through foreign banks, which tend to have offices in Oslo, the capital, and in cities where the oil industry is based, especially Bergen and Stavanger. Access to investment finance is adequate, as tighter rules were established in the wake of the global financial crisis. Companies are able to obtain bank funding (subject to risk limits) and can also access the equity or bond markets, which-owing to the government's strong fiscal position-are more stable than in many other countries. Foreign-exchange access will remain unhindered as authorities maintain a free-float currency with no capital controls.
- Norewegian banks are well positioned to absorb a rise in credit losses and a hit to profitability, but the resilience of the finanical sector will be tested by the fallout from the pandemic. A sharp hit to the mainland economy, a jump in non-performing loans amid higher unemployment and business failures, a drag from low global oil prices and reduced oil- ector investment, a hit to bank profitability from lower official interest rates and a period of increased financial market volatility will weigh on lenders' balance sheets, exposing areas of weakness and reducing willingness to provide credit.

Monetary support have been substantially increased since February
- In response to the crisis, Norges Bank reduced its official policy interest rate from 1.5% to a record low 0% (it stated that it does not envisage a negative policy rate) and implemented initiatives to boost liquidity, including temporarily unrestricted access to short-term loans, additional foreign-currency swap auctions and a cut in banks' countercyclical capital buffer from 2.5% to 1% (in effect releasing new liquidity from banks' capital reserves). The government also launched loan-guarantees amounting to Nkr100bn: a scheme specifically aimed at new bank loans to SMEs and a reintroduced Government Bond Fund.
- In the near term there will a marked slowdown in overall loan demand, with bank financing of existing SMEs and new start-ups declining. Over the forecast period we expect an increase in take-up of non-bank funding alternatives, including debt and equity markets, venture capital and securitisation.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.6 6.4 26 35 10 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
High standards of tertiary education and vocational training have helped to develop a highly skilled labour force in managerial expertise and language skills. Central-level bargaining between government, the Confederation of Norwegian Enterprise and the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions involves a high degree of co-ordination, with blue-collar manufacturing wages providing the bench-mark for sector-specific and company-level bargaining. The more restrictive elements of this system, such as a large public sector and some scarcity of skills in the private sector, had become more evident prior to the coronavirus pandemic. Following a jump in unemployment as a result of the crisis, the focus in the near term will be on responding to a weaker jobs market (with significant disruption in certain sectors such as retail, hospitality and tourism) through active labour market policies such as subsidised jobs, training and job-search support.

- A relative lack of labour mobility will restrict opportunities for development in remote regions, and relatively low skill levels among imm-igrants and asylum-seekers settling in Norway will hamper integration into the workforce. Political pressure to restrict migration will also remain high, stifling any surge in labour supply later in the forecast period as the economy strengthens. High aspirations for wages and entitlements contribute to workforce welfare, but also add to business operating costs. Strike action is a familiar feature of the wage-bargaining process in the public sector and among offshore petroleum industry workers seeking higher rates and benefits, which contributes to the lower score on this category. However, the government reserves the right to enforce arbitration in disputes that are likely to have a major impact on the economy or be detrimental to public health. Although occasional industrial action has taken place in recent years, we expect future action to be largely avoided through arbitration.

Recent stimulus measures have been focussed on the labour market
- The government introduced various temporary measures in response to the pandemic aimed at mitigating the rise in permanent unemployment. Companies were able to temporarily furlough employees, with the state covering a proportion of related wage costs. A similar income-protection scheme was also available for self-employed workers, alongside rapid (and expanded) access to sickness and unemployment benefits. The level of registered unemployment surged from 2.2% in February 2020 to almost 11% in March, but had fallen back to 6.4% at end-May. Further declines will be more gradual, with unemployment in Norway unlikely to return to pre-crisis levels until 2023.
- Against a backdrop of stricter immigration controls and divergent sectoral trends, concerns over skills shortages have been a feature of certain pockets of the labour market for some time. Although at an aggregate level such concerns will ease as a result of the pandemic, amid a period of weaker overall activity and higher joblessness, the fallout from the downturn and the inequitable damage to some sectors risks contributing to a further mismatch of demand and supply, including in healthcare, engineering, construction and ICT.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.5 8.5 6 6 6 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway has well developed physical transport networks and high-quality digital infrastructure, with few of the problems, such as traffic congestion, that affect countries with higher population densities. Gradual improvements to road and rail networks are scheduled over the forecast period, based on a new ten-year national transport plan published in 2018, but overall we expect Norway's fairly high score and rankings for this category to remain largely unchanged. Good ferry and internal air transport services, including oil-rig helicopter links, help to mitigate the logistical challenges posed by Norway's diverse topography and weather-related vulnerabilities. Rock fall, flooding and landslide risks, alongside the ongoing requirement to increase the connectivity of cities and regions, place constant demands on the public purse to maintain roads, bridges and tunnels, and rail, air and maritime transport systems, as well as public transport links. However, the unpopularity of road tolls, which are an important source of funding for Norwegian infrastructure, are becoming a more salient political issue. Norway's digital infrastructure is among the most highly advanced in the world. In recent years many rapidly growing start-ups have emerged, and almost all services available digitally. Telecommunications coverage and quality is high, with providers reasonably quick to roll out imp-rovements to the high-speed broadband network.
A National Transport Plan, published in 2018, directs infrastructure spending
- Infrastructure policy will be guided by the National Transport Plan for 2018-29, which focuses on the maintenance and upgrading of transport infrastructure, pollution reduction, and stronger public-private co-operation, as well as increased use of intelligent transport systems and digitisation. The plan's baseline scenario allocates 58% of a total budget of Nkr418m (US$46m) for road improvements; 32% for railways (which includes new double-track lines for intercity routes, Oslo-Skien and Halden-Lillehammer, and a second light-rail line in Bergen, to Fyllingsdalen, a borough in the south of the city); and another 3% to sea infrastructure to benefit the fishing and shipping industries.
- Telenor launched Norway's first commercial 5G mobile services in March 2020, with its main competitor, Telia, switching on its 5G network in May. Availability of services will initially be limited, but the two main operators are targeting about 50% population coverage by 2021 and nationwide coverage by 2023, supported by allocation of increased spectrum by the National Communications Authority (Nkom). In May 2020 parliament approved a new Broadband Development Act, which aims to facilitate the development of ultrafast broadband networks and 5G rollout by encouraging co-operation in infrastructure construction and promoting joint utilisation of existing networks.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
7.8 8.6 23 18 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway performs reasonably well on the technological readiness ranking and we expect gradual improvements over the forecast period, raising its global and regional standing. Stronger aspects are the quality of its digital infrastructure; high adoption rates of e-commerce and e-business technology; good penetration of e-government services; widespread internet usage; and above-average digital skill levels. There is more room for improvement in cyber-security preparedness, research and development (R&D) spending and the quality of the country's research infrastructure, although these are still satis-factory on a regional basis. Total investment in R&D corresponds to just over 2% of GDP-slightly below an OECD average of 2.4% and well below levels of 3.1% in Denmark and 3.2% in Sweden. Norway ranks in the second-highest group as a "strong innovator" in the European Innovation Scoreboard, scoring particularly well for its innovation-friendly environment, strong public-private linkages and lifelong learning (aided by Norway's flexible education system). Weaker aspects include a below-average impact from sales and exports of knowledge-intensive products, implying scope for improvement in translating the country's strong innovative capacity into increased entrepreneurial activity.
A cyber-attack on an energy supplier led to a national plan for cyber-security
- In May 2019, in response to the increasing prevalence of cyber-security attacks (exemplified by an attack on Norsk Hydro, a state-backed energy supplier, in March 2019), the government unveiled a national cyber-security strategy. This strategy places further emphasis on public-private collaboration across both civilian and military branches of government, with the aim of safeguarding national infrastructure against cyber-security threats.
- Public-private partnership will be an increasing theme in technology research initiatives, in line with many other developed economies. In August 2018 some of Norway's biggest companies announced that they would jointly establish a national powerhouse for artificial intelligence (AI) to improve the country's quality and capacity for research, education and innovation in the field. The government has actively supported these partnerships, as it encour-ages the matching of technical skills to business need, reducing the extent of skills mismatches and raising productivity. However, their effect on innovation and the extent of spillovers to other industries is yet to be established.

Economic forecast: Policy trends Having passed the first stages of the pandemic ahead of neighbouring countries, the government's chief policy objective is to steadily unwind the controls imposed from March 12th onwards. Government policy has been more stringent than in neighbouring Sweden, with enforced closures of schools, businesses and public events, alongside restrictions on population movement (specifically from urban to rural areas).
Controls on cross-border movement were also implemented, with closures imposed on the land borders to neighbouring Russia and Finland. These actions have been largely successful in arresting the spread of the virus, and the number of new cases has remained extremely low since May 24th. The government is implementing a steady withdrawal of social-distancing controls from April 20th, schools have been fully re-opened since May 11th, with bars and restaurants allowed to re-open on June 1st, provided they enforce dist-ancing measures among consumers. However, the trajectory of future policy remains uncertain and is likely to depend on the stresses in the public health system (especially in rural areas) and on the spread of the virus nationally.
Although most of the economy will be free of lockdown restrictions, significant controls on the population (including border closures and restrictions on the number of people allowed to enter bars and restaurants) will probably remain in place until July at the earliest. A revival in infections as controls are lifted remains a substantial risk to the forecast and would certainly slow the normalisation of activity, perhaps leading to a re-imposition of controls later this year. However, improvements in the capacity of the healthcare system and in the government's ability to trace and quarantine the infected (through the use of voluntary applications) will curtail the spread in the virus compared with its early stages.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

General government budget balance 6.4 -0.9 1.5 3.0 3.5 3.6
General government debt 40.3 52.7 55.3 55.7 56.3 57.2
Like other European countries, Norway has announced fiscal stimulus in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, although this is much smaller than in peer economies. Total new measures have amounted to about Nkr160bn (US$13.7bn), or about 5.5% of mainland GDP. The budget that the government presented in October 2019 has been abandoned as the disruption from the coronavirus generates a dual shock to both the mainland and oil sectors. The government's new budget, presented on May 13th, targets a substantial with-drawal from the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG; 4.2% of its value) to fund further expenditure. This will be sufficient to pull the fiscal balance into deficit in 2020, for the first time since 1993, but Norway's history of fiscal rectitude and the presence of the GPFG, Norway's vast sovereign wealth fund, will keep the deficit modest, at just 0.9% of GDP in 2020.
Existing government support for the labour market is similar to the measures implemented in response to the coronavirus in neighbouring countries. Under the system of " permittering", the government temporarily pays a large portion (more than 60%) of the wages of workers who are placed on furlough. Expanded take-up of this scheme, although it will preserve much of the existing labour market for the duration of the pandemic, will leave the government liable for a significant increase in spending.
On the employer side, fiscal support has expanded rapidly. The government has deferred tax payments and purchased corporate bonds on the secondary market, reducing borrowing costs for businesses. About Nkr20bn has been set aside as a crisis fund to cover fixed costs for businesses during the coronavirus pandemic, modelled on the Danish fund set up for this purpose. Norway has also established a fund to subsidise healthcare provision in developing countries affected by the coronavirus.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)

10-year government bond yield (av) 1.5 1.0 1.2 1.3 1.5 1.7
In response to the substantial disruption caused by the pandemic, Norges Bank (the central bank) has lowered the policy rate by 150 basis points since February, to 0%-the lowest rate in modern history. This unprecedented mone-tary easing was completed over three meetings of the monetary policy committee. The first meeting, on March 13th, lowered the policy rate from 1.5% to 1%. The second, on March 20th, lowered it to 0.25%. In May the rate fell further, to 0%. The central bank also lowered countercyclical capital buffers for major banks from 2.5% to 1% to ensure bank solvency and expand credit growth.
As the economic fallout from the virus becomes more profound, we expect Norges Bank to maintain its highly accommodative policy until the end of 2021. There are likely to be substantial scarring effects on both output and employment from the virus, and the looser monetary policy will be required to accelerate the recovery in the near term. The possible recurrence of the virus in the winter will make the central bank less inclined to normalise rates.
Looking ahead, Norges Bank targets inflation of "close to 2% over time", and the policy rate should rise steadily as the economy recovers. Nevertheless, its mandate is flexible to ensure stable output and employment, and to avoid the build-up of financial imbalances. The steady rise in the oil price, the gradual recovery of the domestic economy and the revival in global trade should all generate a steady normalisation of interest rates over the forecast period.
