Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts are built on a series of epidemiological assumptions on the novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Without rapid access to a vaccine, we expect that the disease will eventually infect up to 30% of the world's population. We assume that about 15% of symptomatic cases will be severe and that up to 1% of symptomatic cases will prove fatal.. Death ratios will depend on a country's ability to detect, track and contain the virus, and the capacity of the national health system. Governments are lifting restrictions on freedom of movement gradually in countries where the number of cases is falling and where there is sufficient spare capacity in the healthcare system. Some countries may be forced to re-impose measures if cases spike again. Based on previous viral outbreaks and the progress made on other coronavirus vaccines (such as that for severe acute respiratory syndrome-SARS), we expect a vaccine to be available by end-2021.
In economic terms, we forecast that global output will contract by 4.2% year on year in 2020 and that global trade will decline by 24.8%. Global GDP will not recover to pre-coronavirus levels before at least 2022; 2020 and 2021 will be lost years for growth. Real GDP will contract in all regions of the world, but the drop in output will be especially severe in OECD countries. All G7 countries and almost all G20 countries will experience a full-year recession in 2020. We expect China's real GDP growth to slow sharply to 1% this year, and forecast a full-year recession in the US, with a contraction of 4%. We assume that oil prices will decline by more than 40% this year, to average US$38/barrel. Most countries have responded with huge fiscal expansion to support businesses and households, raising the risk of sovereign debt crises in the medium term. Central banks have cut interest rates and, more importantly, have stepped up as buyers of last resort for government and corporate debt.
Europe is heading towards a historic recession this year. Most governments started to relax some of the rules governing social and economic behaviour in May, but economic activity will remain greatly impeded. We assume that the worst of the economic damage will occur in the second quarter of 2020, when most economies have been subject to the strictest containment measures. The euro zone will register a full-year recession in 2020, with a forecast contraction in GDP of 8%, as output in all of the bloc's economies will contract. Supply-side effects include disrupted global supply chains, a sharp fall in working hours and a spike in business failures. Demand-side effects are likely to be longer lasting. Even once lockdowns are eased, people are likely to avoid public spaces for fear of contagion and to hold off on travel plans. Households will limit their consumption in response to a loss of income, and businesses will delay investment. We expect a bounce-back in the third quarter, after the outbreak has peaked, but confidence will remain subdued.
The political and geopolitical impact of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, with limited parliamentary oversight. Elections have been cancelled in some countries. When the pandemic has passed, governments will face intense scrutiny on their response. Failure to address the humanitarian crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. A severe global economic crisis, followed by large-scale unemployment, could fuel a new wave of popular protests. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. It will also intensify the competition for global leadership between China and the US, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other regions.

Despite the shift in policy towards a steady easing of lockdown restrictions, the gradual pace of withdrawal throughout the second quarter of 2020 will guarantee a contraction in both the first and second quarters of the year. Subsequently, we believe that the economy will rebound only in the latter half of 2020 as control measures subside and economic activity improves, bringing full-year output down by 5.5% from 2019. There remains a high risk that the rate of viral infection will increase as the social-distancing measures are withdrawn, prompting a re-imposition of controls later in the year. We judge that long-term scarring from the crisis will be significant, but modest compared with peer economies, as government support for short-term disruption to the labour market will remain substantial.
The coronavirus pandemic and the subsequent lockdown will primarily impact consumer spending and export demand in Norway, which we expect to decline by 6.9% and 11.8% respectively. On the consumption side, the imposition of social-distancing measures damages consumer spending both directly, through the prevention of consumer activities such as services spending, and indirectly, through a decline in total employment and consumer spending power. On the external side, similar lockdowns among major trading partners (namely the UK and Germany) will weigh on demand for major exports, such as energy goods and shipping.
Although Norway is sheltered from the worst effects of the economic shutdown owing to its fairly small tourism industry (at just 4% of GDP), its large export sector and debt-laden household balance sheets make it vulnerable to a prolonged lull in economic activity. Government intervention, primarily through state-sponsored loans and support for the labour market, will lessen the extent of the economic fallout, but will not prevent substantial contractions early in 2020.
Investment in both the oil and non-oil sectors will also weaken, as uncertainty around a possible recurrence of the virus (at least until a vaccine is produced) will chill investor appetite for risk and cuts in oil sector production will weigh on the returns of offshore projects. Growth will recover more substantially from 2021 onwards as economic life returns to normal and the risk of a re-imposition of controls steadily abates. However, the prospect of lasting damage to household balance sheets (with household debt at 110% of GDP in December 2019), business confidence and oil investment will keep real GDP below pre-crisis levels until 2022.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Norway's sectoral balance has changed only modestly since the exploitation of the country's oil reserves in the 1970s, which placed the oil and gas industry in a prime position in the Norwegian economy, composing about a fifth of GDP in 2018. As in most developed economies, the services sector is the mainstay of Norway's output, contributing about 65% to the country's GDP in 2019. This share is below Norway's peer economies in Scandinavia: Finland and Denmark's share of services output is 69.7% and 74.4% respectively. The size of other sectors in the economy, (outside of oil) is fairly small, at just 2.2% for agriculture; and 5.9% for manufacturing.
Services command less of a share of output than in other Nordic countries The oil and gas sector has been the main driver of economic development since Norwegian oil was first exploited in the 1970s. Early phases of oil exploration took place in the North Sea (on the country's west coast) but later efforts have concentrated on the Barents Sea (to the north). Historically, the influence of the oil sector has been in steady decline, and the size of the oil sector has fallen from a peak of 25% of GDP in 2012 to 15% in 2019, owing to falling oil prices and disrupted production on major oil platforms. The corona-virus outbreak will keep oil prices low over the forcast period, but the re-activation of important oil platforms after maintenance operations and the development of new platforms will boost oil production over in the next five years. By year-end 2019, 88 fields were producing-slightly more than in 2018 (when there were 83). This includes Johan Sverdrup, the fifth-largest oil discovery ever made in Norwegian waters, which will account for 30% of all Norwegian oil production by the mid-2020s, according to the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate (NPD), a government agency. These factors will encourage continued growth in oil production, to a peak in 2023, albeit not to the same scale as the early peak in the mid-2000s. Despite the revival in offshore activity in the near term, various factors will curtail growth in the oil sector in the coming years. The collapse in oil prices, caused by the coronavirus outbreak, will curtail the appetite for new oil sector projects. Oil firms will also face the rising costs of de-commissioning aging oil platforms, weighing on the sector's profitability. Diversification of global energy demand away from oil and gas will also erode prices and curtail new investment.
Support for the oil sector is also becoming less politically desirable for various reasons. Firstly, the damaging effects of the sharp decline in the oil prices since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic has emphasised the need for economic diversification away from oil. Secondly, strengthening environmental concerns will further influence government policy. Since the withdrawal of the pro-oil Progress Party from government in 2020, the environmentalist Liberals have greater influence over government policy, and could use legislation to constrain the growth of the oil sector over time. Thirdly, the generous tax system for oil exploration, which refunds 78% of oil exploration costs, has come under mounting pressure within the usually pro-oil Labour Party. These growing pressures will constrain the oil sector's influence on the economy beyond 2023.
Since the exploitation of oil, Norway's manufacturing sector has receded in economic importance, from 17.7% in 1970, according to the World Bank, to 5.9% in 2019. This decline has been more pronounced than that of Norway's peer economies. Denmark, Sweden and Finland all have manufacturing sectors that comprise more than 12% of GDP. Manufacturing is split between an oil-oriented component, dominated by machinery, chemicals and ship-building, and a consumer-oriented component, based on production of food and beverages. The sector is highly capital intensive so the effects of the coronavirus will be muted compared to other sectors in the economy (particularly the services sector),as it is able to increase production with social-distancing measures in place. Manufacturing may receive further support as part of government plans to diversify the economy further in the years ahead. Nevertheless, the perpetually strong krone, making exports expensive, will curtail the extent of this wider recovery in the manufacturing industry.
The services sector will bear the brunt of the damage caused by coronavirus The services sector, although small compared to peer economies, is the largest in terms of both activity and employment, making up roughly 79% of the labour force. As in other advanced economies, public administration (health and education for example) accounts for the largest share of total employment, at about 35% in 2019, but other services industries, such as real estate, retail and transportation also play a sizeable role. Much of the sector services the internal market, but there are numerous service industries that have developed a significant advantage compared to their European and global competitors. Given Norway's geographical location and the influence of the oil industry, these tend to be firms specialising in logistics or research and development.
Partnership with the oil sector has also enabled transport and maritime services, alongside other professional or technical services (such as engineering, chemicals and research), to develop outside the oil sector, and Norwegian firms such as Aker ASA and Yara International can compete globally. The outbreak of the virus, and the resulting lockdown, will deal substantial damage to the services sector for an extended period. Activity in contact-intensive services such as retail or tourism is likely to be severely curtailed in the first half of 2020, but as their overall size is small compared with neighbouring economies, the total scale of the fallout will be reduced. Activity in less contact-intensive services, such as shipping, is likely to rebound alongside movements in global trade and oil demand.

The price effects from the coronavirus lockdown have proved mixed so far, with the collapse in energy prices and in demand for luxury goods being balanced by a rise in household stockpiling of essential goods (particularly in food and other consumable items). The conflicting effects of the crisis have been borne out in the inflation statistics. Headline inflation fell from 1.8% in January to 0.7% in March, whereas core inflation (excluding energy) has remained elevated at more than 2% throughout this period.
Looking ahead, we expect that the disruptive effects of the coronavirus will drag down inflation in 2020, to an average of 0.2%. This downward trend will be supported by an easing in household stockpiling as controls on social distancing abate, and as the fall in oil prices (which we expect to average $36/b this year) ripples through the economy. Although the downward movement in the krone could generate an uptick in inflation owing to higher import costs, we judge that this will only partially countervail the deflationary effects of the fall in demand.

The krone has largely matched the substantial changes in global energy markets since January. Since December 2019, the krone has depreciated by roughly 8.5% on a trade-weighted basis, as the price of oil has collapsed and economic activity has slowed.
Although the krone has strengthened from its nadir in March (when it had depreciated by over 17% since December), conditions of subdued demand and slower growth are likely to prevent the krone from fully returning to its December value until 2024, when oil prices have recovered, and production is restored. Further downward shocks to oil prices, chiefly from shocks to global demand, remain a risk to our exchange-rate forecast.

Norway's current-account surpluses are structurally supported by large inflows in the trade and primary income accounts, respectively reflecting the economy's position as a major oil exporter and the size of the GPFG.
Although inflows in both of these components will be damaged by the economic fallout from the coronavirus, we do not expect either of these accounts to fall into deficit. Oil exports will be damaged by the proposed cuts to production, but we expect that this will be balanced by the reduction in goods imports, keeping the trade balance in surplus despite the fall in oil prices.
As the coronavirus abates, steady rises in oil prices from 2021 onwards will further support the trade balance, and increases in production (barring any government intervention) will continue throughout the forecast period. We expect that this, combined with a revival of growth in major trading partners (particularly the UK and Germany), will support a rise in the current-account surplus over the forecast period, to 5.6% of GDP in 2024.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Norway Stocks and flows Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) had been elevated prior to the sharp fall in oil prices in 2014, averaging US$18.7bn in 2007-12, with significant declines in the wake of the financial crisis and alongside fluctuations in the oil market. After the drop in oil prices in 2014, inward FDI flows weakened greatly, turning negative in 2016, at the nadir of the oil sector's performance. Inward flows also turned sharply negative in 2018, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the coronavirus pandemic to cause a surge in divestment in 2020, before a steady recovery from 2021 onwards, back to net inflows by 2022. However, these inflows are unlikely to reach pre-2014 levels. By end-2019 stocks of inward FDI stood at US$251.5bn, or about 62% of GDP, although this will rise to about 65% by 2024. At US$46,955, FDI per head remains above that of the EU15 and many peer Nordic economics, with Finland and Sweden at US$23,919 and US$46,196 respectively.
Origin and distribution Norway's oil-intensive economy means that FDI is largely focused on the oil and gas sector, in addition to ancillary services such as transport, infrastructure and finance. Most of the world's major oil and gas companies are involved in Norwegian oil production, including Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Marathon (all US-based), BP, Shell (both UK), Eni (Italy), RWE Dea (Germany) and Engie (France). FDI data for 2018, released by Statistics Norway, show that about 24% of all FDI goes to mining and quarrying (including the oil sector), whereas manufacturing, the next highest recipient, gets 15.2%. Financial services are also an important beneficiary of foreign investment, taking about 10.9%. Both manufacturing and financial services have considerable overlap with the oil and gas sector. The bulk of Norwegian FDI has its origins in fellow European countries, with the Netherlands, Sweden and the UK in the top five investor countries, with these three jointly accounting for about 40% of all FDI in Norway. The US has become a more prominent investor in Norway in recent years, now holding 15% of all foreign investment in 2018-higher than the 9% held by the US in 2014.
Determinants The Norwegian government operates a system to encourage and regulate the exploitation of oil within its waters (the country has no onshore oil production). To ensure that the exploration of oil is intensive in previously explored, or "mature", areas, the government awards licences for the exploration of these regions annually-as opposed to unexplored, "frontier", areas, for which licences are awarded once every two years. This awards system has been in place since 2003 and comes with a taxation system, in place since 2005, which rewards exploration but penalises excessive production. The government imposes a special additional tax of 51%, on top of an oil-sector tax rate of 27%, on wells that are producing oil-higher than the marginal tax rate for UK oil producers, which stands at 40%. This high rate of taxation is compensated by a feature that enables upstream companies to write off 78% of losses on oil exploration if the search for oil proves unsuccessful. The presence of oil has led to high FDI stocks, but an onerous tax burden, high wages, Norway's limited market size and high house prices are all factors that restrain further growth in foreign investment. The constraint posed by Norway's small market size is partly mitigated by Norway's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA), which gives Norwegian firms access to the European market. However, this trade access is made slightly more uncertain by Norway's retention of its own currency, the krone, which moves alongside fluctuations in the oil price and adds to exchange-rate risk.
Impact FDI has encouraged a sustained transfer of foreign knowledge to Norway and has accelerated the development of the oil and gas sector. The oil sector has, in turn, encouraged wider growth in the mainland economy, through higher wages and stronger consumer spending but also through ancillary services such as transport and finance. Several of these ancillary services, notably the supply and maintenance services, have become internationally competitive, despite the historically strong krone. Moreover, high taxation on developed oil wells has led to a resilient fiscal balance and vast sovereign wealth fund, the Government Pension Fund Global, which is used as a "nest egg" for future public spending, enabling additional public spending when fiscal stimulus is needed, as was the case after the 2014 slide in oil prices. The government has also withdrawn from the fund in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. Despite the sector's influence on the wider economy, its impact on employment is limited, as just 1% of the labour force is involved in offshore activities. FDI outside oil and gas-related sector is through purchases of existing companies rather than establishing new companies or facilities. Slow progress on selling government stakes in a number of part-publicly owned companies may dampen FDI flows.
Potential Despite recent efforts by the government to induce more investment and private-sector activity by reducing the tax burden, the economy will still remain broadly unattractive to foreign investment owing to high labour costs. Although the population is highly educated and well trained, many of the non-oil, non-agricultural industries remain centred in Oslo, the capital. The government has made the wider development of the "High North" (the areas adjacent to the Arctic) a wider policy priority, offering various incentives and grants, including a reduction in the scale of employer contributions, with a focus on encouraging stronger growth in the maritime, healthcare and information technology sectors there. Nevertheless, the bulk of opportunities for foreign investment will remain in the energy sector, encompassing oil, gas and green energy (notably windpower).

The coronavirus crisis will raise downside risks to population growth The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the population to maintain its steady rate of growth over the forecast period (2020-24), although long-run factors, such as the ageing of the population and the trend towards smaller family sizes, will weigh on population growth in the coming years. Spurred by the solid expansion in the economy, high levels of migration from eastern Europe and the wealth effect of a steady rise in house prices, population growth has been consistently above 1% since 2007, averaging about 1.3% in 2008-14, according to Statistics Norway.
Since the start of 2013 the growth rate of the population has declined, from 1.3% to 0.9% in 2019, as the economic outlook has become more uncertain, reducing both births and immigration. Net immigration declined from its post-crisis peak of more than 48,700 in 2012 to 25,000 in 2018, reflecting the subsiding of the migrant crisis in 2016 and a tightening of migration rules for those outside the European Economic Area (EEA). The disruption caused by the coronavirus will probably dampen population growth significantly in the near term, as the outlook for the offshore and mainland economy weakens and the inflow of migrants slows.
Net migration has declined since 2012, despite a rise in asylum-seekers Net migration, which reached a peak of more than 47,000 in 2012, has been more subdued in recent years as migration from eastern Europe has subsided, to 25,000 in 2019. Inflows of migrants from Poland made up the largest incoming nationality in 2019, falling behind Syrian migrants for the first time since the 2015 migrant crisis. Polish migrants are the largest group within the migrant population, at a total of 101,000, according to official 2019 data.
This is followed by Lithuanians (40,600), Swedes (35,500) and Syrians (31,900). Strong migration inflows earlier in the decade will compensate for Norway's declining fertility rate, which peaked in 2009 at 1.98 (still below the replacement rate), and medical improvements should continue to raise life expectancy. Over the forecast period we expect the population to age gradually, with more than 18% of the population over the age of 67 by 2024, but buoyant inflows of migrant workers should also maintain steady growth in the working-age population at 0.5% from 2020-24, matching its average from 2015-19.
The demographic challenge is not as severe as in other European countries The ageing population will place a greater long-run strain on the public finances, with older citizens requiring more state support in the form of pensions, health and social care. These problems are less immediate than in other countries, as Norway has a more youthful population than other Scandinavian countries, with individuals 65 and over accounting for 27% of the working-age population in 2019, compared with 31% in Denmark. However, the ageing trend, and its repercussions, will remain the same, and we expect the dependency ratio to rise steadily, to 29% in 2024. For the fiscal balance, this will have a steadily corrosive impact.
Reform of the pension system to ensure its sustainability in the face of these pressures has been ongoing since 2001, and various measures, including flexible retirement ages (from 62 to 75), adjustments for life expectancy and less generous indexation have all been implemented to ensure the system is well funded. More measures are likely in the near future to disincentivise early retire-ment. Healthcare expenditure will also rise steadily, along with the median age, owing to both the greater healthcare needs of the older population, the greater need for stockpiling of medical equipment after the coronavirus outbreak and the price inflation of medical technology over the forecast period. Greater fiscal burdens will also be placed on local and municipal government, as the burden of social caring for the aged, in the form of live-in helpers or retirement homes, will also steadily mount as the age of the population rises.
Owing to Norway's unique geography, with a long coastline and separated settlements, rural areas are far more dispersed than in other European countries, raising the cost of services provision for isolated communities. This is aggravated by an increasingly concentrated population as a whole, with 81.9% of Norway's population living in urban areas. Areas in the far north of Norway are remote and underpopulated; Finnmark, the northernmost region, had a population of just 75,000 in 2014 and an area of 48,000 square kilometres. The cost of maintaining public service provision in rural areas was a central driver behind the "municipal reform" implemented by the Conservatives-led govern-ment in 2020.

High marginal taxes and tight labour markets ensure low wage inequality. Despite being one of the richest countries in the world (by GDP per head), Norway's limited population size, of just over 5m, and the country's high operating costs limit the scale of market opportunities available. When ranking countries by nominal GDP per head, Norway is third highest in the world, at US$75,472, ahead of the rest of the OECD excluding Luxembourg and Switz-erland. Measured at purchasing power parity (PPP), Norway performs less well, positioned sixth, with a GDP per head of US$69,213. This is owing to the country's higher price level and the correspondingly weaker purchasing power of the currency in Norway, reflecting higher costs for labour and transport. The econ-omy's overall size remains fairly small, with nominal GDP at just US$418bn, according to the IMF. This is larger than Finland (US$269bn), but slightly smaller than Austria (US$448bn) or Sweden (US$529bn), demonstrating Norway's limited size relative to other global markets. The OECD estimated the country's Gini coefficient to be at 0.262 in 2017, the fifth-lowest in the group of advanced economies (a Gini coefficient of zero represents perfect income equality and 1 displays total income inequality). This strong score reflects the low level of inequality in Norway, ensured by relatively high rates of marginal taxation and redistribution, alongside high levels of trust and co-operation within its society.
Investment has taken a larger role in growth since the financial crisis. Norway's consumer goods market is similar to those of other Scandinavian countries, albeit larger than Denmark's and smaller than Sweden's. Private consumption accounted for about 45% of overall GDP in 2019. Consumption growth accelerated in the late 1990s until 2007, averaging 4.1% year on year from 1996-2007 and contributing an average of 1.5 percentage points to annual economic growth over the period. Since the financial crisis, consumption growth has fallen, averaging 2.5% in 2010-18. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this slowdown to continue over the 2020-24 forecast period, to an average of 2.3%, as investment recedes in its importance. The shock from the coronavirus crisis is likely to suspend further improvements in the near term. Unemployment will rise significantly in 2020, growth in nominal wages will decline, and price growth will subside. By 2024 we expect GDP per head to reach US$78,540 at market exchange rates and US$78,540 at PPP exchange rates.

The dominance of the oil sector prevents substantial diversification. As an advanced economy, Norway's consumers are well equipped with most consumer durables, including white goods, television sets, personal computers and home entertainment equipment. These markets are relatively open to competition, with many small, medium-sized and niche players competing. As the extent of domestic manufacturing remains limited, the bulk of consumer goods are imported. High labour costs are one of the few downsides to producing in Norway: at about EUR50 (US$56) per hour, the average hourly labour costs are among the highest in Scandinavia and the second highest in Europe after Switzerland (at EUR53 per hour) Geographically the country is connected to few of its major export markets (except Sweden) by land, preventing it from taking a role as a business or commercial hub for the rest of Europe. The dominance of the oil sector, on both skilled labour and the currency, also serves to constrain efforts to diversify the economy into other industries, as has been achieved in neighbouring Sweden and Denmark.
Norwegian consumer spending tends to be leisure-focused Norwegians tend to spend a higher proportion of their total income on food than most other European populations, although we expect this figure to fall during the forecast period. In part, this will reflect high tariffs and taxes on food products, as well as limited competition within the food retail sector. A higher proportion of spending is directed towards leisure, including hotel stays and restaurants. E-commerce has become incorperated into many firms' business structures, and 80% of Norwegian retailers have either a mobile app or a mobile-integrated website. We expect the extent of digital-service provision and online retail to increase substantially as a result of the coronavirus. Standards of living are generally high, with two out of ten households owning more than one car and a similar proportion owning a second (or holiday) home. Among the sociological trends that will have an impact on consumption patterns are a rise in single-person households and the gradual ageing of the population.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
The economy will not recover completely (in real terms) from the virus until 2023 Initial conditions: Aided by its rich endowment of offshore oil and gas, Norway's growth has outperformed that of its European neighbours over the past decade, with growth averaging 1.2% in 2008-19, compared with a euro area average of 0.8%. With only 48% of its petroleum reserves extracted to date, the country will retain its pre-eminence in European energy production throughout The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term forecast period, to 2050. However, pressures on the oil and gas sector are expected to mount over the short term as production is curtailed by disruption from the coronavirus crisis, and over the longer term as government policy becomes less accommodative, the oil price stays low and environmental concerns become more prominent in the national debate. Although participation rates in Norway are high, one long-term chall-enge for the government will be to reverse the trend among older workers to take early retirement. To this effect, the pensions system is undergoing more reform, including via a pension adjustment linked to life expec-tancy, which will be fully implemented by 2025. Technological change has also accelerated
Norway's growth in recent years, with the application of communication and information technology becoming more widespread since 2008 and supporting productivity growth. However, the economic fallout from the coronavirus will erode the features that have driven growth since 2009, including tight labour markets and solid trade growth. Further risk factors are a slowing pace of product market reforms and the overweening influence of the oil sector on the economy, limiting diversification and promoting exchange-rate volatility.
Demographic trends: Norway, like many other OECD countries, faces a steadily ageing population, driven by both a socioeconomic trend towards a lower birth rate and a preference for marrying later that have been evident since the 1960s. However, in the Norwegian case these trends have been slower to materialise, and immigration is higher than in the country's European neighbours, so Norway is in a more favourable position to face the challenges of an ageing population relative to other developed countries. Owing to strong inward migration from eastern Europe prior to the coronavirus crisis and a comparatively large share of young people in the population, Norway will maintain positive population growth throughout the forecast period (2020-24), although the rate of growth will fall from the 2020s onwards. The growth rate of the working-age population will also remain positive, but will ease from about 1% per year from 2000-18 to about 0.4% in 2020-50. Concurrently, the proportion of those aged 67 or above, and the old-age dependency ratio (those 67 and over relative to those aged 15-66) will increase, leading to greater fiscal pressure on the government, which provides old age services and transfers. Further rises in the participation rate (which is already among the highest in the world) or improvements to worker productivity will be needed to maintain the social safety net.
Even taking into account the flow of oil revenue, pension liabilities will greatly exceed the expected assets of the entire Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund that was created to ensure that future gen-erations would benefit from the country's oil riches). There is concern that current pension reforms do not go far enough in tackling the problems related to work incentives and the generous scale of public-sector pensions. The government will need to take further action over the coming decade to avoid a sharply rising tax burden.
Disruption from coronavirus could undermine Norway's trading position External conditions: As a small country that is highly dependent on open markets and free trade, Norway stands to benefit from its European Economic Area (EEA) agreement, which extends the EU's single market to include it. The EU is the world's largest and most integrated regional market, and accounts for the vast majority of Norwegian exports and imports. Set against this, the EU's long-term rate of growth is likely to remain moderate. Another uncertainty over the forecast period concerns Norway's position with respect to the EU. Within the EU, although some progress will be made in advancing trade in goods and the liberalisation of trade in services, the focus-particularly in the next decade-will be on ensuring that there is no reversal of these policies. In this context the UK's withdrawal from the EU has the potential to be disruptive. Protectionist forces will increase in the aftermath of the coronavirus outbreak, but as Norway is less well integrated into global supply chains, the fallout from this pressure will be less than in other countries. Although effort has gone into improving Norway-China economic relations, we expect collaboration to be confined to specific sectors, such as fish or oil exports, limiting effectiveness.
The sovereign wealth fund may not be adequate to guarantee pension costs Institutions and policy trends: Norway has a long democratic history and enjoys stable, democratic and transparent institutions, along with a well-entrenched justice system. Corruption is largely absent from Norwegian political and business life. The prospects for stable growth are enhanced by high levels of benefits and state-funded education, including at tertiary level, which ensures a healthy and well-educated workforce. In the long term, however, the welfare state may not be as well funded as it is currently. Norway favours free enterprise and market competition to a lesser extent than Denmark and Sweden. The state remains a significant player in many sectors, such as telecommunications, banking, energy and the offshore sector, and progress on the government's plan to reduce its stakes in some companies has been slow. Norway also lags neighbouring countries in efforts to promote competition in major product and labour markets, in part because the country's oil riches provide little incentive for policymakers to enact potentially unpopular structural reforms. Similarly, there is a risk that the existence of the GPFG will mask the need for reforms to the social security system. Ongoing pension reforms have incentives to work beyond retirement age and cut the link between pension payments and wages; these reform efforts are expected to continue in the coming years. However, government projections indicate that the assets of the pension fund will be insufficient to cover the state's liabilities arising from pensions and other demands on the public purse (such as healthcare) in the absence of further reform of both the pension system and the labour market. Measures would have to include further discouragement from taking early retirement or drawing disability benefits. (The proportion of the workforce drawing disability benefit in Norway is almost double the average for the OECD.) Ensuring the sustainability of Norway's generous welfare state will be an important challenge for future governments.
Strong investment and productivity growth will raise long term output Long-term performance: As Norway has less scope than most other developed economies to raise its labour force participation rate, its long-term economic prospects will depend on a continued high rate of investment, as well as improvements in productivity, which we expect to rise during the forecast period (to an average of 0.3% in 2020-50), having been sluggish for much of the past decade (at an average of 0.2% in 2011-20). Long-term economic performance will also depend on how successive governments meet the challenge of structural reform. Given the current large surpluses on the general government budget, it is often easy for policymakers to ignore non-oil budget deficits. A failure to adapt social security and welfare systems to the challenge of population ageing would lead to large fiscal deficits towards the end of the long-term forecast period, which would necessitate a rising tax burden and dampen growth. This would be exacerbated should oil production decrease markedly, making continued investment in exploration important.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability The majority of Norway's emissions come from the exploitation of the country's oil and gas reserves, with aluminium production also contributing. Domestic energy usage, which is largely met through abundant hydro-electric infrastructure, is not an important contributor to Norway's carbon emissions, unlike in other advanced economies. The Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund) has become more strident in its support of environmental concerns over the past few years. In 2016 two new criteria were established by the fund, making it move away from, firstly, companies with unacceptable greenhouse-gas emissions and, secondly, companies for which at least 30% of revenue is derived from thermal coal, or operations based on thermal coal. In March 2019 the government established a further criterion forcing the fund to divest from upstream firms specialising in oil and gas exploration, although its holdings of generalised energy firms, including all major publicly traded oil producers, have remained.
Norway will be relatively sheltered from the impact of climate change. With a small agricultural sector and a mostly urban population, the country is easily protected from the warming planet. With the majority of economic output concentrated in the area around Oslo, the capital, and the coastal cities of Bergan, Stavanger and Trondheim, the protection of urban areas against rising sea levels and weather events will be central to Norway's strategy to mitigate the economic effects of climate change. The opening up of new areas for oil exploration in the Arctic Circle (as ice cover falls) will be an upside risk to Norwegian growth and should mitigate some costs to output.
Despite efforts by successive governments to bolster environmental policy, a substantial effort to reduce oil-related activities is unlikely, with further reform only likely to limit the sector's growth, rather than reverse it. Aided by the economic need for further diversification, political pressure is mounting from smaller parties, like the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (both of which are in government) and an environmental element within the Labour Party to curtail the oil sector's development. This division within parliament is likely to be reflected in a gradual erosion of the country's generous tax incentives for oil exploration over the long term. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's climate change model, Norway's GDP will be only about 0.8% smaller by 2050 than it would have been in a world without climate change.
Migration and urbanisation Norway has largely adopted an accommodative policy towards migration since the late 1970s and the migrant population (including those of Norwegian birth, but with two parents born abroad) in 2017 was about 888,700, making up 16.8% of the country's total population. Immigration to Norway has risen steadily over the decades-in 1992 migrants totalled about 183,000 people (4.3% of Norway's population) and net migration was relatively small (9,100). Net migration steadily rose thereafter, peaking in 2012 as 48,700 people entered the country, before dropping to 27,800 in 2016. The bulk of these migrants came from eastern Europe after the region's transition into the EU in 2004, but there remains a significant portion of German and Swedish migrants in Norway (totalling about 60,900 in 2016). Recent migration has come from non-European countries such as Syria, Somalia and Eritrea. These migrants have proved more politically contentious, as greater differences in cultural background and socioeconomic status have led to concerns about integration-the far-right Progress Party (FrP) has now included the reduction of non-European migration as part of its policy agenda. Although the FrP supports the centre-right coalition government, we expect Norway's collaborative political system to result in moderate government policy and the country to maintain an accommodative stance on immigration and integration.
Norway's population has become more urbanised as the economy has developed. According to the World Bank, urbanisation rates surpassed 50% in 1960, rising rapidly over the next 20 years to 70.5% in 1980. Since then the pace of urban growth has been more subdued, with the rate only surpassing 80% in 2013, reaching 82% 2018. Norway remains the most rural of the Scandinavian economies, with urbanisation rates in Sweden and Denmark slightly higher, at 87% and 88% respectively. This is in part owing to Norway's large land area and long sea coast, making rural communities more isolated, but also because Norway was historically rural and underdeveloped compared with its Scandinavian peers, and so has further to catch up with its neighbours. The difficulties of paying for high standards of public service provision to an ageing and diminishing population in rural areas are putting pressure on the government to reduce costs. This was the motivation behind the "municipal reform" circulated in 2014 which will aggregate the municipal and county authorities together to encourage greater economies of scale and information-sharing in local government services.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the public health crisis triggered by the spread of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, will retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. Low international crude prices, combined with US sanctions on the regime, mean that Venezuela is struggling to place its oil exports abroad. We therefore project a reduction in domestic crude production over the coming months. Moreover, given that it will lose control of the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure in 2020 to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have so far aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environment rankings for 2020-24, having been 80th in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2022-24: Investors remain highly cautious of committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017, a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus to be 3.6% of GDP.
