Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit considers that the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19) and diminished oil rents-resulting from low international oil prices and existing US sanctions-present the greatest challenges to date to the survival of the military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). Hyperinflation and bolívar depreciation are worsening, with goods shortages already making a comeback. In addition, owing to the bleak state of its healthcare system, Venezuela faces an uphill battle against the coronavirus, and there is a high risk that the ongoing socioeconomic crisis will evolve into a humanitarian calamity. Mr Maduro is wary of the potential political ramifications of fuel scarcity in Venezuela, given that these may lead to severe shortages of goods and public services over the coming months. Coupled with the government's mandatory social distancing measures (which will curb incomes further), significant bouts of social unrest are likely. Mr Maduro's recent decision to lift some petrol subsidies will cause further ill will.
Despite these compounding social and economic shocks, we expect Mr Maduro to retain power throughout 2020, ruling over what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. Mr Maduro has two main factors in his favour. First, the opposition, led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in 2019. Although Mr Guaidó enjoys widespread international recognition as the legitimate leader of Venezuela, the current public health crisis is demonstrating once again that his interim government has no de facto power. Second, the regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. Although the risks to our forecasts are very high, we assume that this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and the recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is an extremely high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as low and consider that a negotiated transition would also be difficult. In early March the US outlined a transition framework in which both Mr Maduro and Mr Guaidó would allow a new state council to be created and fresh elections to be held. However, this proposal (like other negotiated solutions) is likely to fail, as trust issues between the sides are insurmountable. In March the US indicted 14 top chavista officials, including Mr Maduro, discouraging the regime from co-operating on a negotiated exit. Nevertheless, successful talks with Colombia regarding humanitarian and/or health assistance are possible.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink dollar inflows further. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems and a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch Legislative elections will take place in December, assuming that Mr Maduro clings to power and that the regime does not cancel the polls (Mr Maduro has hinted that they could be suspended owing to the coronavirus pandemic). These elections would be neither free nor fair, and the opposition would lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions-most recently placing severe restrictions on the Venezuelan operations of Chevron, a US oil company-and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Mr Maduro's main international backers are Cuba, Russia, China and-more recently-Iran. Russia is helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to circumvent US sanctions; in March the Venezuelan assets of Rosneft (a Russian energy company) were transferred directly to Russia, representing a step-up in the US-Russia diplomatic crossfire over Venezuela. Nevertheless, both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments. Iran recently sent 1.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela in exchange for gold shipments and is helping to fix the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering the fuel shortages and containing the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite community spread and an accelerating number of Covid-19 cases, Mr Maduro has eased nationwide quarantine measures to some degree. From June the regime will implement a "5+10" system, whereby five days of more flexible social distancing measures will be followed by ten of tighter restrictions. Reflecting a lack of confidence in the government's ability to support incomes, quarantine restrictions have barely been followed; many workers lack the savings they need to survive without continuing to work. Furthermore, the country's medical infrastructure is poor and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity. Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The regime's overall lack of policy-making capacity will lead to accelerating hyperinflation, sharper bolívar depreciation and an even steeper recession in 2020.
Moreover, given the risk that fuel shortages pose to the regime, Mr Maduro has taken some steps to alleviate fuel scarcity. On May 31st the regime announced a two-tiered petrol distribution system. Drivers will be subject to a monthly quota of subsidised petrol. When this has been reached, petrol will be available at internationally indexed prices. The regime will also designate 200 fuel stations across Venezuela, which will be operated by independent or private companies, with petrol in these stations costing a fixed US$0.5 per litre. These measures seek to regularise black-market activity so that the regime (rather than a third party) benefits from the gains. Nonetheless, this will only partly work, as arbitrage opportunities are still possible under the new subsidy system.
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the regime's survival. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the current regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, over the medium term, growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. We currently assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. Venezuela's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US court ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, thus currently shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyper-inflationary pressures in 2019. However, we expect hyperinflation to return in the coming months, owing to monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages. Overall, hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect an additional decline, of 25.4%, in 2020. The contraction reflects falling oil exports and the adverse effects of the government's quarantine measures, which will further dent domestic demand. Fuel shortages will also hit the non-oil economy indirectly, through scarcity of inputs and reinvigorated hyperinflation. From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes and continued mass emigration (which is fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability).
Low crude prices and weak oil exports will put significant pressure on the country to slash crude production. Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-US$20 per barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is selling its oil at a loss (its oil basket reached US$10/barrel in mid-May). The current circumstances will inevitably lead to cuts in production; we expect oil output to decline from 630,000 barrels/day (b/d) in April-according to the International Energy Agency (IEA)-to 620,000 b/d on average in 2020. However, we believe that average output could fall as low as 500,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2021 we expect the economy to grow marginally, owing to a stabilisation of oil output, base effects and the lifting of social distancing measures. In 2022 economic growth will accelerate on the back of a surge in oil prices. However, in the medium term, oil output will continue to fall-albeit gradually-owing to serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and to a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude. Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24 (owing to moderately higher global oil prices), as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout the forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will lead to a return to hyperinflation this year. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit helped to subdue hyperinflation in the second half of 2019. However, inflationary pressures will intensify substantially in the coming months, owing to wide-spread goods shortages, the reintroduction of price controls on a number of goods and the ramping-up of government money printing. Indeed, consumer prices rose by 80% month on month in April. In the medium term, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Accelerating hyperinflation will quicken the pace of bolívar depreciation in 2020. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this context, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On May 26th the official exchange rate was BsS193,200:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS196,700:US$1. The premium (currently 1.8%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 2.2% of GDP in 2020, owing to lower oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019). We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 5.3% of GDP in 2022-24. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Global data Oil prices: dated Brent
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
US and OECD growth: OECD
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsS:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+India&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+India+June+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-06-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+India&amp;rft.issn=09668829&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the current government to serve out its second term, which will expire in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration, and make some progress on pushing through structural reforms.
- We expect the government to extend the nationwide lockdown introduced as a result of the coronavirus pandemic in late March until July. Nevertheless, restrictions under the lockdown have been partially relaxed since mid-May. The Economist Intelligence Unit's view is that the daily confirmed cases of the virus will peak in early July.
- India's relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24. However, disagreements on tariff and service-sector export restrictions will limit trade deals. Relations with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's ambitions in South Asia. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- The budget deficit will widen to 7.4% of GDP in 2020/21 (April-March), as the government falls short on revenue income and launches stimulus to keep households and firms afloat during the lockdown. It will narrow but nevertheless remain wide during the remainder of the forecast period.
- We expect the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to cut interest rates by another 100 basis points in the remainder of 2020. The RBI will also tweak its policy tools and regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of accommodative monetary policy.
- Real GDP will contract by 5.8% in 2020/21. While, the recovery in 2021/22 will be sluggish on a sequential basis, we expect the economy to grow by 9.4%, primarily owing to a low base of comparison.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs74.8:US$1 as global investors flee to safe-haven markets. It will strengthen slightly in 2021, before depreciating again for the rest of the forecast period
- The trade deficit will narrow in 2020 amid a slump in global oil prices. It will widen from 2021 as India increases imports of capital goods. Business outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score improves over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies in 2021.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or merger and acquisition activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The government liberalises foreign direct investment (FDI) policy in several sectors, as it also encourages the use of locally made products.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: The country remains reluctant to join major regional trade deals.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: The government provides only marginal tax rebates and breaks to businesses and individuals affected by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks and non-bank financial companies (NBFC), raising risks to incentivise lending to support economic growth.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad debt issues persist in public-sector banks. Major consolidation and privatisations within the public-sector banks will continue.
The labour market 2020-21: Unemployment soars because of the lockdown; the government expands the national employment guarantee scheme. Labour laws are liberalised temporarily in some provinces through state-level ordinances.
2022-24: State-level liberalisation of labour laws is made permanent through legislation by the central government.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation of infrastructural spending to support the economy through the coronavirus crisis.
2022-24: The construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore and Hyderabad. Expenditure on research and development (R&D) as a proportion of GDP remains low by international standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.37bn people in 2019, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2019 when measured in nominal US dollars at purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: We expect the ruling BJP to undertake policy reforms once the coronavirus pandemic passes. The government has already announced measures to privatise or merge public-sector units in many industries to promote competition within private companies. The government will also make modest progress on liberalising regulatory requirements and foreign investment. However, the primary focus of the government will be on structural reform, particularly the contentious labour and land laws. We expect progress to be made on these issues, even in the face of opposition. The current administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this, too. will remain a priority in the next five years.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's merchandise trade deficit narrowed to US$154.1bn in 2019, from US$186.7bn in 2018, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$80.8bn to US$83.7bn in the same period.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) elections that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the central government to remain in power for its full term, which ends in 2024. The results of the 2019 election were a testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi, who will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers.
In late March the government began to implement what have been among the most stringent lockdown measures around the world, designed to stem the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19). These measures were initially welcomed by the public as an effective method of halting the spread of the virus. However, we expect the extensive economic damage caused by these restrictions to lead to increased social unrest. High levels of unemployment and the government's inability to provide income support will challenge the administration. We expect the government's reform agenda, especially with regard to liberalising labour laws, to be another source of social unrest. Nevertheless, we do not expect these developments to unseat the government; this is owing to its formidable support from a large part of the citizenry and the lack of a strong opposition.
Over the medium term, protests by religious groups and communal clashes will pose a threat to political stability. Large-scale protests tied to the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were only cut short by social distancing measures put in place to slow the spread of the virus. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups in the country, notably Muslims. The risk of social instability is high in the latter part of the forecast period, particularly in the two-year period prior to the 2024 general elections, provided the ruling party moves ahead with its Hindutva agenda.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will also remain a key concern throughout the forecast period. The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state sparked protests. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders, further unrest cannot be ruled out. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shutdowns, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be the state assembly elections. The results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important in the former. We expect the BJP coalition to gain power in the upcoming Bihar election to be held in late 2020, but only with the help of its coalition partner in the state.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half the total number of seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) could secure a simple majority in the upper house. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan have been exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August 2019 to revoke the special status granted to J&K. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, the nuclear arsenal of the two countries will act as a powerful deterrent against full-scale conflict.
China is India's primary geopolitical rival in the region, and economic and political relations between the two countries will remain testy. India will continue to take steps to shield the domestic market from Chinese influence, such as a recent change requiring government approval for Chinese investments. Skirmishes will also continue over the infrastructural developments in border regions disputed by the two countries, but these will not turn into large-scale clashes.
We expect India to make progress in improving ties with the US, Japan and Australia, among other countries, to counter China's growing influence. India's foreign policy within South Asia will also focus on countering increasing Chinese influence in Nepal and Sri Lanka with increased diplomatic engagement and economic support. India's relations with Bangladesh will remain more cordial.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the economic policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. The key near-term priority for the administration is to contain the development of the coronavirus outbreak, to which India is particularly vulnerable, given its large population and weak healthcare infrastructure. While the government applied widespread and stringent lockdown measures, it has not succeeded in driving down the infection rate. Furthermore, as the economic costs of these measures became clear, the government relaxed measures by mid-May. While we expect the lockdown to be extended further into June, the current relaxations will, however, continue.
We expect the government to take up policy reforms after the crisis as it looks to support growth. The government has announced plans to open up many sectors of the economy to private firms, by privatising or reducing the number of public-sector units. The government will undertake piecemeal changes to legislation, such as relaxation of regulatory requirements and a modest liberalisation of foreign direct investment (FDI) rules. However, we expect the primary policy focus of the government to be improving the business environment by liberalising contentious labour and land laws. These reforms will take years to materialise and the benefits will only be seen in the latter part of the forecast period. The lockdown will amplify the mounting non-performing loan (NPL) issue in the banking sector. Slow progress will be made towards policy changes to improve the health of the banking sector. Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National Infrastructure Pipeline-remain a priority, in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and partly to boost the business environment. But we expect a revival in infrastructural spending only from the fourth quarter of 2020, once the coronavirus outbreak is brought under control.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The coronavirus outbreak will force the government to rewrite its approved budget for 2020/21, which was conservatively expansionary. It is likely to suspend temporarily the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act to allow for more flexibility in terms of supporting the economy. The extension of the lockdown has prompted an unbudgeted increase in social spending programmes, especially the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, as well as an extension of existing financial support schemes for businesses.
The government had announced an Rs20trn package (equivalent to around 10% of GDP) to support the economy. However, this headline figure includes liquidity measures provided by the central bank and advances by banks under the government's measures. The actual amount of additional budgetary spending announced is worth around 1.4% of GDP. We expect the government to announce another fiscal package, worth 1-1.5% of GDP, in the third quarter of 2020, which will include an infrastructure development programme. Combined with a fall in revenue and lower nominal GDP, the budget deficit is forecast to widen to the equivalent of 7.4% of GDP in 2020/21.
As the economy recovers, the government will look gradually to consolidate the public finances. This will lead to a narrowing of the budget deficit to the equivalent of 6.5% of GDP in 2021/22. The authorities will look to deepen the tax base and increase low levels of tax compliance. However, the need to support welfare payments and infrastructure spending will keep upward pressure on fiscal expenditure. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive, small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the true level of the deficit. The deficits of many states and part of the expenditure by public-sector units represent implicit liabilities for the central government.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The coronavirus epidemic will prompt further monetary-policy loosening by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank). The central bank has lowered its policy repo rate by 115 basis points to 4% since March, as well as widening the monetary-policy corridor by lowering the reverse repo rate (the "floor" of the corridor) by 155 basis points, to 3.35%. With inflationary pressures expected to moderate and economic growth under strong downward pressure, we expect a further 100-basis-point reduction in the policy repo rate over the remainder of 2020. We also expect the adoption of more unconventional policy instruments, which will include further long-term refinancing operations.
Monetary policy will aim to support businesses as the coronavirus pandemic supresses household spending and business investment. However, the outcome may be far from satisfactory, as monetary policy transmission is not smooth. While banking-sector lending to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) will improve as the government has provided a sovereign guarantee to those loans, banks will be reluctant to lend to other parts of the economy, given increased risk. The level of non-performing assets in the financial sector is alarming, and the coronavirus outbreak will only exacerbate the issue, with more firms forced out of business. Policy support by the central bank and the government will be needed to support the recovery of the banking sector once the pandemic passes. The RBI has maintained inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-has complicated the achievement of these objectives.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth We expect real GDP in 2020/21 to contract by 5.8%, registering the sharpest contraction in economic activity since independence in 1947. The headline GDP number will primarily be pulled down by a 20% year-on-year economic contraction in the first quarter of 2020/21, reflecting India's stringent lockdown measures. Economic activity will continue to contract year on year in the second quarter of 2020/21, as job losses and closures of businesses depress economic activity. Many sectors, particularly travel, hospitality and tourism, will continue to contract sharply in the second quarter, with coronavirus cases unlikely to peak until July. Economic conditions will improve through the remainder of the year. Nevertheless, labour shortages and depressed consumer and business sentiment will mean that the economy will still register only modest year-on-year growth in the third and fourth quarters.
On a GDP expenditure basis, we expect private consumption to contract sharply in 2020/21, as people are unable to consume as much during the lockdown and as consumption remains low, even after the lockdown is lifted. Investment spending is also expected to decline steeply as firms postpone investment activity amid high uncertainty around the virus. We also expect increased loan liabilities to be taken up by corporates and banks to further discourage new investment. We maintain our view that the government will continue to bolster the economy through increased expenditure, but the effect will be limited. We expect exports to fall as global recession sets in.
Real GDP growth is expected to rebound sharply in 2o21/22, but the headline forecast of 9.4% is exaggerated by an extremely low base of comparison in 2020/21. Economic growth in 2022/23-2024/25 will average 5.8% a year. Structural reforms, which we expect to be passed by the current administration, will provide support to growth in the latter part of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 3.4% in 2020 as a whole. While food price inflation has remained elevated during the lockdown, we expect it to moderate once supply-side constraints ease. Furthermore, a collapse in non-food demand will lead the fall in the headline number. Inflation will be further pushed down in the second half of the year, owing to a higher base of comparison in 2019. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
The RBI will keep its policy rate unchanged in 2021 to bolster the recovery. The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in 2022 will offset the inflationary impact of strengthening oil prices. The central bank will accord higher priority to containing inflationary pressures towards the end of the forecast period; consumer price inflation is expected to reach 4.4% in 2024.
Low oil prices and low domestic demand in 2020 will cause producer price inflation to decline by 0.2% in the year. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.7% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2020, along with a sharp contraction in economic activity, will weigh on the exchange rate. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate by 6.3% on an annual average basis, to Rs74.8:US$1 in 2020, as investors flee to safe-haven markets and the domestic economic situation worsens. In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate to an average of Rs73.2:US$1, as foreign investment returns. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-24 amid rising oil prices and persistent current-account deficit.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The lower oil price and weaker domestic demand will contribute to a narrowing of India's current-account deficit in 2020, to the equivalent of 0.4% of GDP. Merchandise exports will contract owing to disruption caused by the pandemic, but are expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in global commerce. Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business-process outsourcing and information technology (IT). Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit in the remainder of the forecast period.
The coronavirus outbreak will also weigh on inward investment in 2020-21. Inward direct investment will recover in 2021-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Domestic data GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown
Population: IMF, IFS
Public finance: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by the GOI's annual budget papers
Oil production: Oil & Gas Journal; Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Inflation, exchange rates and money supply: IMF, IFS; Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE; RBI, WSS
Yield on 91-day Treasury bills: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE
Short-term benchmark interest rate: World Bank, India CEM; IDBI prime lending rate
Direction of trade: GOI, Economic Survey (annual)
Composition of trade and the current account: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE or RBI, Annual Report
Foreign direct investment (FDI): IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; includes reinvested profits
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics

Full text: - Venezuela is engulfed in a severe socioeconomic crisis, which will deepen amid the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. Political volatility is high and risks to The Economist Intelligence Unit's political outlook are substantial. For now, we maintain our assumption that the regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) will retain power throughout 2020. The opposition led by Juan Guaidó, the leader of the National Assembly, has lost its momentum, while international pressure has reached an impasse. Moreover, Mr Maduro has managed to exert a strict control over the country's complex security apparatus, which is crucial to maintaining power. The largest threat to Mr Maduro's rule is not the opposition, but ultra-low international oil prices. Weak oil rents could lead to cracks within the regime and could fuel mass social unrest, owing to severe shortages of fuel and food. We acknowledge, however, that the risks of a political transition are currently very high.

- Venezuela ranks as the least attractive location of the 82 countries covered in our rankings in the 2020-24 forecast period. The severe macroeconomic crisis is a key factor in this forecast, posing challenges for business through its impact on income and purchasing power, the migration of a sizeable share of the population (approaching 20%) abroad and the destruction of virtually all of the country's non-oil manufacturing capacity. Government policy deters foreign investment through capital controls, a heavy tax burden and a weak commit-ment to creating a level playing field for foreign firms. All of these challenges will become even harder to address in the context of the coronavirus pandemic and the collapse in oil prices.

- A combination of highly distortionary economic policies and subdued global oil prices will prolong Venezuela's recession in 2020. Large budget deficits-owing to a narrow revenue base and dropping oil production-will continue to spur money printing, driving inflation. Oversupply of local currency and falling exports will yield significant bolívar depreciation. Our fore-casts for 2021-24 are more positive, based on the assumption that international oil prices will bounce back somewhat, thus improving oil revenue and giving way to relatively macroeconomic stability. However, real economic recovery and growth will not occur under the current administration.

- Amid the political and economic crisis, Venezuela's population has declined in recent years owing to outmigration, with over 5.1m Venezuelans estimated to have left since 2014; this has resulted in population growth declines in 2015-19. We forecast that mass outward migration will continue, owing to the lack of employment and goods shortages in Venezuela. Given that many of the refugees and migrants will have been of working age, this will result in a higher old-age dependency ratio. This ratio will remain low by developed-country standards, but population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily indebted social security system in a context of volatile public finances.

- Years of economic crisis and hyperinflation have decimated the Venezuelan economy; in real terms it is now two-thirds smaller than it was in 2013. Our forecast for Mr Maduro to retain power assumes that a strong economic recovery is unlikely in the coming years. The economic crisis and falling real incomes will continue to restrict purchasing power. Although Venezuela is generously endowed with natural resources, extremely challeng-ing conditions will keep private-sector investment well below potential.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.

- Assuming that international oil prices will bounce back in 2021, we expect that Venezuela's economy will begin to recover. Nevertheless, this will not reverse the damage inflicted on the economy in recent years and economic growth will plateau in the long term. GDP growth will average only 1.1% annually in 2020-30. In 2031-50 we forecast that Venezuela's real GDP growth will pick up to 3.5%, as relative macroeconomic stability-a result of limited economic reforms from future governments-enables non-oil sector growth and boosts labour productivity growth, helping to offset deteriorating demographics. Persistent oil dependency will be difficult to undo, and a weak productive base will limit overall economic output.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017, a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus to be 3.6% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance The ruling party, originally called the Movimiento V República and transformed into the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) in 2006, has been in power since 1999. The populist-nationalist PSUV was initially ruled by the late president, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). Since Mr Chavez's death, the party has been led by Nicolás Maduro. Over most of its tenure, the PSUV has wielded practically uncontested power, initially owing to Mr Chavez's immense popularity, and later through electoral manipulation and systematic campaigns to disenfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. The opposition is diverse and contested the 2015 election as part of the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática coalition, winning a majority in the National Assembly (AN)-although the group's largest party, Acción Democrático, left the coalition in July 2018. However, following the opposition's victory, the government sought to make the AN essentially powerless, and convened a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC) that has granted itself remit over all legislative matters. The politicised Supreme Court and the executive have recognised the ANC, turning it into the country's de facto legislature and relegating the AN.
Mr Maduro's controversial re-election in May 2018 was declared illegitimate by the AN, leading that body's president, Juan Guaidó, to declare himself interim president of the country in January 2019 (when Mr Maduro's disputed new term began). In this claim, Mr Guaidó has support from the majority of the international community, including most Latin American democracies and the US. Although the regime had set the ANC as the de facto legislature, Mr Maduro's actions tacitly recognise the opposite. The regime understands that the AN holds an important legitimacy among the inter-national community, which limits his room for manoeuvre in terms of foreign policy. Thus, Mr Maduro has sought to undermine Mr Guaidó's control over the AN through gambits, such as forcing opposition legislators into exile or physically closing down the legislative palace. Indeed, Mr Maduro is eyeing the December 2020 legislative elections, in which the regime is set to regain control of the AN, as the elections will be neither free nor fair.

Political outlook: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit considers that the spread of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) and the collapse of international crude oil prices present the greatest challenges to date to the survival of the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). These simultaneous crises have shattered the relative stability that had developed in recent months. With the onset of the crises, shrinking oil revenue will add significant pressure to the regime's finances. Hyperinflation and bolívar depreciation will worsen, with shortages of food and fuel making a comeback. In addition, owing to the bleak state of the country's healthcare system, Venezuela faces an uphill battle against the coronavirus and there is a high risk that the ongoing socioeconomic crisis will evolve into a humanitarian calamity.
Mr Maduro is wary of the potential political ramifications of the coronavirus outbreak in Venezuela. With US dollars ever more scarce, severe shortages of goods and public services are likely over the coming months. Together with the government's mandatory social-distancing measures, which will further curb incomes, significant bouts of social unrest are likely.
However, despite these compounding social and economic shocks-and the US sanctions already in place-we expect Mr Maduro to retain power throughout 2020, ruling over what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. Mr Maduro has two main factors in his favour. First, the opposition led by the head of the National Assembly (AN), Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in 2019. Although Mr Guaidó enjoys widespread international recognition as the legitimate leader of Venezuela, the current public health crisis is demonstrating once again that his interim government has no de facto power. Secondly, the regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. Although the risks to our forecasts are very high, we assume that this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and the recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is an extremely high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as low. A negotiated transition would also be difficult, in our view. In early March the US outlined a transition framework in which both Mr Maduro and Mr Guaidó would allow a new state council to be created and fresh elections to be held. Mr Guaidó himself recently called for the creation of a "national emergency government" (which would not include Mr Maduro) to better combat the coronavirus epidemic. However, both proposals (and other negotiated solutions) are likely to fail, as trust issues between the sides are insurmountable. In March the US indicted 14 top chavista officials, including Mr Maduro, discouraging the regime from co-operating on a negotiated exit. Nevertheless, successful talks with Colombia regarding humanitarian and/or health assistance are possible.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Furthermore, the collapse in international crude prices and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink dollar inflows. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems and a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Venezuela will continue to suffer in the 2020-24 forecast period from the weakest political and institutional framework in the region. Two decades of rule by the PSUV have engendered low institutional effectiveness and high levels of corruption, largely owing to the centralisation of power within the executive branch. Questions around the credibility of the country's institutions, and a lack of accountability and transparency, will continue. For example, massive corruption and clientelism in the provision of subsidised goods and utilities will remain a risk for political effectiveness. Similarly, Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) is an enormous source of direct and indirect profits for regime insiders and the company will continue to be run by army personnel, and not by technocrats.
In an eventual political transition (not our baseline forecast), there would still be little progress in addressing these shortcomings, as approving numerous structural frameworks and eliminating inherent vested interests would require considerable political capital, which will probably be in short supply. A new government, which would undoubtedly include former chavistas, would be constrained by public demands to punish corruption in the previous admin-istration, balanced against the practical need to keep PSUV regime members and bureaucrats onside.
Moreover, a political transition could similarly exacerbate existing problems, such as violent crime, which is currently fuelled by corruption in the judiciary and law enforcement. This could be aggravated by the disbanding of colectivos (armed pro-PSUV civilian groups), which would continue to operate as armed gangs under a future government.
Drug-trafficking will remain a worrisome issue, with criminal networks well established in the country. US authorities have repeatedly accused high-ranking military and civilian government members of drug-trafficking (those accused deny the allegations). Furthermore, the homicide rate has risen sharply over the past 15 years. According to official figures, Venezuela recorded a homicide rate of 58 per 100,000 people in 2015, although private sources claim that the rate was much higher. Subsequent measurements by a well-regarded local think-tank, the Observatorio Venezolano de Violencia, put the national murder rate in 2019 as high as 60.3 per 100,000 people, a slight reduction from 2017, but still the highest regionally and among the highest in the world. Aside from homicides, there have been numerous high-profile kidnappings for ransom in urban areas, a development that has increased concern over police corruption and mis-management. This increase in criminality will not be halted unless measures are adopted to improve the competence and effectiveness of law enforcement agencies and the criminal justice system, to reduce rates of impunity, and to boost youth employment.
Political outlook: Election watch Legislative elections will take place in December, assuming that Mr Maduro clings to power and that the regime does not cancel the polls (Mr Maduro has hinted that the elections could be suspended owing to the coronavirus pandemic). These elections would be neither free nor fair, and the opposition would lose control of the AN. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Political outlook: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions-most recently severe restrictions on US oil firm Chevron's operations in Venezuela-and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) so that Mr Maduro is forced to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future. The US admin-istration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Mr Maduro's main international backers are Cuba, Russia and China. Russia is helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to circumvent US sanctions; in March, the Venezuelan assets of Rosneft (a Russian energy company) were transferred directly to Russia, representing a step-up in the US-Russia diplomatic crossfire over Venezuela. Nevertheless, both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments. Furthermore, at present Iran is reportedly helping to fix the Amuay oil refinery in exchange for gold shipments.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings placed Venezuela among the world's least attractive investment locations during the historical period (2015-19). The country deteriorates further during the 2020-24 forecast period, leaving it ranked as the worst place to do business in the 82 countries covered by our rankings.
The poor score reflects a combination of political conflict, an erosion of the legal framework for investors, and a state-led model that hampers private enterprise and competition. Highly distortionary macroeconomic policy measures have created critical economic problems that have paralysed the investment climate, most noticeably through extreme difficulties in purchasing foreign exchange and remitting profits. Recurrent goods shortages, combined with the regime's highly expansionary fiscal and monetary policy stance, have generated hyperinflation.
The macroeconomic collapse poses significant challenges for businesses because it has fundamentally altered income patterns and Venezuelans' purchasing power, has forced a sizeable share of the population (approaching 20%) to migrate and has destroyed virtually all of the country's non-oil manufacturing capacity. All of these challenges will become harder to address in the context of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and the collapse in oil prices. Our underlying forecasts for the business environment are based on the political assumption that the regime led by Nicolás Maduro remains in place, but there is an extremely high level of uncertainty regarding this projection, given the unprecedented challenges that the coronavirus-led crisis brings. Yet, even if the regime was overthrown and a more market-friendly administration was in power, the extent of dislocation means that it would take several years to put the country on a firmer footing.

Business environment outlook: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency will remain limited.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, while de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2022-24: Investors remain highly cautious of committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
