a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The macroeconomic environment will remain very weak During the forecast period, Venezuela's macroeconomic environment is ranked as the least attractive of all 82 countries covered in our rankings. The economy has contracted sharply for six consecutive years, aggravated by three years of hyperinflation and a sizeable drop in oil production, from 2.4m barrels/day (b/d) in 2015 to an average of 860,000 b/d in 2019. This reflects a combination of long-running underinvestment in Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the state oil firm), little private investment, deep-seated corruption and, since 2019, the impact of US oil sanctions and nationwide power cuts.

- The coronavirus pandemic and collapse in oil prices will place huge strains on the already critical economy. Shrinking oil revenue will add significant pressure to the regime's finances, which will aggravate shortages of food and fuel, and worsen hyperinflation and bolívar depreciation. Venezuela will be disprop-ortionately, negatively hit because of the legacy of years of incompetent policymaking. The fact that Venezuela is in default on its external debt means that no sources of external finance will be available to cushion the impact on the domestic economy. Foreign reserves have already been nearly entirely wiped out, leaving the economy completely exposed to the deterioration in external demand under way as a result of the coronavirus. Unless the Maduro regime is replaced by a more market-friendly government (not our baseline forecast), there is little prospect of a material improvement in macroeconomic conditions during 2020-24.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
1.5 1.8 81 81 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Distortionary measures and price controls will remain the regime's norm The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition will remain extremely weak in 2020-24 and Venezuela's ranking in this category will place it among the least business-friendly of the 82 countries assessed in the business environment rankings. Operating conditions have long been challenging, but the Maduro regime will refuse to alter its stance-characterised by bias against free markets, politicised and inefficient institutions, and widespread price-fixing-despite supply constraints amid a deepening economic crisis. Hopes that greater currency and debt pressures will force Mr Maduro to adopt a more pragmatic approach are likely to be dashed. Uncertainty over contract and property rights, distortionary price and exchange controls, and the cumbersome burden of government regulation will continue to restrict businesses' freedom to compete under Mr Maduro. In the context of the institutional decay that has occurred in recent years, improving competition policy (as well as restricting lobbying and corruption) would require an overhaul of regulatory bodies and legal frameworks. This will not occur under Mr Maduro; even if his regime is replaced by a more market-friendly administration (not our baseline forecast), the process of improving competition policy would take several years.

- Even though there have been fewer outright seizures of private companies under Mr Maduro compared with his predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2009), there will be a high and ongoing risk of state interference in 2020-24. Politically sensitive industries, including those with access to foreign exchange (including energy and financial services) and those selling goods that are prone to shortages (including food retailers), are particularly vulnerable. The regime has used accusations of black-market transactions, or of increasing retail prices too aggressively as a pretext for uncompensated state intervention. Most recently, in April the Maduro administration took over the management of Alimentos Polar (the country's largest private-sector food manufacturer), as well as two meat producers, Plumrose and Matadero Turmero, following accusations that the firms had flouted previous price agreements. Raids, fines and confiscations on retailers violating maximum prices are a common occurrence and will continue during the forecast period.
- Price controls on a wide range of goods have been in place for most of the past 17 years. Periods in which the regime has eased controls-most recently in mid-2019 until April 2020-have been quickly followed by a renewed tightening, usually in response to rampant inflation and slippages in global oil prices (which have the effect of cutting foreign-exchange earnings and therefore hampering the country's import capacity). Price controls affect food manu-facturers and retailers, with a broad range of food staples, including meat, dairy, cooking oil, flour and rice, featuring on the regime's latest list of price-controlled goods. Price controls are also applied to domestic petrol sales and utility rates. Managed prices are regularly lifted in the context of hyperinflation, but soaring overheads means that firms may operate at a loss. Some degree of price controls is likely to be reimposed on an even larger number of products during 2020-21, which will continue to undermine the operating environment for businesses.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.3 2.8 77 80 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Foreign investment will remain scarce Venezuela's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment slip further between the historical and forecast period. On the assumption that the Maduro administration clings to power, there is little prospect of any friendlier approach towards foreign investment from the Maduro regime, despite the fact that investment is desperately needed to rebuild the decimated domestic productive capacity. Although the 1999 constitution establishes national treatment for foreign capital, in practice both the Chávez and Maduro administrations have prioritised investment from firms tied to, or owned by, friendly governments. However, as funding from China has dried up, economic necessity has driven the regime to be less selective about the sources of investment. Given extreme economic and policy instability, we do not believe that this will result in a significant increase in investment inflows (or an improvement in operating conditions for foreign firms). Given that the Venezuelan government remains in default on its external debt obligations, firms would not be able to access invest-ment protection schemes, adding a further disincentive.

- The fact that the World Bank's International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) is currently considering 17 cases lodged by firms affected by government nationalisation-most of which have dragged on for several years-will deter foreign investment, particularly as there is little indication that the Maduro regime has either the desire or the funds to make compensation payments. Indeed, about 30 cases have already been concluded by the ICSID, but the regime has only agreed payment plans on a limited number of these cases, and only under threat of seizures in foreign courts.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.7 4.6 77 75 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Easing currency controls will prove difficult and will progress only slowly This category is the only area of the business environment in which we expect a slight improvement in conditions, leading to a small improvement in Venezuela's global and regional ranking. This mainly reflects the lifting of exchange-rate controls in 2019, with individuals and companies now able to buy or sell foreign currency at private and state-run banks, which has brought the bolívar somewhat closer to its black-market value. Notwithstanding the improvement, however, Venezuela continues to rank extremely poorly in this area. Despite the lifting of currency controls, there remain significant barriers to accessing US dollars in the context of extremely limited supply and the regime still intervenes in foreign-exchange markets if necessary. With global oil prices likely to remain depressed in 2020-21-and rise only moderately in 2022-24-supply of foreign currency is likely to be restricted, hampering foreign trade. Trade policy will remain incoherent and Venezuela remains an unreliable partner, racking up significant debt in unpaid invoices to suppliers. The country has been subject to increasingly tight US sanctions on financial transactions, as well as on the country's oil trade. These restrictions will remain in place as long as the Maduro regime is in office.

- Given that hyperinflation is likely to take hold again in the coming months, another currency denomination or even the introduction of a new currency is possible at some point during the forecast period. There has long been speculation that the country's deep currency distortions might force Mr Maduro to replace the currency with the US dollar; until recently, we believed that deep-seated political aversion to the adoption of the currency of a foreign-policy foe made outright dollarisation unlikely. However, Mr Maduro has shifted his stance in recent months, with the Venezuelan leader demonstrating greater openness towards the wider use of the US dollar in Venezuela. After years of labelling the US dollar a "criminal" currency, Mr Maduro has welcomed the existence of the US dollar. Many domestic transactions are now conducted in US dollars, with most shops now accepting payment in dollars. Although a formal abandonment of the bolívar and the adoption of the US dollar as the country's official currency does not form part of our baseline scenario, it is a possibility within the forecast period.
- Difficulty in remitting profits earned in Venezuela will remain one of the most significant challenges of doing business for foreign companies operating in the country. Official permission is required to remit profits, but with critical shortages of foreign exchange, remittances face long delays. Many foreign-owned companies have not been able to remit their profits for many years. In the context of massive local-currency depreciation, the waitlisted profit remittances have seen their US dollar value erode significantly.
- Foreign trade will continue to suffer from US sanctions that have been in place for several years against several government individuals, but have been ramped up significantly since 2017 and now target the country's com-mercial infrastructure, including its financial and energy sectors. In 2017 the US president, Donald Trump, issued an executive order that prohibited Venezuelan government entities, including PDVSA, from accessing US financial markets; this was followed by another executive order in May 2018 that prohibited dealings in Venezuelan debt issues. In January 2019 the US Treasury Department sanctioned PDVSA, blocking its property held in US jurisdictions and prohibiting it from engaging in transactions with US entities (companies or individuals). The US has warned non-US countries and companies that it is considering punitive action if they continue to trade with Venezuela, but has so far drawn short of applying sanctions on third parties. Sanctions will remain in place as long as the Maduro regime is in office.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.1 4.9 65 78 8 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Improvements in the tax regime are unlikely given fiscal constraints The tax regime will remain a barrier to investment, with fiscal constraints prompting a further deterioration in this area during the forecast period. Rates of direct corporate taxation are currently moderate, with a top corporate income tax rate of 34% (excluding oil companies, for which the rate is set at 50%), but tax laws, regulations and procedures are complicated, inconsistent and subject to frequent arbitrary adjustments. The system is extremely complex: according to the World Bank's 2020 Doing Business survey, 99 separate payments are required each year for businesses to comply with tax requirements (compared with a Latin American average of 28), taking 920 hours to complete (compared with a Latin American average of 317 hours). The tax burden is heavy, accounting for 73% of profits (the regional average is 47%). A series of new taxes introduced in 2009 in many cases doubled the effective tax rate on earnings. These taxes formed part of wider reforms such as a sports law, a new science and technology law, a worker training law, and a municipal law, but included new fiscal charges on businesses-some of which are levied on gross revenue rather than net earnings. The weakening fiscal outlook in the context of the coronavirus pandemic and plummeting global oil prices will severely limit the scope for tax cuts, and may even increase the tax burden on businesses.

- It is difficult to assess exactly how narrow the tax base is currently: according to the latest official data disclosed by Venezuela's tax authority (Seniat), tax income accounted for just 12% of GDP in 2012. The Seniat regularly reports large increases in tax collection, but with hyperinflation, tax collection is actually shrinking in real terms, implying that the tax base has shrunk even further in recent years. Despite this, we do not believe that tax rises are likely under the current administration. Mr Maduro has shown little interest in raising revenue to offset significant increases in public spending and he appears content with financing the huge fiscal deficit through public debt issuance, which is monetised, driving hyperinflation.
- The fiscal regime will do little to encourage new investment in 2020-24. In theory, Venezuela offers both foreign and domestic investors a full and equal range of investment incentives, including tax exemptions, special credit financing, export incentives and debt-equity swaps. The federal government also operates a number of state-run lending institutions that focus on micro, small and medium-sized businesses. Corporación Venezolana de Guayana, the state industrial-holding company, also offers investment incentives, as do many states and municipalities. However, there is no evidence that the Maduro regime is actually making the benefits of these investment incentives available to businesses.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.3 2.5 77 80 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Financing conditions will remain difficult Venezuela's score for financing deteriorates further in the forecast period, given the weak state of the banking sector, and on the assumption that improvements in access to medium-term finance for the private sector are highly unlikely during 2020-24, as is eliminating distortions in the financial sector. Financial sector distortions will remain severe, with the regime set to continue its policy of directed lending, which requires private banks to channel credit to specific sectors at preferential rates (including agriculture, mortgages and tourism). Despite huge increases in nominal lending in local-currency terms, this reflects captive domestic liquidity, hyperinflation and deeply negative real interest rates. In both real and US dollar terms, the financial sector has shrunk dramatically in recent years, resulting in a shallow credit market. We do not expect any significant rationalisation of the financial sector within 2020-24; as such, financing will remain a major weakness of the business environment throughout the forecast period.

- The soundness of the financial system and the quality of regulation will remain key concerns. Legislative changes in recent years have not resulted in a tighter regulatory framework, but have simply established new layers of bureaucracy. There has been no concerted effort to tackle the patchy enforcement of existing regulations. Weak skills in regulatory agencies and political meddling in oversight decision-making will remain problems, and will continue to undermine efforts to identify and support ailing banks at an early stage. Improving the quality of financial sector regulation is unlikely to be achieved, given a lack of political will.
- State intervention will continue to have an impact on the health and profitability of the banking industry. The state already has a substantial direct presence in the industry through full ownership of three of the top ten banks, and is prone to intervention in private-sector lenders.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.1 3.7 81 82 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Recent large-scale emigration will hamper the labour market in 2020-24 Venezuela's labour market is forecast to deteriorate further in 2020-24, mainly reflecting increased skills shortages following the departure of large numbers of Venezuelans in recent years. Even though the coronavirus outbreak has slowed outward migration sharply, this is set to resume in the second half of 2020 and few of the skilled Venezuelans who have left the country are likely to return until the economy is on a much firmer footing (if at all). The economy's informal sector is large and employs a substantial portion of the country's workers. The highly distorted exchange-rate system makes it very difficult to assess wage costs in US dollar terms, in comparison with the rest of the region. Venezuela's labour laws were already among the most rigid in the world, even before a highly restrictive labour reform came into effect in 2012. This increased non-wage costs considerably: obligatory non-wage costs, employers' social security contributions, mandatory profit sharing, and childcare and food allowances added more than 70% to the basic wage costs for large and medium-sized companies, and 30% for smaller companies.

- The mass exodus of Venezuelans leaving the country will put significant constraints on the labour market during 2020-24, particularly in terms of companies' ability to find skilled labour. As of April, the UN estimates that 5.1m Venezuelans-about 18% of the population-had fled the country. Although outward migration has virtually halted in the wake of the coronavirus pan-demic, with some reports of Venezuelans even returning across land borders as informal-sector work in Colombia and Brazil has dried up, we expect the numbers of Venezuelans leaving the country to start to pick up again once lockdowns in neighbouring countries are lifted. This will worsen skill shortages further. This situation will be aggravated by the fact that chronic under-investment in education in recent years means that even basic skills are scarce in much of the workforce, while political interference in universities and technical colleges has damaged the quality of the country's tertiary education system.
- Wage and non-wage costs come on top of a long-standing firing freeze, under which staffing levels (excluding managers, short-term workers and high-income earners) can be reduced only via collective agreement. Many workers cannot be fired at all, even in cases of stealing company property or failing to come to work. In practice, companies looking to shed staff are forced to negotiate "voluntary redundancy" agreements with workers; these typically centre on extremely generous severance payments, further adding to employment costs. Employment tribunals are generally hostile to private-sector employers, a factor used by workers and union representatives to their advantage. Moreover, companies that make recourse to voluntary redundancies have at times been targeted for nation-alisation, representing a further disincentive for the private sector.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.3 3.8 66 78 8 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Electricity provision will remain a critically weak area of infrastructure Following years of mismanagement and underinvestment, Venezuela's infrastructure has fallen into critical disrepair and we expect further slippage in 2020-24. Repeated pledges by the Maduro administration to implement ambitious infrastructure projects have come to nothing, with state-led investment drying up entirely in recent years. Even routine maintenance has not been completed, with current prolonged power shortages and limited access to running water the most visible manifestation of this failure to sustain basic service provision. The coronavirus outbreak will pose even greater fiscal constraints and, coupled with the ongoing difficulty of attracting long-term foreign direct investment (FDI) into capital projects, will compound the dismal state of the country's infrastructure. Given pervasive corruption in state institutions, even multilateral assistance is unlikely to be particularly forthcoming, sustaining problems of limited power and fresh water supply. Even if a new, more market-friendly, government took office during the forecast period (not our baseline scenario), reversing the long-term underinvestment in infrastructure would take many years.

- Reliable access to electricity will be one of the most significant challenges for businesses operating in Venezuela in 2020-24. Although the country has long faced sporadic power outages, the situation has deteriorated sharply in recent years, which on occasion has forced the government to request that workers remain at home while the authorities try to restore power. Some companies have opted to install backup generators, but this is a costly solution that does not solve all operational problems, as businesses find it difficult to find fuel and staffs face difficulties getting to work during blackouts. The supply of fresh water has been seriously affected, while communication, financial and transport networks have also been interrupted. Insufficient investment in maintaining the generation and transmission systems in recent years are to blame. Electricity tariffs have been kept extremely low, leading to rapid growth in demand. Water levels at the Guri dam-which generates most of the country's hydropower (which, in turn, accounts for more than 50% of total electricity generation)-have recovered from critically low levels, but with recent damage to several transformers at the dam, power generation currently stands at considerably less than the total installed capacity of 24,000 MW. Even if the government had the funds, overhauling the entire system would take years-meaning that blackouts (and possible electricity rationing) will persist throughout the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.0 2.1 73 80 9 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is not well prepared for technological disruption As in virtually all other categories of the business environment rankings, Venezuela's already weak technological readiness ranking deteriorates even further during 2020-24. Given the scale of the economic crisis, modernising technology provision and digitalising services will remain far from a govern-ment priority. The crisis will continue to take its toll on the telecommunications sector, with falls in disposable income leading to an ongoing decline in mobile-phone penetration (which has already fallen steadily since 2013 and now only stands at about 60%). Internet penetration has also since fallen; both are now among the lowest rates in the region. Given that these areas are critical to driving broader technological developments, including mobile apps and cloud computing, Venezuela's slippage in these areas are important factors explaining the country's weak score. Regulation and governance also remain relative weak points, while the long-running economic crisis has deterred private investment, which in turn has hampered research and development, and the number of patent applications.
Skills shortages will undermine Venezuela's long-term growth
- Price and tariff regulations affect the quality of technological infrastructure in Venezuela, because high consumption levels are not matched by capital expenditure. Chronic underinvestment in scientific and technical skills, and massive "brain drain" also limit Venezuela's technological readiness. Moreover, acute skills shortages in technology will not be resolved in the short term, and private investors will want to wait for the political and economic situation to improve significantly (which is not expected within the forecast period) before making substantial capital expenditure commitments.
- Although the Maduro regime, like the Chávez government before it, sought to direct state investment towards a variety of high-tech sectors, resources have been allocated inefficiently. For instance, the administration funded the construction of a factory to manufacture mobile telephones, but underinvested in the mobile network infrastructure, leading to poor service. Similarly, the government also built a factory to build educational computers, but school curriculums, educational materials and teaching standards have not been revised to train children in computer programming.
- Internet and mobile-network services are some of the cheapest in the world. However, lags in price adjustments make it difficult to cover the rising cost of maintaining the level and quality of the services. In addition, theft of equip-ment from companies' network infrastructure is common. As a result, service is unreliable and internet speeds are low compared with neighbouring countries.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The regime led by Nicolás Maduro will focus on weathering the collapse in oil prices and containing the looming public health crisis caused by the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. At the time of writing, the country had 414 reported cases of the virus and had reached Stage 4 (community spread). To contain the spread, Mr Maduro announced a mandatory nationwide quar-antine set to be extended until at least mid-June, and made the wearing of facemasks compulsory. To cushion the adverse effects of social distancing on people's incomes, Mr Maduro also announced extraordinary cash transfers and rent deferrals, but funds to finance such measures are scarce. Reflecting a lack of confidence in the government's ability to support incomes, quarantine restrictions have barely been followed; many workers lack savings to survive without continuing to work. Furthermore, the country's medical infrastructure is poor and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity. Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The regime's overall lack of policymaking capacity will lead to accelerating hyperinflation, sharper bolívar depreciation and an even steeper recession in 2020.
Based on The Economist Intelligence Unit's view that Mr Maduro will retain power for the duration of the 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the survival of the regime. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the present regime.

The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime heavily relies on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, over the medium term, growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. At present, we assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. The country's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly debt issued by Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm) and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US court ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US currently considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, thus shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors. However, once the PSUV retakes control of the (currently legitimate) AN, Citgo assets will no longer be safeguarded.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 28.5 45.6 42.7 35.5 31.3 29.9
The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyper-inflationary pressures in 2019. However, we expect hyperinflation to return in the coming months, owing to monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages. Overall, hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.

Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) that originated in December 2019 in Wuhan, central China, is now a global pandemic. The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that the virus will affect about 50% of the world population, including asymptomatic cases. Of the symptomatic cases, about 20% will experience severe symptoms and about 1% will not recover. Death ratios will depend on a country's capacity to detect, track and contain the virus, and the capacity of its national health system. We believe that a mass vaccine will be available at end-2021 (at the earliest) and that the coronavirus will become a seasonal disease, with another outbreak likely in winter 2020/21.
Quarantine and social-distancing measures will be effective in limiting the spread, but they will have severe negative economic consequences. Disruptions to global supply chains will also be severe. Overall, we forecast that global output will contract by 2.5% in 2020, and that global trade will drop by 15.3%. All G7 countries and almost all G20 countries will experience a full-year recession. We forecast real GDP growth in China of only 1% in 2020 and a full-year recession in the US, with a contraction of 2.9%. We assume that oil prices will be 40% lower this year, averaging US$36/barrel. Most countries have responded with huge fiscal expansion to support businesses and households, raising the risk of sovereign debt crises in the medium term. Central banks have cut interest rates and, more importantly, have stepped up as buyers of last resort for government and corporate debt.
The infection curve in Latin America is about four to six weeks behind that of European countries and about two to three weeks behind that of the US. As such, cases are expected to peak in May in Latin America. Managing the health crisis in the region is particularly challenging, given overstretched hospitals, limited fiscal resources and the fact that large swathes of the population live in shanty towns with poor basic services and where social distancing is challenging. Although containment measures will remain the priority in the short term, the policy debate in Latin America will soon begin to turn towards how to plan for an easing of lockdown measures. In formulating exit strategies, Latin American governments will draw on all the data available relating to the progression of the pandemic and experiences in other regions. Their challenge will be to get the timing and phasing right, so that the numbers of coronavirus cases and deaths remain under control, health services can cope, public confidence in the handling of the crisis remains strong and the economy can recover. Exit strategies will be implemented gradually and reviewed on a regular basis. There is a risk that even a gradual and phased easing will expose countries to a second wave of infections (as has happened in Singapore and South Korea).
The coronavirus pandemic will have a severe economic impact. We forecast a Latin American recession in 2020, with a contraction of 5%, with output in all of the major economies contracting by 3-7%. Some Caribbean countries, which depend on tourism, will be hit even harder. Quarantine measures will result in a sharp supply-side shock, hitting working hours and productivity, and manufacturers will suffer from a disruption to global supply. Supply-side disruptions will be short-lived, but demand effects will be long-lasting. A decline in confidence is likely to persist after quarantine measures are lifted. For fear of contagion, people may continue to avoid public spaces, and tourism may not resume immediately. Households will limit their consumption in response to a loss of income, and businesses will delay investment.
The longer-lasting political and geopolitical impact of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, with limited parliamentary oversight. Elections have been cancelled, or delayed, in some countries. When the pandemic has passed, governments will face intense scrutiny on their response. A failure to address the humanitarian crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. A severe global economic crisis, followed by renewed fiscal austerity and large-scale unemployment, will fuel a new wave of popular protests. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. The competition for global leadership between China and the US will intensify as a result of the crisis, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other regions. This will provide a challenging environment for Latin America over the medium term as the region tries to grapple with the debt overhang from the extra spending measures and the hit to revenue, as well as lower potential growth rates, owing to the damage to productive sector value chains, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect a further decline, of 25.4%, in 2020. The contraction will follow the steep drop in crude prices and reflect the adverse effects of the government's quarantine measures, which-even if only partly followed-will further dent domestic demand. Ultra-low oil prices will hamper production, but most importantly, they will indirectly hit the non-oil economy through shortages of fuel and public services, scarcity of goods and reinvigorated hyperinflation. From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes and continued mass emigration (which is fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability).
The recent collapse in oil prices will put significant pressure on Venezuela to slash crude production. The country's average break-even price is about US$15-US$20/barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is selling its oil at a loss (its oil basket reached US$15/b at end-April). Although the country seeks to produce as much oil as possible, the current circumstances will inevitably lead to cuts in production; we expect oil output to decline from 660,000 barrels/day (b/d) in March (according to OPEC), to 620,000 b/d on average in 2020. However, we believe that average output could fall as low as 500,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2021 we expect the economy to grow marginally, owing to a stabilisation of oil output, base effects and the lifting of social-distancing measures. In 2022 economic growth will accelerate on the back of a surge in oil prices. However, in the medium term, oil output will continue to fall-albeit gradually-owing to serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and to a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude. Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24 (owing to moderately higher global oil prices), as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout the forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Oil sector: With proven levels approaching 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the largest reserves in the world, making it a major oil producer and exporter. However, the energy sector has suffered from disinvestment and mis-management owing to political interference. The state is accorded exclusive ownership of PDVSA and its subsidiaries. Since 2007, oil exploration, extraction and storage activities have been reserved for state-owned enterprises or companies in which the state holds a stake of at least 60%.
The latest PDVSA data put oil output at an average of 2.6m b/d in 2016, while OPEC estimates it at 2.2m, in line with data from the International Energy Agency (IEA). However, in early 2019 Venezuela's oil output fell drastically as nationwide blackouts and US sanctions have taken further toll on a sector decimated by corruption, underinvestment and mismanagement. Production stabilised at an average of 860,000 b/d in 2019, according to estimates from the IEA. However, oil production fell further in March-April 2020, as the coronavirus pandemic resulted in a collapse in global oil demand and a significant price decline. Oil output fell to 622,000 b/d according to OPEC, compared with 760,000 b/d in February. Official data are not available, but production estimates suggest that joint ventures with foreign investors have kept output from dropping further. As joint ventures deal predominately in heavy and extra-heavy oil, and as production of lighter oil is collapsing, PDVSA has been forced to import more diluents from abroad. Existing US sanctions have complicated their import, and have led Venezuela to rely further on blending its heavier crude with ones of a lighter grade to produce crudes to the liking of Venezuela's new main buyer-Asian markets. In early 2020, Russian energy firm Rosneft sold all of its Venezuelan assets in the face of US sanctions on the company. Although the assets were sold to another Russian firm, the support previously given to PDVSA will undoubtedly dwindle. Furthermore, the US announced that US oil firm Chevron will be forced to halt operations in Venezuela by end-2020. Additional measures such as these from the US will put further pressure on PDVSA this year (particularly if international prices remain at ultra-low levels).
PDVSA's main joint-venture partners are Russian firms (Gazprom, Lukoil and Rosneft), CNPC (the Chinese state oil company), Chevron and Eni (Italy). The government has shown a preference for Russian and Chinese firms, but even co-operation with these partners has reportedly been rocky at times, given (among other things) pervasive corruption at PDVSA, complex regulatory and planning requirements, difficulties securing foreign exchange to afford production imports, and criminality in areas surrounding at oil production and refining facilities.
Dwindling production and a punishing debt redemption schedule have stretched PDVSA's financing to its limits. At present, PDVSA is in arrears on all of its debt, including its 2020 bond. The latter security included 50% of Citgo, a PDVSA subsidiary, as collateral, and PDVSA's default has thus opened the door for creditors to seek the liquidation of Citgo's assets. The US Treasury has so far banned the seizure of Citgo's assets as the company is under Mr Guaidó's purview. Citgo traditionally has been a vital part of PDVSA's operations, as it refines and commercialises Venezuelan oil in the US-historically PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. Through the US Treasury's actions, the hope is that Citgo will remain an important government asset in any future administration.
Given the challenges arising from PDVSA's financial difficulties and perennial mismanagement, as well as US sanctions, the ongoing decline in output is irreversible for as long as the present regime remains in power. Seizure of Citgo's assets is likely as the Treasury will lift their bans if Mr Guaidó's claim for the presidency loses its legitimacy claim. With the prospect of further sanctions, oil output will remain volatility throughout 2020. Given PDVSA's inability to afford required new investment to ramp up production, the company could hand more of its operations to Russian and Chinse firms. However, prospects for structural overhauls to the current framework remain highly uncertain.

Severely reduced domestic supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will lead to a return to hyperinflation this year. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit helped to subdue hyperinflation in the second half of 2019. However, inflationary pressures will intensify substantially in the coming months, owing to wide-spread goods shortages, the re-introduction of price controls on a number of goods and the ramping-up of government money printing. In the medium term, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.

Accelerating hyperinflation will quicken the pace of bolívar depreciation in 2020. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this context, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On May 6th the official exchange rate was BsS160,150:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS178,500:US$1. The premium (currently at 5.5%) is small by historical comparison.

Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 2.2% of GDP in 2020, owing to lower oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019). We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 5.9% of GDP in 2022-24. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Venezuela Stocks and flows According to the IMF (whose figures differ somewhat from local sources), the stock of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Venezuela stood at US$30.1bn in 2016, the last year in which actual data have been provided. This is around one-third less than a peak of US$48.9bn in 2007 and is primarily the result of significant disinvestment, notwithstanding the government's long-standing capital controls. Given the massive decline in GDP in recent years, this means that the FDI stock is estimated at 27.4% of GDP in 2019 (forecast to rise to 49.3% of GDP this year, as GDP contracts further). Overall, FDI inflows have been very volatile in the past 20 years, affected by both political and macroeconomic factors. During the oil opening of 1996-98, inward FDI peaked at an annual average of US$4.5bn per year. By historical standards, inward FDI held up well in the first three years of the presidency of Hugo Chávez (1999-2003), averaging US$3.8bn per year in 1999-2001. As political conflict intensified, FDI inflows began to decline in 2002-08 (averaging US$1.8bn per year), and in 2009-a year of great volatility in the world economy and adverse domestic developments in Venezuela-the country registered disinvestment of US$1.1bn (some negative inflows were also the result of compensation for nationalisations). Inward FDI has recovered afterwards, averaging an estimated US$4.3bn per year in 2011-13, because of greater investment from China in energy and housing. It declined considerably afterwards, to US$1.9bn per year in 2014-16, likely as a reflection of both sliding international oil prices and foreign investors' increasing disillusionment with the government's inability to comply with investment agreements and manage the economy. Outbound FDI in Venezuela is considerable, reaching a stock of US$32.7bn in 2016. However, this tally is dominated by investments abroad by PDVSA, the state oil company.
Origin and distribution The energy sector, and oil in particular, remains the main magnet for FDI. US and European oil companies have major investments in the country, even after forced changes to the ownership structure of most contracts. After oil, banking and communications have been the main recipients of FDI. Spanish banks have the largest foreign presence in the financial sector, although the Venezuelan state has bought back some operations. Other notable FDI inflows come from Chile (in forestry activities) and Canada (in the mining industry). Owing to expanding US sanctions and restrictions, Venezuela has courted new investment partners in China, Russia and Iran, with limited success. The fact that these countries will continue to grapple with the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) throughout 2020 means that short-term efforts will be focused on seeking support on the oil and defence sectors.
Determinants Following a period of booming FDI inflows in the 1990s, driven by oil and telecommunications openings, an uncertain political and policy environment-including threats of nationalisation-and a volatile macroeconomic climate have served to keep FDI well below potential, particularly in the non-extractive sectors. In the extractive sector, FDI inflows have been affected by the government's restrictive hydrocarbons investment regime, which mandates that PDVSA must hold a minimum 60% stake in the oil and gas sector, and levies high taxes and royalties on private partners. The vast reserves of extra-heavy oil in the Orinoco Belt require substantial technical know-how and massive investment to be put to production, an environment where major oil companies would thrive. Many major companies are already present via joint ventures or were already present before nationalisation drives. Venezuela's oil sector will continue to be a major draw to FDI under more sustainable economic and regulatory policies.
Impact Foreign investment in oil brought accelerated growth in output, from 2.4m barrels/day (b/d) in 1994 to a peak of 3.4m b/d in 1999. Foreign investment in the extractive sector has fallen since then, contributing to a decline in oil output, reinforced by PDVSA's inability to drive production. Foreign involvement has had a less dramatic impact in other sectors, such as domestic manufacturing or services, but this in turn has resulted in high levels of import dependence. As FDI has flowed mostly into capital-intensive industries, its impact on employment and skills levels has been limited.
Potential Given the scale of economic mismanagement and poor maintenance of existing infrastructure and productive capacity, there is large potential for investment opportunities in Venezuela. Potentially attractive opportunities for FDI exist in an array of sectors, such as oil and gas, petrochemicals, coal, aluminium, gold, forestry, power, tourism, and telecoms. There is additional potential in some manufacturing and agricultural niches (for example, leather goods, cocoa and rum). However, FDI inflows will be severely curtailed by concerns over the current government's policy stance, difficulties in accessing foreign exchange, the weak macroeconomic environment and the fragility of the legal framework. A recovery in investment is unlikely under the leader of the regime, Nicolás Maduro, as exchange-rate distortions and controls local prices will remain unaddressed. A more noticeable upturn in FDI inflows will have to wait until after a political transition takes place and only if the new government were to engage in structural economic reforms.

As long as the current regime is in place, mass emigration will continue. Population growth will remain weak because of a falling birth rate and large-scale emigration. The annual population growth rate has been steadily decreasing from 2.8% in the 1980s to 2.3% in the 1990s and 1.8% in 2000-10. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the population declined by an average of 2.1% per year in 2015-19, as the economic crisis worsened. The UN High Commission for Refugees estimates that some 5.1m Venezuelans have left the country since 2014, with approximately 1.8m residing in neighbouring Colombia. The economic impact of the quarantine measures-applied by countries in the region to combat the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic-has affected earnings of Venezuelans abroad. Some are even returning to Venezuela-reportedly over 50,000 have come back from Colombia since April 2020. However, the inversion in migration flows will be short-lived. Regional economies will gradually reopen during 2020. This, together with a lack of employment and goods shortages at home, will cause migrants to continue leaving Venezuela. Therefore, our estimates for population growth in the 2020-24 forecast period assume that outward migration will continue. The total population is expected to reach 27.2m by 2024 (from an estimated peak of 30.9m in 2016), with just over one-quarter of the population under the age of 14 and two-thirds of the population between 15 and 64 years of age. Population density is low, at 34 people/sq km as per official estimates from 2017. Distribution between urban and rural areas is highly uneven, with about 90% of the total population living in urban centres. Underdeveloped rural infrastructure and limited job opportunities in the countryside will result in a continuing trend of urbanisation in 2020-24.
The labour participation rate declined in 2004-12 (owing to an increased uptake of education linked to the government's social programmes), but ticked up marginally in 2013 and 2014, before falling again in 2015 as economic conditions worsened because job seekers became discouraged. The government has stopped producing labour data, but we expect that continued economic contraction and diminishing real wages (we estimate that, in real terms, the minimum wage plus food vouchers has lost over 99% of its value since mid-2013) have driven participation down further. Participation rates will remain subdued in 2020-24. A very poor business environment, economic malaise and extremely restrictive labour regulation will continue to limit job creation, forcing more people to depend on the informal sector, which is already estimated to account for more than half of employment. According to the authorities, the official unemployment rate fell from 8.5% in 2010 to 6.8% in 2015. However, given that this coincided with a sharp deterioration in local economic conditions, it is likely that it reflects inflexible labour laws (which make it virtually impossible to lay off workers) rather than any significant job creation. It is also possible that the data are unreliable, as it is highly implausible that unemployment has remained low in the midst of a deep economic recession, with a growing number of companies folding.
Poverty indicators improved during the tenure of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but these data are no longer published by the authorities. Independent academic sources estimate that poverty rates have risen sharply in the context of collapsing economic activity and hyperinflation. A study by three well-regarded universities estimated the poverty rate at 87% in 2017. Shortages of medicines and surgical supplies are creating huge problems in the healthcare system, while insufficient vaccines are resulting in the re-emergence of diseases that had previously been practically eradicated.
Public services will remain under strain from a lack of resources The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards but, in the context of volatile public finances, population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily burdened social security system. Public hospitals will continue to suffer from crumbling infrastructure, and a lack of supplies (including medicines) and equipment. The latter are mainly imported, or assembled from imported parts, and supplies have fallen victim to a lack of US dollars. Hospital building and rebuilding programmes have been a failure, owing to mismanagement of funds and shortages of building materials. Even a parallel welfare system, the Sistema Nacional de Misiones, is struggling to function as the government makes cuts and inflation erodes purchasing power. Overall, the provision and quality of public healthcare and education services is therefore expected to deteriorate further. The coronavirus pandemic will exacerbate these fragilities. This will also reflect long-running problems, including a pronounced deficit of technical and basic skills, and the continued emigration of professionals (particularly doctors and nurses).

The scale of Venezuela's economic crisis has led to a rapid decline in living standards, with GDP per head falling by over two-thirds, from a peak of US$12,291 in 2012, to an estimated US$3,933 in 2019. Estimates using purchasing power parity (PPP) give a higher figure of US$5,994. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a further decline in both GDP per head at market exchange rates and PPP by 2023, based on our expectation for the leader of the regime, Nicolás Maduro, to cling onto power during the 2020-24 forecast period, given that the country's severe economic imbalances will remain unaddressed.
Several factors will restrict purchasing power, including hyperinflation, and persistently high levels of poverty and income inequality. Although national statistics show a dramatic improvement in social indicators in recent years, the data have been disputed; independent studies have suggested that inequality has not fallen as quickly as the government indicates, and that the middle-income class has shrunk. According to the UN Human Development Programme, 6.6% of the population survived on less than US$1.25/day (in purchasing-power terms) in 2012, a higher proportion than in almost any other country in the region.
Investment potential will only be tapped after a political transition Venezuela is a reasonably sized consumer market and has the potential to become an attractive investment location. However, any benefits from this will not materialise until a more market-friendly administration takes over (not our baseline forecast). The country has vast reserves of natural resources (including oil, gas, coal and precious metals), an array of spectacular natural tourist attractions, relatively good physical infrastructure and a fairly favourable geographical location-given its proximity to the US. However, poor economic policies have contributed to a volatile GDP profile, and a deterioration of public services and human capital over the past two decades. The unattractiveness of the business environment is compounded by inadequate contract and property rights. Moreover, continued high poverty levels and a deterioration in health-care and education provision in the past three decades have contributed to an erosion of skills and productivity, which has also been exacerbated by an exodus of talented individuals to work abroad.

A weakened productive base will lead to recurrent shortages of goods In common with the rest of the Latin American region, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure, and this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. Sharp growth in mobile-telephone usage, and an underdeveloped urban public transport system and subsidised petrol are the main factors behind the relatively heavy weighting of expenditure on transport and communications. Most consumer goods industries will remain underdeveloped, owing to government controls and the country's severely damaged productive capacity. Furthermore, limited availability of foreign exchange has resulted in a scarcity of consumer goods that are not produced domestically. Looking forward, the scale of the country's ongoing recession will lead to major contractions in retail-sales volumes during the forecast period.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that the leader of the regime, Nicolás Maduro, will retain power in the short to medium term, we expect successive governments in the longer term to put forth structural reforms to the oil sector and to make limited inroads in diversifying the economy. We therefore anticipate that Venezuela's real GDP per head will contract by an average of 0.1% in 2020-30 (this figure is also influenced by major contractions in 2018-20). Growth will average a healthier 2.9% in 2031-50, but the country's population is unlikely to reach a high standard of living within the forecast period. Indeed, by 2050 we forecast that per-head GDP at purchasing power parity will be US$18,100-a low value for a country with Venezuela's endow-ment of national resources. Although we expect the business environment to improve, the country's weak institutions, dependency on the extractive industry and a weak productive base will remain significant barriers to growth.
The macroeconomic collapse will impair the long-term productivity capacity Initial conditions: After averaging growth of 10% in 2004-08, real GDP fell sharply in 2009-10. Although the economy recovered in 2011-12 on the back of aggressive fiscal spending, growth slowed sharply again in 2013, with the economy slipping into a deepening recession in late 2014. We estimate that by the time the economy returns to growth in 2021, real GDP will have fallen by almost 75%, making the recession the country's most severe since compilation of national statistics data began. The heterodox policy framework that has been in place for over a decade has been a major factor in hampering GDP growth, while an opaque and distorted exchange-rate system has provided opportunities for corruption on a large scale, further undermining the institutional framework and maintaining income inequality. In addition, institutional deterioration is very deep-rooted and will prove harder to reverse. On a more positive note, a higher skills base and reasonably good road infrastructure by regional standards provide scope for faster overall growth and a rise in personal incomes. Nevertheless, underinvestment in human capital and infrastructure, as well as the emigration of most skilled labour, is eroding these advantages and, given fiscal difficulties, this trend will take time to reverse. Successive governments have failed to take advantage of Venezuela's proximity to developed US and European markets relative to its South American neighbours, as internal geography and a lack of investment in infrastructure in the interior have limited Venezuela's chances of becoming a regional hub for transport and commerce.
Demographic trends: As in most other emerging-market countries, growth in the working-age population will slow in the long term, while rising partici-pation rates will ensure that the labour force will grow at a brisker pace. Venezuela will continue to enjoy supportive population dynamics, with the dependency ratio of old to young low by comparison to OECD levels even in 2050. Even with life expectancy growing steadily, the share of the population aged 65 years and over will be only around 15% in 2050 (although rising from an estimated 6.6% in 2017), while the share of the population at working age will remain high, at 66%. A particular risk to productivity is the "brain drain" seen in recent years, as many experienced professionals have left the country to work abroad with no guarantee of returning.
Oil will remain crucial to Venezuela's economic prospects External conditions: Oil, which we estimate accounts for some 95% of export revenue at present, will continue to dominate the Venezuelan economy. Although there will be a limited drive to diversify the productive base in the long term, Venezuela will continue to be highly dependant on exports of oil and other commodities. During the eras of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013) and Mr Maduro, Venezuela and its allies have taken a confrontational stance against US policy and US-led efforts at economic integration. In the medium term, we expect Venezuela to continue to rely very heavily on oil and extractive industries, and to strengthen economic links with Asian markets and with existing political allies (Russia, Turkey, Iran, etc). In the longer term, however, we assume that successive governments will implement a number of structural economic and political reforms, which will allow Venezuela to somewhat diversify away from oil, and trade with the US will revivify.
Institutions and policy trends: We assume that some of the most distortionary elements of the current policy framework, including price and exchange controls, will be scaled back gradually as the regime deems their removal as essentially for their survival. However, the prospects for improvements in other aspects of the business environment are very low, as structural microeconomic reforms will not be forthcoming. For example, an improvement of the public finances will prove unfeasible unless international crude prices reach pre-2014 levels. Given that the economy will still be highly vulnerable to oil price fluctuations, the fiscal position will remain highly procyclical. Reforms to social security or labour legislation will only be possible under a potential new administration. In 2031-50 we assume that successive administrations will yield policy improvements; however, their effects will be slow to materialise given the country's institutional weakness.
Economic growth will only accelerate in the long term after structural reforms Long-term performance: Even once the most distortionary elements of current economic policy are abandoned, the deterioration of the skills base over the past decade will mean that Venezuela's potential GDP growth will have been eroded, although there is still some scope for recovery in 2021-40, when growth will average a respectable 4%. It will then slow down to an average of 3.1% in 2041-50. A higher trend rate of GDP growth will be possible in the long term under more market-friendly successive administrations, which we expect to go ahead with reforms to the country's long-standing economic and political policies. The overall economy will remain vulnerable to continuing cycles of boom and bust, with negative consequences for macroeconomic stability and growth, and constraining the prospects for catch-up with more developed economies, despite some solid projected growth late in the forecast period.
