From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Venezuela is vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change, owing to both geographical limitations and the government's inadequate focus on preparedness. Venezuela is deemed extremely vulnerable to climate change, given its population distribution along coastal lines on unstable terrains. About 75% of the country's population is estimated to live in the 20% of the territory facing the Caribbean Sea. Given low maintenance of infrastructure and little disaster preparedness, the population centres there are exposed to torrential rains, mudslides and flash floods. According to a recent study by a local and internationally recognised expert, Juan Carlos Sanchez, even within established rainfall patterns, variance has resulted in the growing number of extreme events per year in the past decade. Longer-term trends in rainfall will also affect the country. A study performed by the Universidad Simón Bolívar, a well-regarded university, has concluded that rainfall in the northwest of the country could fall by 25% by 2060. This would not only cause internal migration, but would also drive the country into further food insecurity (Venezuela is already heavily reliant on imports of foodstuffs). In addition, changing rain patterns may disrupt hydroelectricity generation, a major problem given that this represents more than 50% of the country's electricity.
The government has done little to address these challenges. Its public works programmes concentrate on traditional infrastructure projects and there is minimal focus in the way of disaster preparedness. In a recent forum with a UN delegation, authorities touted their plans to build apartment blocks in place of shantytowns, the logic being that concrete buildings would hold up to flooding better. There is scarce official data on carbon emissions or pollution in the country, but environmental policies are generally deemed poor by specialised observers. PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, has been routinely accused of poor environmental protection in both its oil and gas operations. The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Venezuelan economy will be 4% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Migration and urbanisation Venezuela experienced rapid urbanisation through the majority of the second half of the 20th century, as the country's oil wealth was developed. According to data from the World Bank, the percentage of urban population grew from 60% in 1960 to almost 90% by the late 1990s-high by global standards but in line with most large Latin American countries. Oil exports, especially at the start of this process, funded large-scale real estate developments and infrastructure works in budding urban centres, attracting prospective workers from the countryside. In addition to a growing middle class fed by spill-over from the country's oil wealth, the rural exodus towards the cities also created sprawling shantytowns across major metropolises, which public-housing programmes have been unable to eradicate. Income inequality in urban centres is especially acute, feeding crime and political tension. This is perhaps best exemplified by Caracas, the capital, where income and wealth disparities have correlated with voter preferences for the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) and opposition parties.
Emigration, previously a limited phenomenon, has become a major issue. No official data exist, but out of a total population of about 31m, local estimates put total emigration since 2013 at 5.1m people, with most having left in the past three years. These migrants were initially primarily driven by political reasons, but the exodus is also driven by criminal violence (Venezuela has one of the world's highest murder rates) and woeful economic conditions. Anecdotal evidence suggests that those leaving have been primarily young, well-trained professionals, which has harmed the economy's prospects further. Under our expectation of no political transition, outward migration is set to continue (albeit at smaller rates than in 2018-20). Skilled workers in particular will seek to move abroad, further dampening Venezuela's long-term growth potential.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated

US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits

External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV

Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+India&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+India+May+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-05-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+India&amp;rft.issn=09668829&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the current government to serve out its second term, which will expire in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration. The administration's Hindu nationalistic agenda could raise the incidence of communal violence.
- The government has extended a nationwide lockdown until May 3rd, to contain the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19). Some of the measures under the lockdown have been relaxed since April 20th. We maintain our view that the spread of the virus will be brought under control by June, although the World Health Organisation has warned that the premature lifting of containment measures is likely to cause a renewed spike in new cases.
- India's relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24. However, disagreements on tariff and service-sector export restrictions will limit trade deals. Relations with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's ambitions in South Asia. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in 2020/21 (April-March), as the government will fall short on revenue income and launches stimulus to keep households and firms afloat during the lockdown. It will narrow but still remain wide during the remainder of the forecast period.
- We expect the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will cut interest rates by another 75 basis points in the remainder of 2020. The RBI will also tweak its policy tools and regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of accommodative monetary policy.
- Real GDP growth will slump to 0.3% in 2020/21, down from an estimated 4.9% in 2019/20. The recovery will be sluggish, we expect the economy to grow by an annual average of 5.8% in 2021/22-2024/25.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs74.8:US$1. The currency will r emain weak in 2022-24, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and rising domestic inflation.
- The trade deficit will narrow in 2020 amid low global oil prices. It will widen from 2021 as India increases imports of capital goods. Business outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score improves over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies in 2021.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or merger and acquisition activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The government's policy towards foreign direct investment will remain ambiguous. Some firms face a lengthy approval process.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: The country remains reluctant to join major regional trade deals.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands. Tax breaks and rebates are made available to businesses and individuals affected by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the GST.
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks and non-bank financial companies (NBFC), raising risks to banking-sector stability but improving the funding availability for corporates.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad debt issues persist in public-sector banks. Major consolidation and privatisations within the public-sector banks will continue.
The labour market 2020-21: Unemployment soars because of the lockdown. The government expands rural employment guarantee schemes.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at the central government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation to healthcare facility projects, in response to the coronavirus outbreak.
2022-24: The construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by Asia standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or by purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's domination of the central government during its term, which ends in 2024.
The results of the 2019 election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts, the most prominent being the national security adviser, Ajit Doval. We believe that the PMO and Mr Doval will continue to set the policy agenda until the next election. The lockdown measures, introduced on March 25th, have been welcomed by the public as an effective measure to halt the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19). Mr Modi will continue to enjoy the relatively high popularity ratings, but a prolonged bout of containment measures that lasts for months could damage his reputation. State governments have largely followed the directives of the central government, although some have opted for stricter containment measures.
Assuming that spread of the coronavirus is contained by mid-year, social unrest will pose a threat to political stability during the remainder of the forecast period. Clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups, notably Muslims. Violent protests are continuing across India following the enactment in December of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019, with some fearing that the change will erode secularism and others concerned about unchecked immigration. State governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, although some may not implement the changes to the citizenship law.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a key concern in 2020-21. The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state sparked protests. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders, further unrest cannot be ruled out. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shutdowns, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be on gauging support for the BJP in the state assembly elections. However, the results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important. We believe that the BJP will perform poorly in the state election in Bihar later in the year.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half the total number of seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of a few more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) could secure a simple majority in the upper house. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan will be exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August 2019 to revoke the special status granted to J&K. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
The US president, Donald Trump, visited India in February 2020. India and the US have affirmed further co-operation on defence policy and confirmed a military equipment purchase. However, they failed to reach even a limited trade deal, owing to disagreements on India's tariff collection and restrictions on service sector exports by the US. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence.
China's sway in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. A decision on April 18th to subject all direct investment from China to a lengthy approval process has triggered blowback from China, although we don't expect any immediate retaliation. Despite attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the economic policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. The key near-term priority for the administration is to contain the development of the coronavirus outbreak, to which India is particularly vulnerable, given its large population and weak healthcare infrastructure. The government's approach will include effectively quarantining the country (a lockdown from March 25th to May 3rd), enhancing the capacity of the healthcare system and ratifying a stimulus plan to bolster the economy. The government delivered a first stimulus-relief package targeted at low-income groups on March 26th, which included direct cash transfers and food giveaways. A fiscal relief package for businesses will also be forthcoming. Incentives will be offered to labour-intensive sectors and special allowance given to service sectors that are heavily impacted by the closure of businesses, including transportation and hospitality. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will also extend liquidity support.
The government's broader policy agenda will be put on the back burner, at least in 2020. It is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements and a modest liberalisation of foreign investment, could be undertaken. Nevertheless, we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging. The lockdown will amplify the mounting non-performing loan (NPL) issues in the banking sector. The risk of a systemic failure of banks is not negligible.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National infrastructure Pipeline-remain a priority, partly in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and partly to boost the business environment. In light of the coronavirus outbreak, healthcare facilities will become another focus of government investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The coronavirus outbreak will force the government to rewrite its approved budget for 2020/21, which was conservatively expansionary. It is likely to temporarily suspend the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act to allow for more flexibility in terms of supporting the economy. The extension of the lockdown will probably prompt an unbudgeted increase in social spending programmes, especially the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, as well as an extension of existing financial support schemes for businesses. As a result, the budget deficit will widen to the equivalent of 6.1% of GDP in 2020/21.
Lockdown policies and the demands of healthcare provision mean that the government will implement relatively aggressive fiscal stimulus. Measures will include a direct cash-transfer initiative to households. Social spending will be expanded significantly amid the extended lockdown. Further plans include an infrastructure development programme and tax break for businesses. These measures will go alongside reforms included in the approved budget, such as the simplification of income tax for individuals in certain income groups and the abolition of the dividend distribution tax.
As the economy recovers, the government will look to gradually consolidate the public finances. This will lead to a narrowing of the budget deficit to the equivalent of 5.2% of GDP in 2021/22. The authorities will look to deepen the tax base and increase low levels of tax compliance. However, the need to support welfare payments and infrastructure spending will keep upward pressure on fiscal expenditure. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive, small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits of several state governments. The deep deficits in some states, such as Himachal Pradesh, will present implicit liabilities for the central government.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The coronavirus epidemic will prompt further monetary policy loosening by the RBI. The central bank has lowered its policy repo rate by 75 basis points to 4.4%, as well as widened the monetary policy corridor by lowering the reverse repo rate (the "floor" of the corridor) by 115 basis points, to 3.75%. With inflationary pressures moderating and economic growth under strong near-term downward pressure, we now expect further 75-basis-points reduction in the policy repo rate during the remainder of 2020/21. We also expect the adoption of more unconventional policy instruments. This will include cuts to the reserve cash ratio, long-term refinancing operations and a moratorium, of three months initially, on all term loan repayments.
These measures aim to support businesses as the coronavirus pandemic supresses household spending and business investment. However, the outcome might be far from satisfying. The transmission from monetary policy rate to actual lending is not so smooth, as the banks are also reluctant to lend. Also, the informal sector cannot lend from normal financial institutions and, therefore, will be hard to benefit from these policies. The level of non-performing assets in the financial sector is alarming, and the coronavirus outbreak may amplify the issue, with more firms forced out of business. The government might have to recapitalise the banks through rescue mergers with public-sector banks, or even directly nationalise the stressed banks.
The RBI has maintained inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-has complicated these objectives.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth The coronavirus outbreak will take a significant toll on India's economy. A near six-week long nationwide lockdown period, with factories and office buildings closed, will remove a significant proportion of economic activity. A loss of income, corporate bankruptcy and a jump in unemployment will affect household spending and business investment beyond the lockdown. Following the extension of the containment measures and the fact these were stricter than we originally envisaged, we now expect real GDP growth to slow to 0.3% in 2020/21, compared with growth of 2.1% previously. Expansion of this level would be the lowest since 1991. The economy will contract (on a year-on-year basis) in the first half of 2020/21 (April-September), before mounting a recovery in the second half of the year as the coronavirus outbreak comes under greater control and the global economy recovers.
On a GDP expenditure basis, we now expect private consumption to contract at a faster pace, as people are unable to consume as much during an extended period. Investment spending is now expected to decline at a faster pace as well. We maintain our view that the government will continue to bolster the economy through government expenditure, but the effect will be limited. We expect both exports and imports to fall as the global economy slips into recession.
Real GDP growth is expected to rebound sharply in 2o21/22, but headline forecast of 6% will be somewhat exaggerated by a low base of comparison in the April-June quarter of this year. An anticipated tightening of monetary policy in 2022-23 will also weigh on sentiment. Over the long term, progress on structural reforms will be too slow to give real GDP a significant boost.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 3.4% in 2020 as a whole, compared with 3.7% in 2019. Food price has fallen significantly in the wake of strong harvests. The coronavirus outbreak will lead to significant drop in demand, and therefore prices for services at least will fall gradually. Price pressures will recover gradually from the second half of this year, as the lack of labour during the next harvesting season weighs on overall food prices, and household demand recovers gradually. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
The RBI will keep its policy rate unchanged in 2021 to bolster the recovery. The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in 2022 will offset the inflationary impact of strengthening oil prices. The central bank will accord higher priority to containing inflationary pressures towards the end of the forecast period; consumer price inflation is expected at 4.4% in 2024.
Low oil prices and low domestic demand in 2020 will cause producer price inflation to decline by 0.2% in the year. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.7% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2019, along with high political risks associated with the removal of J&K's special constitutional status and changes to the citizenship law, have weighed on the exchange rate. The coronavirus outbreak has amplified such pressures. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate by 5.9% on an annual average basis, to Rs74.8:US$1 in 2020, as investors flee to safe-haven assets and the domestic economic situation worsens.
In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly, to an average of Rs72.7:US$1, as investor confidence returns. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-24 amid rising oil prices and persistent current-account deficit.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The lower oil price and weaker domestic demand will contribute to a narrowing of India's current-account deficit in 2020, when it is forecast to stand at the equivalent of 0.4% of GDP. Merchandise export growth will be depressed by disruptions caused by the outbreak of the coronavirus globally in the year, but is expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in global commerce. In the longer term, India's export manufacturing sector will still be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology (IT). Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit in the remainder of the forecast period.
The coronavirus outbreak will weigh on inward investment in 2020. Inward direct investment will recover in 2021-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses.

Full text: - The unfolding economic crisis stemming from the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak will complicate policymaking for the remainder of the term of the president, Lenín Moreno, which ends in May 2021. Commitment to fiscal discipline in the face of a deteriorating macroeconomic environment will embolden political opposition to the government ahead of presidential and legislative elections in February 2021, and will raise the risk of social unrest. Irrespective of the election outcome, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects sizeable barriers to governing and to stability to persist, considering the highly fragmented political landscape. Assuming that a centrist government is elected, these headwinds will hamper piecemeal liberalising economic reforms.
- Ecuador is one of the smallest markets in our business environment rankings. The country's mineral reserves will continue to attract oil and mining investors, but the domestic market will grow only slightly as it struggles to recover from the recession engendered by the coronavirus outbreak. We forecast that GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will rise only marginally in 2021-24, after falling by about 7% in 2020, but will remain below its 2019 level of $6,206. As such, business opportunities will remain restricted by low purchasing power, as well as by a small market size.
- Under the auspices of the IMF, the government will cut public spending and investment to shore up the public finances. Despite a statistical rebound in real GDP in 2021, the country's short-term growth prospects will be curbed by soft oil prices, which will also weigh on the fiscal and external accounts. Notwithstanding political and economic uncertainties, we expect dollarisation to be maintained in the 2020-24 forecast period, as it remains popular for delivering macroeconomic stability and for taming inflation.
- Population growth is slowing, owing to a falling birth rate and continued emigration (albeit at lower levels). However, at an annual average of 1.3% per year in 2020-24, population growth will be on a par with that of neighbouring Andean nations. The unemployment rate will average 5% in 2020-24 but underemployment will remain high. The informal sector will remain substantial, partly owing to labour market rigidities. Although low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador to catch up with more developed countries, poor prospects for institutional improvements are likely to preclude a stable economic policy direction. We forecast that income will continue to lag OECD levels in the long term.

- Ecuador scores poorly in our business environment rankings, owing to its dependence on oil and the current administration's timid embrace of orthodox policymaking. Although the country's score improves slightly in the forecast period, its global ranking remains low. The government will seek more private investment, but structural shortcomings in the investment environment will not be fully addressed, hindering investors' perceptions.

Country forecast overview: Ecuador's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Fuel subsidies are gradually, albeit not completely, rolled back in targeted manner. Implementation of antitrust policies is subject to politicisation. Select industries (such as mining) benefit from policies promoting supply-side growth.
2022-24: Government continues to scale back state's role in development. Nonetheless, regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector firms. A new public-private partnership model is trialled.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Overtures to foreign firms and pro-business reforms partly offset the government's continual interventionism.
2022-24: Inadequate property-rights protection and questions regarding access to foreign arbitration deter investment. New mining projects attract investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Government maintains capital outflows tax and increases import tariffs to protect dollarisation.
2022-24: Supply-side reforms enhance national competitiveness and government begins to phase out capital outflows tax.
Taxes 2020-21: Government implements tax reform to expand tax base and improve collection. Certain exemptions will be eliminated, while other burdensome regulations are simplified.
2022-24: Efforts continue to increase tax collection, supporting revenue growth. Tax system remains complex.
Financing 2020-21: Deposit and credit growth are moderate and support banking stability.
2022-24: Financing is still below potential as public-financing needs curb growth of long-term lending to private sector.
The labour market 2020-21: Government takes steps to reduce public-wage bill and reduce labour market rigidities.
2022-24: Quality of workforce remains poor. Labour reforms are slow to take effect.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Fiscal constraints lead to cancellation of several projects. Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment achieve little success.
2022-24: Renewed interest in port and airport development sustains new cycle of investment.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Investment to expand fourth-generation (4G) broadband availability.
2022-24: Increasing adoption of civic technologies by government. Fifth-generation (5G) technology remains in its infancy.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions remain fragile. External economic shocks have contributed to the ousting of three presidents by popular protest since 1997. The current president, Lenín Moreno, took office in May 2017, succeeding Rafael Correa (2007-17)-the longest-serving president in Ecuadorean history. In February 2018 a series of constitutional reforms introduced by Mr Moreno (including the reintroduction of a two-term limit for the presidency) were approved by referendum. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation, persistent social and fiscal challenges will continue to weigh on governability.
Political structure: The 2008 constitution increased executive power, but has done little to foster institutional capacity to tackle problems such as a politicised judiciary, powerful business lobbies, and mobilised grassroots and indigenous groups. The political system is fragmented. Mr Moreno retains strong executive powers, but his Alianza País lost considerable standing after the results of the 2018 referendum splintered the party.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided macroeconomic stability but exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitiveness. Modest oil prices during the 2020-24 forecast period, relative to the previous decade, have necessitated fiscal adjustments. A three-year IMF agreement (along with other multilateral financing), secured by the Moreno administration in March 2019 after borrowing in international capital markets became unsustainable, will be leveraged to address these shortcomings. The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will complicate the government's economic reform agenda, especially considering its lack of fiscal space to counter the hit to the economy and financial system.
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador recorded an estimated trade surplus of US$1bn in 2019. Weak external demand is likely to preclude a trade surplus in 2020, before an expansion of earnings from oil, banana and shrimp exports support trade surpluses in 2021-24.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic presents the president, Lenín Moreno, with two immense challenges before his term ends in May 2021. First, Mr Moreno must work to contain the spread of the virus with limited resources. Strict national lockdown measures have been in place since mid-March, but have largely been unsuccessful; the virus has spread rapidly, with more than 22,160 cases reported as at April 24th (double the amount reported on April 23rd). Although there is consensus for thorough containment measures and an eventual gradual easing of restrictions, policymaking will be challenging as the crisis deepens; the political landscape is highly fragmented, Mr Moreno lacks a majority-his Alianza País (AP) has 42 seats, 27 short of the threshold-and the February 2021 elections are approaching. The second challenge for the president is to stabilise the economy as oil prices languish, lockdown measures stifle activity and external demand shrinks. With no fiscal space to mount a countercyclical response (Mr Moreno has announced cuts to public spending and submitted tax-raising legislation), the opposition will be emboldened, political instability aggravated and the risk of unrest heightened significantly.
A daily curfew from 2pm to 5am is in effect until early May, although this will be heterogeneous across the country, with an easing of measures directed by mayors of cantons. However, with the economic situation for millions of Ecuadoreans quickly worsening, there is a high probability for protests to occur in the next few months, especially considering that indigenous groups responsible for intense protests in October 2019 have called for a permanent mobilisation against the government.
Commitment to socially unpalatable and politically divisive economic measures will help the government to retain IMF support, but will dissolve support for the president. Mr Moreno has staked his presidency on his economic programme backed by a three-year, US$4.2bn extended fund facility (EFF) with the IMF, and US$6bn in additional multilateral financing (intended to be disbursed between March 2019 and December 2021). On March 23rd, amid the coronavirus outbreak, the administration made Ecuador's second-ever bond repayment. In doing so, the president snubbed a nearly unanimous request from the legislature that external debt payments be suspended, reflecting the governability challenges that the administration faces as it seeks a successor programme to its current IMF arrangement and attempts to advance several reforms to shore up the public finances amid an economic crisis.
Political jockeying will be a constant undercurrent as elections near. Political leaders from across the ideological spectrum will seek to capitalise on the economic crisis and elevate their position. Radical leftist ideals supported by the former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), may return to the fore as the economy deteriorates, despite the fact that Mr Correa was sentenced in absentia to serve eight years in prison in early April. Although it is unlikely that his supporters will re-emerge as the dominant political force, political uncertainties will prevail (rather than dissipate) in the short to medium term, as the economy contracts.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is scheduled for February 2021. We currently assume that the president will serve out the rest of his term. An early termination of Mr Moreno's term (either through his resignation or elections being brought forward) would intensify economic uncertainties and throw the country into political turmoil-outcomes that most parties are keen to avoid. Nevertheless, the presidential election result is nebulous at this stage, owing to obscurity caused by the coronavirus outbreak.
Mr Moreno has signalled that he does not intend to run and, given his government's commitment to unpopular economic measures, it is unlikely that a member of his centre-left AP will secure victory. However, the vice-president, Otto Sonnenholzner, may rise in stature owing to his visibility amid the pandemic. The conservative opposition Partido Social Cristiano (PSC) performed well in municipal elections in March 2019, and is strongly placed to capitalise on the fragmented political landscape and mount a robust campaign. The other major conservative opposition party, Creando Oportunidades led by Guillermo Lasso (who narrowly lost to Mr Moreno in 2017), also may grow in appeal. A candidate backed by Mr Correa could play a significant role in the election, as the government struggles to weather the worsening economic situation. However, even though a Correa-backed candidate may make it to the second round, we believe that Mr Sonnenholzner, a PSC candidate or Mr Lasso are more likely to win. We would expect these administrations to pursue broadly centrist economic policies, and we have based our medium-term forecasts on this assumption.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations The foreign policy agenda of Mr Moreno will remain focused on strengthening diplomatic and commercial ties with major trading partners, mainly the US (Ecuador's largest trading partner). In the short term, the coronavirus pandemic and Ecuador's unfolding economic crisis will overshadow free-trade agreement (FTA) discussions with the US (talks were scheduled to take place in April) and Ecuador's accession to the Pacific Alliance (a regional trade bloc). The latter may also be hindered by the absence of an existing bilateral agreement with Mexico; however, Ecuador and Mexico have ambitiously set February 7th 2021 (the date of general election in Ecuador) as the deadline for an FTA. There is a reasonable chance that Ecuador will enter the bloc by 2024, considering that the presidents within the Pacific Alliance (as well as Mexico's foreign minister) have expressed their support for Ecuador's swift accession to the group. However, the coronavirus pandemic or changes in government and policy direction may yet hinder the accession process.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The coronavirus outbreak will push Ecuador closer to default and a balance-of-payments crisis. Avoiding this will require, more than ever, the support of the IMF (and other actors), but meeting the conditions required to access these funds will be extremely complicated politically, heightening risks in the coming months. Political pressure to loosen fiscal policy and suspend external debt payments is mounting, and will continue to rise, but Mr Moreno will try to maintain fiscal discipline and work to improve the country's credibility with investors, most likely seeking an amicable restructuring of its debt with private creditors, rather than trigger a disorderly default.
Mr Moreno's stance will help to unlock much-needed financial assistance from multilateral development banks and the IMF. The government has requested a US$500m loan through the Fund's Rapid Financing Instrument (RFI) by end-April, which the IMF is considering. Unlike fully fledged IMF programmes, RFIs come with little conditionality, and this should provide the government with some policy leeway considering the circumstances, assuming that the request is approved (we have pencilled the funds into our forecasts). That said, we do not expect a dramatic loosening of policy either, as the government will be hoping that its show of credibility will help it to secure at least US$1bn from China by end-May (which we have also pencilled into our forecasts). New external financing and close collaboration between the government and the IMF will be paramount to navigating the developing crisis in the coming weeks and months, as the government is working to establish a new arrangement with the Fund that builds on the current EFF.
The objectives of the government's IMF-backed economic programme will be overshadowed by the policy response to the economic and health crises. We expect that the government will still pursue labour reform and the removal of fuel subsidies, having stated before the crisis that a gradual and less drastic fuel subsidy reduction would be rolled out by June, but short-term measures to boost health expenditure and to provide support to the economy will take precedence for now.
Assuming that a centre-right or centre-left government takes office in May 2021 (before the final EFF review in December of that year) and provides for policy continuity, we expect that the four primary objectives of the EFF will continue to be prioritised in the medium to long term. These include improving competitiveness, tackling fiscal imbalances, protecting the poor and fighting corruption. Moreover, under our political assumptions and in the light of the unfolding crises, we view IMF assistance beyond 2021 as a highly probable scenario. This suggests a piecemeal advancement of business-friendly policies and complementary reforms in 2021-24. Nonetheless, limited progress will be made in diversifying the economy away from oil (the country left OPEC in January to free itself from quotas).
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The government will have limited success in cushioning the blow to the fiscal accounts from the drastic halt to domestic economic activity and lower oil revenue than previously anticipated in the budget. We thus expect both a widening of the fiscal deficit and a cut in public expenditure, although there are sizeable political risks to the latter in particular. Even assuming that new, extraordinary multilateral and bilateral assistance is forthcoming, this will not be enough to plug the fiscal hole produced by the collapse in oil prices.
On the expenditure side, the government plans to accelerate the downsizing of the state and to reduce spending by US$1.4bn in 2020 to help to offset the fall in revenue from oil sales. Of the US$1.4bn reduction (equivalent to about 1.3% of GDP), US$845m will come from lower spending on goods and services, while US$535m will stem from lower capital expenditure. On the revenue side, the government has submitted legislation to create a "humanitarian assistance fund" totalling nearly US$1bn, which will be financed by progressive contributions of workers who make more than US$500 per month (paid over nine months), and by a contribution of 5% of the profits of companies with profits greater than US$1m (paid over three months). The government's estimated US$2.3bn in fiscal savings is likely to be overly optimistic, considering the government's struggle to dial back spending in recent months and the National Assembly's opposition to increased taxes amid an economic crisis.
On balance, we forecast that the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit will widen to 4.7% of GDP in 2020, assuming that public spending is cut by much less compared with revenue. Public debt as a percentage of GDP will rise from an estimated 45.3% of GDP in 2019 to 52.7% in 2020. The fiscal targets set in the government's EFF are unfeasible-the pace of fiscal adjustment was already slowed at end-2019 in a combined second and third review of the EFF and the fourth review was suspended-and we view as impossible both an improvement of 4 percentage points in the non-oil primary balance/GDP ratio (including subsidies) from 2019 to 2021, and a reduction in the public debt/GDP ratio to 40% by 2024.
The successor IMF agreement being negotiated will shed light on how fiscal targets and fiscal policymaking adapt to the looming economic recession. Irrespective of the changes, programme implementation risks will be glaringly high, as social and political challenges to reforms exceed their pre-crisis levels. Without details on a new deal, and assuming policy continuity, we expect the NFPS deficit to gradually narrow in 2021-24, to about 2% of GDP by 2024, and for the public debt/GDP ratio to stabilise at about 57%. We are cautiously optimistic that that the government will avoid a disorderly default, owing to bilateral and multilateral financing-the government estimates that it will receive about US$2bn from multilateral creditors and China-and prudent debt-management operations. Following a final US$325m payment on the capital of a 10.5%, five-year bond in mid-March, the government successfully launched a consent solicitation in mid-April to defer US$811m in interest payments until August, as its response to the coronavirus outbreak saps its resources. Although it is not yet our baseline forecast, there is a substantial risk that Ecuador will be forced into a debt restructuring this year, or fall into disorderly default ahead of larger payments in the second half of 2020.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy As a dollarised economy, Ecuador lacks independent monetary policy and will not be able to foment a monetary policy response to the emerging economic crisis. Monetary conditions will continue to be largely determined by external factors, but real local rates will remain elevated, owing to Ecuador's high risk premium. Monetary growth will hinge on foreign-exchange inflows, as well as the confidence of domestic lenders, both of which will be markedly undermined by the rapid deterioration of the economy. The threat of de-dollarisation will sustain the risk of capital flight, which raises the risk that preventative measures in the short term are implemented in order to protect domestic liquidity levels.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth We expect real GDP to contract by 6.5% in 2020. Net exports are still likely to contribute positively to growth, despite a marked drop in export volumes; we expect them to decrease by 9.3% as external demand falls markedly, but this drop will be overshadowed by a 16.7% decline in import volumes. The sizeable decline in import volumes reflects a significant deterioration in domestic demand.
Low oil receipts will lead to a retrenchment in government consumption, indirectly feeding through to private consumption, which will be constrained by a worsening labour market. Economic and political uncertainties will weigh on private investment, which will decline for a second consecutive year. Assuming that the coronavirus outbreak is controlled by end-2020-prompting a recovery in external and domestic demand-we expect real GDP growth to rebound in 2021, but it will remain below 2019 levels.
Political uncertainties will be elevated by the February 2021 general election and this will preclude a more robust pick-up in domestic demand. We expect growth to be tepid in 2022, considering the 2021 rebound, but it should slowly improve thereafter as policy uncertainties wane, oil prices rise and moderate improvements to the business environment materialise.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Tumbling commodity prices, weak demand and a strengthening US dollar will produce deflation this year. Consumer prices were flat in 2019, and we expect them to fall by an average of 0.3% this year. We expect inflation to pick up slightly, to an annual average of 0.9% in 2021-24, as import costs rise owing to renewed dollar weakness and an increase in commodity prices. Dollarisation will help to contain inflation, but the economy will remain vulnerable to increases in food and energy prices.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Risks to dollarisation have risen and remain elevated in the short term. The economic crisis presents major problems of financing and liquidity, as oil prices have crashed and access to global financing remains limited. These problems are likely to be compounded by a short-term strengthening of the US dollar (hurting competitiveness) and a dip in reserves.
Nevertheless, we currently assume that dollarisation will be retained in 2020-24, as the government's commitment to its IMF agreement and to fiscal discipline allows for greater multilateral financing. The real effective exchange rate will remain stronger than its long-term, pre-dollarisation average but, in real trade-weighted terms, there will be some depreciation as the US dollar begins to weaken in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The current-account deficit will widen in 2020, as the macroeconomic backdrop deteriorates. Diminishing oil revenue will weigh significantly on the trade balance in the short term, as oil prices languish and external demand withers. Non-oil export earnings will be hit hard, with shrimp and mining exports in particular suffering from domestic restrictions on business operations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus and a retraction of demand in major export markets, including China and the US. Deterioration of the trade balance will be softened by collapsing domestic demand, which will engender import compression. However, remittances are also likely to suffer as economic activity has ground to a halt outside Ecuador, dragging down the current-account deficit. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will pick up in the medium term after suffering in 2020-21, which will preclude a build up in foreign-exchange reserves, but will remain below 1% of GDP.

External debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP public finances, inflation and exchange rate: BCE, 2000 prices
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IFS; covers the general resource account, structural adjustment facilities, enhanced structural adjustment facilities and trust fund loans
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for low- and middle-income urban households, 2004=100
Population: Economist Intelligence Unit estimates, based on results of INEC 2001 census
Public-sector balance: non-financial public sector (NFPS) unless otherwise indicated; BCE, ww.bce.fin.ec
Abbreviations BCE: Banco Central del Ecuador (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
INEC: Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos (the national statistics institute)

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+April+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-04-08&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The re-election of Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, in June 2018 concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Erdogan and his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) to stay in power until 2023 (the next presidential and parliamentary elections), as he will maintain a tight grip on national institutions and the media in order to continue to dominate Turkish politics. However, the loss of mayoral elections in Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul, the commercial capital, in 2019 dealt a heavy blow to the credibility of the president and his party. The coronavirus outbreak in March 2020 could also be destabilising as Mr Erdogan and the AKP struggle to contain the spread of the pandemic.
- Turkey's foreign policy priorities have shifted under the AKP since the early 2000s. Declining trust in the US and the EU, a gradual shift to a multipolar world and an ambition to make Turkey a regional power have all incentivised the AKP to pursue a "Turkey first" approach to foreign policy. Turkey and Russia entered an alliance of convenience following an attempted coup in July 2016. However, relations are under strain over escalating violence in the province of Idlib in north-western Syria, where the two countries back opposing sides.
- We expect the AKP to continue its policy of favouring credit-driven economic growth in lieu of economic rebalancing. Following a recession in 2018 the economy started to recover in 2019, but we expect the coronavirus outbreak and the measures adopted to contain it to disrupt the recovery in 2020 and to weigh heavily on Turkey's public finances. We expect the deficit to widen from 2.9% of GDP in 2019 to 4.5% of GDP in 2020, before narrowing gradually to a still-large 3% of GDP in 2024. Following a real GDP contraction of 3.5% in 2020 we expect the economy to recover gradually, averaging growth of 3.5% per year in 2021-24-well short of the government's annual 5% target.
- Turkey's heavy reliance on often volatile, short-term capital inflows to fund lending and drive economic growth leaves the economy vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment. However, the country's location and its large consumer market make Turkey an attractive place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save. GDP per head (at market exchange rates) is expected to fall to about US$8,000 in 2020, before recovering during the remainder of the forecast period (2020-24), reaching about US$12,500 in 2024.

- Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period, but the country's global ranking has fallen by 12 places, to 56th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, inadequate policy responses to tighter global liquidity conditions and high domestic inflation have raised the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy.

Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Political instability and adverse market conditions, both of which have been exacerbated by the coronavirus outbreak, will delay further privatisation deals.
2022-24: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2022-24: Further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors could boost FDI inflows.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Political tensions with the US will result in further US sanctions and disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2022-24: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes 2020-21: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2022-24: Income-tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced, but evasion remains widespread.
Financing 2020-21: The Central Bank of Turkey will lower interest rates further, despite still relatively high inflation. State banks continue to extend credit to non-financial corporates and households to support economic growth, but bad loans rise sharply.
2022-24: Lending growth to pick up as banking system regains strength and non-performing loan ratio falls. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market 2020-21: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment.
2022-24: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure 2020-21: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2022-24: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2022-24: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election, the presidential system of government was established and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis and the outbreak of the coronavirus in March 2020 are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but discipline has gradually eroded in recent years. Turkey's large external financing needs require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows, especially in periods of risk aversion, but the central bank is under political pressure to lower interest rates, creating uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south-east of the country, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, leading to a resurgence of violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF-led reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2019 goods exports totalled about US$182bn and imports about US$199bn, reducing Turkey's trade deficit to just US$16.6bn, helping to generate a rare current-account surplus of US$8bn (or 1.1% of GDP).
