Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president, and his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) have dominated Turkey's political scene since coming to power in November 2002. During this period they have tightened their grip on authority by replacing Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidential system that has concentrated control in the hands of Mr Erdogan and by clamping down on all forms of political opposition. Mr Erdogan and the AKP suffered a clear blow to their credibility when an opposition candidate, Ekrem Imamoglu, increased his margin of victory over Binali Yildirim of the ruling coalition in the mayoral election rerun in Istanbul (Turkey's largest city) in June 2019. The spread of the coronavirus to Turkey since March 2020 is likely to be politically destabilising as Mr Erdogan and the AKP struggle to contain the outbreak. However, we expect the president to maintain his tight grip on national institutions and the media in order to continue his dominance of Turkish politics. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023 (the next presidential and parlia-mentary elections).
The economy has become less stable in recent years as a result of domestic political tensions, fraught international relations and unorthodox economic policies. This has jeopardised the hard-won improvements in macroeconomic stability on which the AKP built much of its electoral success in the early years of its dominance. The coronavirus outbreak has become a further source of economic instability, as we expect that the pandemic and the measures adopted to contain it will reverse the fragile economic recovery that got under way in 2019 after the 2018 currency crisis and will result in a sharp deterioration in Turkey's public finances.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). Neither the government nor the PKK are interested in reviving peace negotiations, which collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to the levels seen in the 1990s. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the Nationalist Action Party (MHP) will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP).
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president in June 2018, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority-although it secured a coalition majority with the MHP-as the HDP managed to win more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament. The election process appeared to be mostly free, but largely unfair: opposition candidates received little or no media coverage and the government restrained freedom of speech and association.
Local elections took place in March 2019. The AKP and the MHP retained a majority of the national vote. However, the ruling parties lost vital cities such as Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul. Given the public resources that major cities command, Mr Erdogan and the AKP put huge pressure on the Supreme Election Council (YSK) to annul the Istanbul election result. The YSK ordered an election rerun in June 2019, but the opposition candidate still won, and by a larger margin, probably reflecting discontent over Mr Erdogan's tactics.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations An increasingly multipolar world, national security threats, Turkey's suspicion of its traditional Western allies since the attempted coup in July 2016 and the government's ambition to establish the country as a regional power have all contributed to a shift in foreign policy approach. This shift has led to Turkey adopting a more assertive stance with the US and the EU, and establishing closer relations with countries with which it previously had rivalries or limited ties, such as Russia and China. Following the outbreak of the coronavirus, much of Mr Erdogan's energy will be focused on domestic affairs for some time, but the government may be tempted to use foreign policy for domestic political consumption, as it has done in the past, if it struggles to control the spread of the pandemic in Turkey.
Turkey and Russia entered an alliance of convenience following the failed coup of 2016, but relations are under strain over escalating violence in Syria, where they back opposite sides. Mr Erdogan's attempt to create a buffer zone for Syrian refugees in the Syrian-Turkish border region backfired following the latest campaign by Bashar Al-Assad, the Syrian president, to retake control of Idlib province-the last stronghold of Turkish-backed rebels. Following the death of 57 Turkish soldiers in February alone, Turkey launched an aggressive campaign against Syrian forces, which has been tolerated by Russia to some degree. However, Turkey risks being drawn into an all-out war, as Mr Assad is showing no signs of restraint. In the light of the escalating violence, Turkey has formally asked the US to supply its Patriot missile-defence system to protect Turkey's troops against the Syrian regime's forces. However, such support is unlikely to be forthcoming unless Turkey agrees to abandon deployment of the Russian S-400 missile-defence platform purchased in 2019, which poses a security threat to US aircraft and is unsuitable for Turkey's security needs in Syria. Mr Erdogan's pivot towards Russia, which called into question Turkey's NATO membership, has backfired and will result in Turkey becoming increasingly isolated in 2020-24. Furthermore, Turkish-US relations will remain tense, and the main trigger for a further deterioration in relations in 2020 will be the likelihood of the US imposing sanctions on Turkey for its purchase of the S-400 system.
Relations with the EU are also unlikely to improve in 2020-24. The main area of tension will be Turkey's recent decision to open its border with Greece and encourage thousands of refugees to try to enter the EU. The move has called into question the Turkey-EU migration agreement of 2016. Even before the coronavirus outbreak, EU members were unwilling to open their borders to refugees, fearing a repeat of the 2015 migration crisis. The EU's external borders are now closed, but individual members are likely to offer Turkey more financial assistance to deal with the mostly Syrian refugees domestically. Nonetheless, Mr Erdogan's unilateral decision to open Turkey's border has significantly increased mistrust on the EU side, which does not bode well for EU-Turkey bilateral relations over our forecast period.
Oil and gas exploration by Turkey and the Republic of Cyprus in the eastern Mediterranean also has the potential to further damage relations. The EU has admonished Turkey for its "unauthorised" and "illegal" drilling activities in disputed waters in the eastern Mediterranean as a violation of Cyprus's exclusive economic zone (EEZ). Turkey has long disputed Cyprus's claim to some areas of the EEZ, arguing that they lie inside its continental shelf. Turkish maritime operations are unlikely to be reversed in the foreseeable future.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The AKP government will continue to favour economic policies aimed at reviving fast, credit-fuelled economic growth in the years leading up to the parliamentary and presidential elections in 2023. The economy remains weak and-following its poor performance in local elections-the AKP will continue to feel pressure to support growth and the labour market. However, the coronavirus outbreak in Turkey and the measures adopted to contain it have derailed the government's 2020-22 medium-term economic programme that was announced in September 2019. The programme forecasts included annual growth of 5% in 2020-22 and an average central government budget deficit of 2.8% of GDP. We expect a severe recession in 2020 to weigh heavily on Turkey's public finances and the ability of the public and private sectors to meet their borrowing requirements.
Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches, and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed effectively in the forecast period. Politicisation of the Central Bank of Turkey's monetary policy is also likely to continue, given Mr Erdogan's insistence on the need for lower interest rates to support credit growth rather than curb inflation. We expect these issues to weigh on investor sentiment over medium term, especially at times of increased risk aversion. In such conditions, there is a considerable risk that attracting capital inflows to fund lending could become unsustainable, resulting in a sudden credit stop and another crisis.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy Under the AKP, public finances have been one of the economy's most reassuring aspects, but this credibility is now weakening. The budget deficit widened from an average of 1.4% of GDP in 2014-18 to 2.9% in 2019 on the back of a substantial fiscal stimulus. Based on our assessment of the measures adopted in response to the coronavirus outbreak-including a stimulus package worth TL100bn (US$14.7bn; 2% of GDP), about half of which comprises loan guarantees-we expect the deficit to widen further, to 4.5% of GDP in 2020. It will then narrow gradually, to 3% of GDP in 2024, as the economy recovers and public spending is reined in to reverse an increase in the public debt/GDP ratio to 35.7% of GDP this year. We expect government debt to have eased to 32.6% by the end of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy Since dramatically raising its main policy rate-the one-week repurchase (repo) lending rate-to 24% in September 2018 in a belated response to a sharp depreciation of the lira against all major currencies and a surge in inflation, the central bank has steadily loosened domestic monetary conditions, helped by loosening by major central banks. Since July 2019 the central bank has slashed its main policy rate by a total of 1,425 basis points, to 9.75% in mid-March 2020. This dovish turn reflects pressure from Mr Erdogan for lower interest rates, but also a partial recovery of the Turkish currency and an easing of inflationary pressure-although the average annual rate of consumer inflation was still high, at about 12% in the first quarter of 2020.
The central bank's official mandate is to reduce inflation permanently to 5% or less in the medium term. However, the focus of the central bank and the government appears to be supporting economic activity, including by stimulating credit growth, especially through lending by Turkey's state banks. With the main policy rate now below the current rate of inflation, the central bank has limited scope to cut rates without running the risk of fuelling another currency crisis, especially amid the recent financial market volatility triggered by the global spread of the coronavirus. Nevertheless, we expect central bank to cut its main policy rate gradually by a further 75 basis points, to 9% by end-2020, in order to support the economy. This forecast implies that the real policy rate will remain in negative territory during most of the forecast period, keeping the lira under pressure and causing the central bank continue to overshoot its inflation target of 5%.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth The depreciation of the Turkish lira by about 40% against the US dollar in January-August 2018 caused inflation to surge, increasing input costs for corporates and raising the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. The resulting crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018, followed by modest growth in 2019 driven by a rapid decline in interest rates. Following the outbreak of the coronavirus, we now expect the recovery to be reversed, with real GDP forecast to contract by 3.5% in 2020 as strong growth in the first quarter is offset by sharp falls in activity in the remaining three quarters of the year. This reflects weak household demand as unemployment rises and fixed investment declines further, as well as a heavy hit to exports of goods and services. Despite lira weakness, we expect the impact of supply chain disruptions, quarantine measures and travel restrictions in major markets to hurt major Turkish export industries such as the automotive sector and tourism. Automotive exports account for about 17% of the total value of goods exports and tourism accounts for about 12% of GDP (including indirect effects). We expect a gradual recovery from 2021, with GDP expanding by an average of 3.5% in 2021-24, above the potential rate of growth.
The recovery will be driven by population and employment growth, rising real wages and government-fuelled credit growth, and a pick-up in capital invest-ment and tourist inflows. With the government consistently pushing economic growth above potential, there is the risk of another significant loss of investor confidence at some point in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Annual inflation averaged 8.5% in 2004-17, but reached 24.9% in October 2018 in the wake of the sharp lira depreciation. By October 2019 the inflation rate settled back to 8.3%, reflecting a more stable currency and subdued domestic demand. Owing largely to base effects, a return to growth in the economy and renewed lira weakness, inflation has edged up again since late 2019: inflation stood at 12% year on year (seasonally adjusted) in March 2020, marginally below 12.5% in the previous month. We expect the annual rate of inflation to undulate around this level over the next few months and to decline only moderately later in the year. The slump in global oil prices in January-March will be positive for domestic fuel and energy costs. However, we expect this to be largely offset by the impact of a renewed fall in the external value of the lira since the start of this year, resulting in an annual rate of inflation of 10.9% at end-2020. In 2021-24 we expect inflation to average 10.6% per year, with a spike up to a forecast 12% in 2022 reflecting a sharp rise in global oil prices as the post-coronavirus global economic recovery gathers pace.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Having depreciated against the US dollar by 24.4% on average in 2018 and 14.9% in 2019 as a result of the currency crisis, the Turkish lira remained broadly stable in the second half of last year before resuming a generally weakening trajectory in the first three months of 2020. We expect lira volatility to continue in the remainder of this year, leading to a nominal depreciation of almost 16%-to TL6.74:US$1 on average and about TL7:US$1 at the end of the year-owing to negative real interest rates, a widening fiscal and current-account deficit, continued credit expansion, and the central bank's dovish monetary policy stance. From 2021 we expect the lira to remain broadly stable in nominal terms, but to appreciate moderately in real effective terms as the economy recovers. There are considerable downside risks to this currency forecast, given the increase in risk aversion amid the uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Turkey usually runs a substantial current-account deficit, financed by net inflows of capital from abroad. Since the sharp depreciation of the lira in mid-2018, however, capital inflows have been weak. Conversely, the current-account balance improved dramatically in 2019, posting a surplus of 1.1% of GDP, as the trade deficit narrowed in line with the weak lira and the economic slowdown while the surplus on the services balance (the second most important component) widened, reflecting a strong tourism season. We expect the current account to swing back into deficit, averaging 2.8% of GDP per year in 2020-21, as the hit to exports of goods and services from the coronavirus pandemic more than offsets a fall in imported energy costs resulting from lower global oil prices. In 2022-24 we expect the deficit to average 3.2% of GDP per year as recovering domestic demand and higher global oil prices offset stronger export growth.

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the looming public health crisis triggered by the spread of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, will retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. The collapse in international crude prices in March, combined with US sanctions on the regime, means that barrels are currently being sold at a loss. We therefore project a reduction in domestic crude production over the coming quarters. Moreover, given that it will lose control of the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure in 2020 to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have so far aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries globally in the business environment rankings for 2020-24, having been 80th in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Limited rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain subdued, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions remain on private-sector access to foreign currency.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour creates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2022-24: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but risk of water and electricity rationing remains.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit considers that the spread of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) and the collapse of international crude prices present the greatest challenges to date to the survival of the military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). These simultaneous crises have shattered the relative stability that had developed in recent months. With the onset of the crises, shrinking oil revenue will add significant pressure to the regime's finances. Hyperinflation and bolívar depreciation will worsen, with shortages of food and fuel making a comeback. In addition, owing to the bleak state of the country's healthcare system, Venezuela faces an uphill battle against the coronavirus, and there is a high risk that the ongoing socioeconomic crisis will evolve into a humanitarian calamity.
Mr Maduro is wary of the potential political ramifications of the coronavirus outbreak in Venezuela. He requested, to no avail, a US$5bn loan from the IMF to help the country to deal with the virus. With US dollars ever more scarce, severe shortages of goods and public services are likely over the coming months. Together with the government's mandatory social-distancing measures, which will further curb incomes, significant bouts of social unrest are likely.
However, despite these compounding social and economic shocks-and the US sanctions already in place-we expect Mr Maduro to retain power throughout 2020, ruling over what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. Mr Maduro has two main factors in his favour. First, the opposition, led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in 2019. Although Mr Guaidó enjoys wide international recognition as the legitimate leader of Venezuela, the current public health crisis is demonstrating once again that his interim government has no de facto power. Second, the regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. Although the risks to our forecasts are very high, we assume that this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and the recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is an extremely high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as low. A negotiated transition would also be difficult, in our view. In early March the US outlined a transition framework in which both Mr Maduro and Mr Guaidó would allow a new state council to be created and fresh elections to be held. Mr Guaidó himself recently called for the creation of a "national emergency government" (which would not include Mr Maduro) to better combat the coronavirus epidemic. However, both proposals (and other negotiated solutions) are likely to fail, as trust issues between the sides are insurmountable. On March 26th the US indicted 14 top chavista officials, including Mr Maduro, discouraging the regime from co-operating on a negotiated exit. Nevertheless, successful talks with Colombia regarding humanitarian and/or health assistance are possible.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Furthermore, the collapse in international crude prices and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink dollar inflows. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems and a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch Assuming that the Maduro regime clings to power, legislative elections will take place in December. These elections will be neither free nor fair, and the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America-under the Lima Group banner or through the Organisation of American States-to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) so that Mr Maduro is forced to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. However, if tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Mr Maduro's main international backers are Cuba and Russia. Russia is helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to circumvent US sanctions; in March, the Venezuelan assets of Rosneft (a Russian energy company) were transferred directly to Russia, representing a step-up in the US-Russia diplomatic crossfire over Venezuela. Nevertheless, both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering the collapse in oil prices and containing the looming public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. At the time of writing the country had 159 reported cases of the virus and had reached Stage 4 (community spread). To contain the spread, Mr Maduro announced a mandatory nationwide quarantine lasting until at least April 13th and made the wearing of facemasks compulsory. To cushion the adverse effects of social distancing on people's incomes, Mr Maduro also announced extraordinary cash transfers and rent deferrals, but funds to finance such measures are scarce. Reflecting a lack of confidence in the government's ability to support incomes, quarantine restrictions have barely been followed; many workers lack savings to survive without continuing to work. Furthermore, the country's medical infrastructure is poor and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity. Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared for Covid-19. The regime's overall lack of policymaking capacity will lead to accelerating hyperinflation, sharper bolívar depreciation and an even steeper recession in 2020.
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power for the duration of our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the survival of the regime. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the present regime. In this environment, domestic supply will be persistently weak.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, over the medium term, growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. At present we assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. The country's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US court ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US currently considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, thus shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors. However, once the PSUV retakes control of the (currently legitimate) National Assembly, Citgo assets will no longer be safeguarded.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyper-inflationary pressures in 2019. However, we expect hyperinflation to return in the coming months, owing to monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages. Overall, hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect a further decline, of 25.4%, in 2020. The contraction will follow the steep decline in crude prices and reflect the adverse effects of the government's quarantine measures, which-even if only partly followed-will further dent domestic demand. Ultra-low oil prices will hamper production, but most importantly, they will indirectly hit the non-oil economy through shortages of fuel and public services, scarcity of goods and reinvigorated hyperinflation. From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes and continued mass emigration (which is fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability).
The recent collapse in oil prices will put significant pressure on Venezuela to slash crude production. The country's average break-even price is about US$15-US$20 per barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is selling its oil at a loss (its oil basket reached US$13.8/barrel at end-March). Although the country seeks to produce as much oil as possible, the current circumstances will inevitably lead to cuts in production; we expect oil output to decline from 760,000 barrels/day in February (according to OPEC), to 620,000 b/d on average in 2020. However, we believe that average output could fall as low as 500,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2021 we expect the economy to grow marginally, owing to a stabilisation of oil output and to the base effects of lifting social-distancing measures. In 2022 economic growth will accelerate on the back of a surge in oil prices. However, in the medium term oil output will continue to fall-albeit gradually-owing to serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and to a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude. Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24 (owing to moderately higher global oil prices) as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term.
There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of the improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will bring about a return to hyperinflation this year. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit helped to subdue hyperinflation in the second half of 2019. However, inflationary pressures will intensify substantially in the coming months, owing to widespread goods shortages and the ramping-up of government money printing. In the medium term inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Accelerating hyperinflation will quicken the pace of bolívar depreciation in 2020. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or the introduction of a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the Maduro regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We continue to believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On April 3rd the official exchange rate was BsS86,550:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS94,120:US$1. The premium (currently at 8.7%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit in 2020. The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019). In 2020 Venezuela will post a current-account deficit of 1.6% of GDP, owing to even lower oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from a global recession.
We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 5.9% of GDP in 2022-24. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance government to serve out its second five-year term, which will expire in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration. The administration's Hindu nationalistic agenda could raise the incidence of communal violence.
- The government imposed a 21-day lockdown nationwide from March 25th in response to the coronavirus epidemic. A lack of healthcare infrastructure makes India particularly vulnerable to the virus.
- India's relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24. But disagreements on tariff and service sector export restrictions will limit trade deals. Relations with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's ambitions in South Asia. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in 2020/21 (April-March), as the government launches stimulus to keep households and firms afloat during the lockdown. It will narrow but still remain wide during the remainder of the forecast period.
- The RBI cut the policy repo rate by 75 basis points in response to coronavirus. We expect the RBI will tweak its policy tools and regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of accommodative monetary policy.
- Real GDP growth will slump to 2.1% in 2020/21, down from an estimated 4.9% in 2019/20, and the lowest rate of expansion since 1991. The recovery will be sluggish in 2021/22, with GDP forecast to rise by 5.1%. We expect the growth will average 6.2% between 2022/23-2024/25.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs73.8:US$1. The currency will remain weak in 2021-24, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and rising domestic inflation.
- The merchandise trade deficit will narrow in 2020 amid low global oil prices. It will widen in the forecast period as India increases imports of capital goods. Business outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score rises over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies in 2021.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or merger and acquisition (M&A) activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Restrictions on foreign investment in multi-brand retail are partially removed.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: The country remains reluctant to join major regional trade deals.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands. Tax breaks and rebates are made available to businesses and individuals impacted by the coronavirus outbreak.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking-sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues persist in public-sector banks.
The labour market 2020-21: Unemployment rises as a result of the lockdown. The government expands the rural employment guarantee scheme.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at central government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation to healthcare facility projects, in response to the coronavirus outbreak.
2022-24: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development (R&D) as a proportion of GDP remains low by regional standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or by purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's domination of the central government during its term, which ends in 2024.
The results of the 2019 election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts, the most prominent being the national security adviser, Ajit Doval. We believe that the PMO and Mr Doval will continue to set the policy agenda over the next five years. The lockdown measures have been welcomed by the public as an effective measure to halt the spread of the coronavirus. Mr Modi will continue to enjoy the popularity but any significant disruption during the lockdown will damage his reputation.
Social unrest will pose a threat to political stability during the forecast period. Clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups, notably Muslims. Violent protests are continuing across India following the enactment in December of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019, with some fearing that the change will erode secularism and others concerned about unchecked immigration. State governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, although some may not implement the changes to the citizenship law.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a key concern in the early part of the forecast period. The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state sparked protests. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders, further unrest cannot be ruled out. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shut-downs, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be on gauging support for the BJP in the state assembly elections. However, the results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important. We believe that the BJP will perform poorly in the state election in Bihar later in the year.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half the total number of seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of a few more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) could secure a simple majority in the upper house. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan will be exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August to revoke the special status granted to J&K. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
The US president, Donald Trump, visited India in February 2020. India and the US have affirmed further co-operation on defence policy and confirmed a military equipment purchase. However, they failed to reach even a limited trade deal, owing to disagreements on India's tariff collection and restrictions on service sector exports by the US. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence.
China's sway in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the economic policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. The key near-term priority for the administration is to contain the development of the coronavirus outbreak, to which India is particularly vulnerable, given its large population and weak healthcare infrastructure. The government's approach will include effectively quarantining the country (a 21-day lockdown began on March 25th), enhancing the capacity of the healthcare system and ratifying a stimulus plan to bolster the economy. The government delivered a first stimulus-relief package targeted at low-income groups on March 26th, which included direct cash transfers and food giveaways. A fiscal relief package for businesses will also be forthcoming. Incentives will be offered to labour-intensive sectors and special allowance given to service sectors that are heavily impacted by the closure of businesses, including transportation and hospitality. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will also extend liquidity support, including a three-month moratorium on all term loans.
The government's broader policy agenda will be deprioritised, at least in 2020. It is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements and a modest liberalisation of foreign investment, could be undertaken. Nevertheless, we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging. The lockdown will amplify the mounting non-performing loan (NPL) issues in the banking sector. The risk of systemic failure of banks is not negligible.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National infrastructure Pipeline and the Smart Cities Mission-remain a priority, partly in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and partly to boost the business environment. In light of the coronavirus outbreak, healthcare facilities will become another focus of government investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The coronavirus outbreak will force the government to rewrite its approved budget for 2020/21, which was conservatively expansionary. It will likely temporarily suspend the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act to allow for more flexibility in terms of supporting the economy. As a result, we have widened our budget deficit forecast for 2020/21 to the equivalent of 5.1% of GDP, from 3.7% previously.
Lockdown policies and the demands of healthcare provision mean that the government will implement relatively aggressive fiscal stimulus. Measures will include a direct cash-transfer initiative to households. The National Rural Employment Guarantee Act will be expanded, contrary to the plan in the approved budget. Further plans include an infrastructure development programme and tax break for businesses. These measures will go alongside reforms included in the approved budget, such as the simplification of income tax for individuals in certain income groups and the abolition of the dividend distribution tax.
As the economy recovers, the government will look to consolidate the public finances. This will lead to a narrowing of the budget deficit to the equivalent of 3.9% of GDP in 2021/22. However, the government will struggle to bring down the deficit much further over the remainder of the forecast period. The authorities will look to deepen the tax base and increase low levels of tax compliance. However, the need to support welfare payments and infrastructure spending will keep upward pressure on fiscal expenditure. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive, small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits of several state governments, which are not included in the national figures. The deep deficits in some states, such as Himachal Pradesh, will present implicit liabilities for the central government.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The coronavirus epidemic will prompt monetary policy loosening by the RBI. In March, the central bank lowered its policy repo rate by 75 basis points to 4.4%, as well as widening the monetary policy corridor by lowering the reverse repo rate (the "floor" of the corridor) by 90 basis points, to 4%. With inflationary pressures moderating and economic growth under strong near-term downward pressure, further adjustments are likely. We are not yet forecasting a further 50-basis-point reduction in the policy repo rate in 2020/21. But we expect the adoption of more unconventional policy instruments. This will include cuts to the reserve cash ratio, liquidity to support long-term refinancing operations and a moratorium, of three months initially, on all term loan repayments.
These measures will aim to keep businesses afloat during lockdown periods and as the coronavirus affects household spending and business investment. However, the outcome might be far from satisfying. The transmission from monetary policy rate to actual lending is not so smooth, as the banks are also reluctant to lend. Also, the informal sector cannot lend from normal financial institutions and, therefore, will be hard to benefit from these policies. The level of non-performing assets in the financial sector is alarming, and the coronavirus outbreak may amplify the issue, with more firms forced out of business. The government might have to recapitalise the banks through rescue mergers with public-sector banks, or even directly nationalise the stressed banks.
The RBI has maintained inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-has complicated these objectives.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth The coronavirus outbreak will take a significant toll on the Indian economy. The nationwide lockdown, with factories and office buildings closed, will remove a significant proportion of economic activity while it remains in place. A loss of income, corporate bankruptcy and a jump in unemployment will affect household spending and business investment beyond the lockdown. As a result, we forecast that real GDP growth will decelerate sharply, to 2.1% in 2020/21, from estimated expansion of 4.9% in 2019/20. Expansion of this level would be the lowest since 1991. The economy will contract (on a year-on-year basis) in the first half of 2020/21 (April-September), before mounting a recovery in the second half of the year as the coronavirus outbreak comes under greater control and the global economy recovers.
On a GDP expenditure basis, private consumption will contract, as people are unable to consume as much with lockdown and lower incomes. The investment sentiment will also fall, which eventually brought investment to contraction. The government will be actively bolstering the economy through government expenditure, but the effect will be limited. We expect both exports and imports to fall amid global lockdown.
The economic recovery will be modest initially, with growth forecast at 5.1% in 2021/22, as businesses continue to withhold investment. An anticipated tightening of monetary policy in 2022-23 will also weigh on sentiment. Over the long term, progress on structural reforms will be too slow to give real GDP a significant boost.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 5.7% in 2020 as a whole, compared with 3.7% in 2019. Upward pressure on prices will stem from supply-side disruptions caused by coronavirus control measures. The outbreak has significantly slowed down the traffic of goods and eliminated some logistical options. This will inevitably lead to a hike in prices. Price pressures will abate from the second half of this year, as forthcoming harvests boost food supplies and lockdown gradually eases. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
The RBI will keep its policy rate unchanged in 2021 to bolster the recovery. The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in 2022 will offset the inflationary impact of strengthening oil prices. The central bank will accord higher priority to containing inflationary pressures towards the end of the forecast period; consumer price inflation is expected to ease to 3.4% in 2024.
Low oil prices in 2020 will cause producer price inflation to soften to 0.8% in the year. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.6% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2019, along with high political risks associated with the removal of J&K's special constitutional status and changes to the citizenship law, have weighed on the exchange rate. The coronavirus outbreak has amplified such pressures. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate by 4.5% on an annual average basis, to Rs73.8:US$1 in 2020, as investors flee to safe haven assets and the domestic economic situation worsens. In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly, to an average of Rs72.7:US$1, as investor confidence returns. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-23 amid rising oil prices. We expect the currency to appreciate slightly in 2024, owing to an easing of external pay-ment pressures.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The lower oil price and weaker domestic demand will contribute to a narrowing of India's current-account deficit in 2020, when it is forecast to stand at the equivalent of 0.3% of GDP. Merchandise export growth will be tempered by disruptions caused by the outbreak of the coronavirus globally in the year, but is expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in global commerce. In the longer term, India's export manufacturing sector will still be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities. Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology (IT). Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit in the remainder of the forecast period. The coronavirus outbreak will weigh on inward investment in 2020. Inward direct investment will recover modestly in 2021-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses.

Full text: - The unfolding economic crisis, stemming from the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak, will complicate policymaking for the remainder of the term of the president, Lenín Moreno, which ends in May 2021. Commitment to fiscal discipline in the face of a deteriorating macroeconomic environment will embolden political opposition to the government ahead of presidential and legislative elections in February 2021, and will raise the risk of social unrest. Irrespective of the election outcome, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects sizable barriers to governing and to stability to persist, considering the highly fragmented political landscape. Assuming that a centrist government is elected, these headwinds will hamper piecemeal liberalising economic reforms.
- Ecuador is one of the smallest markets in our business environment rankings. The country's mineral reserves will continue to attract oil and mining investors, but the domestic market will grow only slightly as it struggles to recover from the recession engendered by the coronavirus outbreak. We forecast that GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will rise marginally from US$6,166 in 2019 to US$6,201 in 2024. As such, business opportunities will remain restricted by low purchasing power, as well as by a small market size.
- Under the auspices of the IMF, the government will cut public spending and investment to shore up the public finances. Despite a statistical rebound in real GDP in 2021, the country's short-term growth prospects will be curbed by soft oil prices, which will also weigh on the fiscal and external accounts. Notwithstanding political and economic uncertainties, we expect dollar-isation to be maintained in the 2020-24 forecast period, as it remains popular for delivering macroeconomic stability and for taming inflation.
- Population growth is slowing, owing to a falling birth rate and continued emigration (albeit at lower levels). However, at an annual average of 1.3% per year in 2020-24, population growth will be on a par with that of neighbouring Andean nations. The unemployment rate will remain low in historical terms, falling from a forecast 5.1% in 2020 to 4.7% by 2024; underemployment will continue to be high. The informal sector will remain substantial, partly owing to labour market rigidities. Although low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador to catch up with more developed countries, poor prospects for institutional improvements are likely to preclude a stable economic policy direction. Therefore, we forecast that income will continue to lag OECD levels in the long term.

- Ecuador scores poorly in our business environment rankings, owing to its dependence on oil and the current administration's timid embrace of orthodox policymaking. Although the country's score improves slightly in the forecast period, its global ranking remains low. The government will seek more private investment, but structural shortcomings in the investment environment will not be fully addressed, hindering investors' perceptions.

Country forecast overview: Ecuador's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Fuel subsidies are gradually, albeit not completely, rolled back in targeted manner. Implementation of antitrust policies is subject to politicisation. Select industries (such as mining) benefit from policies promoting supply-side growth.
2022-24: Government continues to scale back state's role in development. Nonetheless, regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector firms. A new public-private partnership model is trialled.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Overtures to foreign firms and pro-business reforms partly offset the government's continual interventionism.
2022-24: Inadequate property-rights protection and questions over access to foreign arbitration deter investment. New mining projects attract investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Government maintains capital outflows tax and increases import tariffs to protect dollarisation.
2022-24: Supply-side reforms enhance national competitiveness and government begins to phase out capital outflows tax.
Taxes 2020-21: Government implements tax reform to expand tax base and improve collection. Certain exemptions will be eliminated, while other burdensome regulations are simplified.
2022-24: Efforts continue to increase tax collection, supporting revenue growth. Tax system remains complex.
Financing 2020-21: Deposit and credit growth are moderate and support banking stability.
2022-24: Financing is still below potential as public-financing needs curb growth of long-term lending to private sector.
The labour market 2020-21: Government takes steps to reduce public-wage bill and reduce labour market rigidities.
2022-24: Quality of workforce remains poor. Labour reforms are slow to take effect.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Fiscal constraints lead to cancellation of several projects. Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment achieve little success.
2022-24: Renewed interest in port and airport development sustains new cycle of investment.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Investment to expand fourth-generation (4G) broadband availability.
2022-24: Increasing adoption of civic technologies by government. Fifth-generation (5G) technology remains in its infancy.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions remain fragile. External economic shocks have contributed to the ousting of three presidents by popular protest since 1997. The current president, Lenín Moreno, took office in May 2017, succeeding Rafael Correa (2007-17)-the longest-serving president in Ecuadorean history. In February 2018 a series of constitutional reforms introduced by Mr Moreno (including the reintroduction of a two-term limit for the presidency) were approved by referendum. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation, persistent social and fiscal challenges will continue to weigh on governability.
Political structure: The 2008 constitution increased executive power, but has done little to foster institutional capacity to tackle problems such as a politicised judiciary, powerful business lobbies, and mobilised grassroots and indigenous groups. The political system is fragmented. Mr Moreno retains strong executive powers, but his Alianza País lost considerable standing after the results of the 2018 referendum splintered the party.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided macroeconomic stability but exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitive-ness. Modest oil prices during the 2020-24 forecast period, relative to the previous decade, have necessitated fiscal adjustments. A three-year IMF agreement (along with other multilateral financing), secured by the Moreno administration in March 2019 after borrowing in international capital markets became unsustainable, will be leveraged to address these shortcomings. The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will complicate the government's economic reform agenda, especially considering its lack of fiscal space to counter the hit to the economy and financial system.
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador recorded an estimated trade surplus of US$865m in 2019. Weak external demand is likely to preclude a trade surplus in 2020, before an expansion of earnings from oil, banana and shrimp exports support trade surpluses in 2021-24.
