Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The unfolding novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic presents the president, Lenín Moreno, with two immense challenges before his term ends in May 2021. First, Mr Moreno must work to contain the spread of the virus with limited resources. Strict national lockdown measures have been in place since mid-March but the virus has spread rapidly, with more than 1,400 cases reported as of March 26th. It remains to be seen whether the country has the capacity to handle a health crisis of this scale. Although there is broad consensus for thorough containment measures, policymaking and the political environment will be complicated as the crisis unfolds, considering that the political land-scape is highly fragmented; Mr Moreno lacks a majority-his Alianza País (AP) has 42 seats, 27 short of the threshold-and the February 2021 elections are approaching. The second challenge for Mr Moreno is stabilising the economy as oil prices tumble, lockdown measures stifle activity and external demand shrinks. With no fiscal space to mount a countercyclical response (Mr Moreno has announced cuts to public spending and revenue-raising measures), the political opposition will be emboldened, political instability aggravated and the risk of social unrest heightened significantly. A daily curfew from 2pm to 5am is in effect until end-March (with the potential to be extended) but, with the economic situation for millions of Ecuadoreans quickly worsening, there is a high probability for protests to occur in the next few months, especially considering that indigenous groups responsible for intense protests in October 2019 have called for a permanent mobilisation against the government.
Commitment to socially unpalatable and politically divisive economic measures will help the government to retain IMF support, but will dissolve support for the president. Mr Moreno has staked his presidency on his economic programme backed by a three-year, US$4.2bn extended fund facility (EFF) with the IMF, and US$6bn in additional multilateral financing (intended to be disbursed between March 2019 and December 2021). On March 23rd, amid the coronavirus outbreak, the administration made Ecuador's second-ever bond repayment. In doing so, the president snubbed a nearly unanimous request from the legislature that debt payments are to be suspended, reflecting the governability challenges that the Moreno administration faces as it seeks to renegotiate its current IMF arrangement and advance its reform agenda.
Political jockeying will be a constant undercurrent as elections near. Political leaders from across the ideological spectrum will seek to capitalise on the economic crisis and elevate their position. Radical leftist ideals supported by the former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), may return to the fore as the economy languishes-despite the fact that Mr Correa himself is facing calls from the country's attorney-general to serve seven years in prison (amid a corruption trial) and remains out of the country. For now, however, it is unlikely that his supporters will re-emerge as the dominant political force, and political uncertainties will prevail (rather than dissipate) in the short to medium term.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next legislative and presidential elections are scheduled for February 2021. The Economist Intelligence Unit currently assumes that the president will serve out the rest of his term. An early termination of Mr Moreno's term (either through his resignation or elections being brought forward) would intensify economic uncertainties and throw the country into political turmoil-outcomes that most parties are keen to avoid. Nevertheless, the presidential poll result is nebulous at this stage, owing to obscurity caused by the coronavirus outbreak.
Mr Moreno has signalled that he does not intend to run and, given his government's commitment to unpopular economic measures, it is unlikely that a member of his centre-left AP will secure victory. However, should the government successfully navigate the health crisis, the vice-president, Otto Sonnenholzner, may rise in stature. The conservative opposition Partido Social Cristiano (PSC) performed well in municipal elections in March 2019, and is strongly placed to capitalise on the fragmented political landscape and mount a robust campaign. The other major conservative opposition party, Creando Oportunidades led by Guillermo Lasso (who narrowly lost to Mr Moreno in 2017), also may grow in appeal.
A candidate backed by Mr Correa could play a significant role in the election, as the government struggles to weather the worsening economic situation. On balance, even though a Correa-backed candidate may make it to the second round, we believe that Mr Sonnenholzner, a PSC candidate or Mr Lasso are more likely to win. We would expect these administrations to pursue centrist economic policies, and we have based our medium-term forecasts on this assumption.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations The foreign policy agenda of Mr Moreno will remain focused on strengthening diplomatic and commercial ties with major trading partners, mainly the US (Ecuador's largest trading partner). In the short term, however, the coronavirus pandemic and Ecuador's unfolding economic crisis is likely to hamper free-trade agreement (FTA) discussions with the US (talks were scheduled to take place in April) and Ecuador's accession to the Pacific Alliance (a regional trade bloc). The latter may also be hindered by the absence of an existing bilateral agreement with Mexico; however, Ecuador and Mexico have ambitiously set February 7th 2021 (the date of general election in Ecuador) as the deadline for an FTA.
There is a reasonable chance that Ecuador will enter the bloc by 2024, considering that the presidents within the Pacific Alliance (as well as Mexico's foreign minister) have expressed their support for Ecuador's swift accession to the group. However, unexpected hitches or changes in government and policy direction may yet hinder the accession process.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The coronavirus outbreak will push Ecuador towards default and a balance-of-payments crisis. Avoiding this will require, more than ever, the support of the IMF (and other actors), but meeting the conditions required to access these funds will be extremely complicated politically, heightening risks in the coming months. Political pressure to loosen fiscal policy and suspend debt payments is mounting, and will continue to rise, but Mr Moreno will try to maintain fiscal discipline and work to improve the country's credibility with investors, most likely seeking an amicable restructuring of its debt with private creditors, rather than a disorderly default.
Mr Moreno's stance will help to unlock much-needed financial assistance from multilateral development banks and the IMF. The government has requested a US$500m loan through the Fund's Rapid Financing Instrument (RFI) by end-April, which the IMF is considering. Unlike fully fledged IMF programmes, RFIs come with little conditionality, and this should provide the government with some policy leeway, considering the circumstances, assuming that the request is approved (we have pencilled the funds into our forecasts). That said, we do not expect a dramatic loosening of policy either, as the government will be hoping that its show of credibility will help it to secure at least US$1bn from China (which we have also pencilled into our forecasts). New external financing and close collaboration between the government and the IMF will be paramount to navigating the developing crisis in the coming weeks and months, as the government is working to establish a new arrangement with the Fund that builds on the current EFF.
The objectives of the government's IMF-backed economic programme will be overshadowed by the policy response to the economic and health crises. We expect that the government will still pursue labour reform and the removal of fuel subsidies, having stated before the crisis that a gradual and less drastic fuel subsidy reduction would be rolled out by June, but short-term measures to boost health expenditure and provide support to the economy will take precedence for now.
Assuming that a centre-right or centre-left government takes office in May 2021 (before the final EFF review in December of that year) and provides for policy continuity, we expect that the four primary objectives of the EFF will continue to be prioritised in the medium to long term. These include improving competitiveness, tackling fiscal imbalances, protecting the poor and fighting corruption. Moreover, under our political assumptions and in the light of the unfolding crises, we view IMF assistance beyond 2021 as a highly probable scenario. This suggests a piecemeal advancement of business-friendly policies and complementary reforms in 2021-24. Nonetheless, limited progress will be made in diversifying the economy away from oil (the country left OPEC in January to free itself from quotas).
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The government will have limited success in cushioning the blow to the fiscal accounts from the drastic halt to domestic economic activity and lower oil revenue than previously anticipated in the budget. We thus expect both a widening of the fiscal deficit and a cut in public expenditure, although there are huge political risks to the latter in particular. Even assuming that new, extraordinary multilateral and bilateral assistance is forthcoming, this will not be enough to plug the fiscal hole produced by the collapse in oil prices.
In mid-March Mr Moreno announced that the government would accelerate the downsizing of the state and reduce spending by US$1.4bn in 2020 to help to offset the fall in revenue from oil sales. Of the US$1.4bn reduction (equivalent to around 1.3% of GDP), US$845m will come from lower spending on goods and services, while US$535m will stem from lower capital expenditure. The government also aims to raise a further US$900m through one-off contributions and increased income tax withholdings from large companies. Some revenue-raising measures will require legislative approval, suggesting that the government's estimated US$2.3bn in fiscal savings is overly optimistic.
We forecast that the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit will widen to 4.7% of GDP in 2020, assuming that public spending is cut by much less than revenue. As a result, public debt as a percentage of GDP will rise from an estimated 45.7% of GDP in 2019 to 51.6% in 2020. Accordingly, the fiscal targets set in the government's EFF are unfeasible-the pace of fiscal adjustment was already slowed at end-2019 in a combined second and third review of the EFF and the fourth review suspended-and we view as impossible both an improvement of 4 percent-age points in the non-oil primary balance/GDP ratio (including subsidies) between 2019 and 2021, and a reduction in the public debt/GDP ratio to 40% by 2024.
The successor IMF agreement being negotiated will shed light on how fiscal targets and fiscal policymaking adapt to the looming economic recession. Irrespective of the changes, programme implementation risks will be glaringly high as social and political challenges to reforms exceed their pre-crisis levels. Without details on a new deal, and assuming policy continuity, we expect the NFPS deficit to gradually narrow in 2021-24, to 2.4% of GDP by 2024, and for the public debt/GDP ratio to stabilise at around 57%.
We are cautiously optimistic that that the government will avoid a disorderly default, owing to bilateral and multilateral financing. The government estimates that it will receive about US$2bn from multilateral creditors and China, after the government made a final US$325m payment on the capital of a 10.5%, five-year bond in mid-March. The government also plans to take advantage of a 30-day grace period on other payments totalling US$200m, as its response to the coronavirus outbreak saps its resources. Even so, and although it is not yet our baseline forecast, there is a substantial risk that Ecuador will be forced into a debt restructuring this year or fall into disorderly default ahead of larger payments in the second half of 2020.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy As a dollarised economy, Ecuador lacks independent monetary policy, and will not be able to foment a monetary policy response to the emerging economic crisis. Monetary conditions will remain largely determined by external factors, but real local rates will remain elevated, owing to Ecuador's high risk premium.
Monetary growth will hinge on foreign-exchange inflows, as well as the confidence of domestic lenders, both of which will be markedly undermined by the rapid deterioration of the economy. The threat of de-dollarisation will sustain the risk of capital flight, which raises the risk that preventative measures in the short term are implemented in order to protect domestic liquidity levels.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth The economy will enter a recession in 2020. Before the crash in oil prices and the acceleration of the spread of the coronavirus, we held the view that net exports would support tepid real GDP growth (less than 1%). We now expect real GDP to contract by 6.5% in 2020. Net exports are still likely to positively contribute to growth despite a marked drop in export volumes; we expect them to decrease by 8% as external demand falls markedly, but this drop will be overshadowed by a 13.1% decline in import volumes. The marked decline in import volumes reflects a significant deterioration in domestic demand. Low oil receipts will lead to a retrenchment in government consumption, indirectly feeding through to private consumption, which will also be constrained by a worsening labour market. Economic and political uncertainties will weigh on private investment, which is set to decline for a second-consecutive year.
Assuming that the coronavirus outbreak is controlled by end-2020, prompting a recovery in external and domestic demand, we expect real GDP growth to rebound in 2021, but it will remain below 2019 levels. Political uncertainties will be elevated by the February 2021 general election and this will preclude a more robust pick-up in domestic demand. We expect growth to be tepid in 2022, considering the 2021 rebound, but it should slowly improve thereafter as policy uncertainties wane, oil prices rise and moderate improvements to the business environment materialise.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Tumbling commodity prices, weak demand, fiscal tightening and a rising US dollar will produce deflation this year. Consumer prices were flat in 2019, and we assume that consumer prices will fall by an average 0.4% this year. We expect inflation to pick up slightly, to an annual average of 0.9% in 2021-24, as import costs rise owing to renewed dollar weakness and an increase in commodity prices. Dollarisation will help to contain inflation, but the economy will remain vulnerable to increases in food and energy prices.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Risks to dollarisation have spiked and will remain elevated in the short term. The economic crisis presents major problems of financing and liquidity, as oil prices have crashed and access to global financing remains limited. These problems are likely to be compounded by a short-term strengthening of the US dollar (hurting competitiveness) and a dip in reserves.
Nevertheless, we currently assume that dollarisation will be retained during the forecast period, as the government's commitment to its IMF agreement and to fiscal discipline allows for greater multilateral financing. The real effective exchange rate will remain stronger than its long-term, pre-dollarisation average but, in real trade-weighted terms, there will be some depreciation as the US dollar begins to weaken in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector We now expect that the current account will deteriorate in 2020, as the macroeconomic backdrop has worsened significantly since our last monthly report. Weaker than expected oil revenue will weigh significantly on the trade balance in the short-term, as oil prices languish and external demand withers.
Non-oil export earnings will be hit hard, with shrimp and mining exports in particular suffering from domestic restrictions on business operations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus and a retraction of demand in major export markets, including China and the US. The deterioration of the trade balance will be softened by collapsing domestic demand, which will engender import compression. However, remittances are also likely to suffer as economic activity has ground to a halt outside Ecuador, dragging down the current-account deficit. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will pick up in the medium term after suffering in 2020-21, which will preclude a build up in foreign-exchange reserves, but will remain below 1% of GDP.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data Food commodity prices: IFS
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US$ exchange rate: IFS
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IFS; BCE, Información Estadística Mensual
Bank deposit rate: BCE; average free-market interest rate offered by deposit-money banks on deposits of 84-91 days
Bank lending rate: BCE; rate charged by deposit-money banks on loans of 84-91 days in local currency
Debt-service ratio, paid: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Exchange rate: EUR:US$1
External debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP public finances, inflation and exchange rate: BCE, 2000 prices
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IFS; covers the general resource account, structural adjustment facilities, enhanced structural adjustment facilities and trust fund loans
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for low- and middle-income urban households, 2004=100
Population: Economist Intelligence Unit estimates, based on results of INEC 2001 census
Public-sector balance: non-financial public sector (NFPS) unless otherwise indicated; BCE, ww.bce.fin.ec
Abbreviations BCE: Banco Central del Ecuador (the Central Bank)

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+India&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+India+March+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-03-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+India&amp;rft.issn=09668829&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance government to serve out its second five-year term, which will expire in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration
- Relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24. Trade tension might ease, as a limited trade pact is in reach. Despite efforts to normalise relations, ties with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's rising influence in South Asia. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained in 2020-24. Small-scale military exchanges cannot be ruled out, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March), owing to a slew of fiscal measures, most notably a cut in corporate tax. The fiscal deficit will remain wide overall during the forecast period, as the government will raise expenditure and fund spending based on uncertain divestment.
- The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to leave its policy rates unchanged in 2020 before embarking on a tightening cycle from 2021. The RBI will tweak its policy tools and regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of its accommodative monetary policy.
- Real GDP growth will slump to 4.9% in 2019/20, owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Economic growth will recover to an annual average of 6.3% in 2020/21-2024/25.
- We expect consumer price inflation to exceed the mid-point of the central bank's 2-6% target range in 2020-24. The key driver will be a sustained recovery in domestic demand. Our forecasts assume normal monsoons.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate slightly against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs70.6:US$1 in 2020. The currency will remain weak in 2021-24, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and rising domestic inflation.
- India will remain dependent on imports for its fuel and capital goods needs. The merchandise trade deficit will therefore widen during the forecast period. Business process outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score rises over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial or complete privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or their merger or acquisition by other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Restrictions on foreign investment in multi-brand retail are partially removed.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: A limited trade deal is signed with the US.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: The government will abolish dividend distribution tax, and the goods and services tax (GST) will be simplified slightly.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the GST.
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks and micro, small and medium enterprises.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues persist in public-sector banks.
The labour market 2020-21: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace, owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2022-24: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by regional standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or by purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's domination of the central government during its term, which ends in 2024. This will ensure continuity in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the 2019 election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts, the most prominent being the national security adviser, Ajit Doval. We believe that the PMO and Mr Doval will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Social unrest will pose a threat to political stability during the forecast period. Clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups, notably Muslims. Violent protests are continuing across India following the enactment in December of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019, with some fearing that the change will erode secularism and others concerned about unchecked immigration. State governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, although some may not implement the changes to the citizenship law.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a key concern in the early part of the forecast period. The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state sparked protests. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders, further unrest cannot be ruled out. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shutdowns, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be to gauge support for the BJP in the state assembly elections. However, the results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important. We believe that the BJP will perform poorly in the state election in Bihar later in the year.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half the total number of seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of a few more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) could secure a simple majority in the upper house. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan will be exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August to revoke the special status granted to J&K. Shortly after the revocation was announced, Pakistan downgraded its diplomatic ties with India, and India responded in kind. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
The US president, Donald Trump, will visit India on February 24th-25th. The chance of a trade deal being signed is low following a recent increase in trade tensions between the two countries. However, some progress is likely to be made on the defence front. A coming limited trade deal between the US and India may address impending issues between the two countries, but it will not solve systemic structural trade conflict. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence.
China's sway in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One priority will be to inject momentum into its divestment programme. The government expects to collect Rs1.2trn (US$16.8bn) of divestment income in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March). The plan will also help to liberalise some sectors. However, given weakness in business sentiment and the balance sheets of some state-owned enterprises, we do not believe that the government's ambitious divestment target will be met.
We maintain our view that incentives will be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: tourism, construction, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a point of contention with countries such as the US in 2020-24. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Nevertheless, we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National infrastructure Pipeline and the Smart Cities Mission-remain a priority, partly in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects will face financing difficulties, as they involve a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy Amid sluggish growth and budget constraints, the government announced a conservatively expansionary budget for 2020/21. It included the simplification of income tax for individuals in certain income groups. Notably, the government abolished the dividend distribution tax in an attempt to bolster investment spending.
We have revised our fiscal forecasts for 2020/21 and expect the deficit to widen to the equivalent of 3.7% of GDP (our previous forecast was 3.5% of GDP). This change is primarily attributable to our belief that progress on its divestment plan will be slow and that the government will miss its targets for both divestment income and total revenue. Moreover, we would caution against reliance on divestment income, which is an unsustainable revenue stream, to plug the fiscal hole. As the economy recovers, the government will attempt to consolidate the fiscal finances, leading to an improvement in the budget deficit to 3.1% of GDP by 2022/23. Spending pressures will increase thereafter in the run-up to the parliamentary election in 2024, resulting in a widening of the budget deficit from 2023/24. Our forecast assumes an absence of significant tax cuts in 2020/21-2023/24.
Efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will, nevertheless, continue over the forecast period; India's tax/GDP ratio remains relatively low compared with those of its regional peers. Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the administration, which will seek to expand public welfare schemes. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. We believe that the government will succeed in raising tax compliance, which will help to prevent a significant swelling in the budget deficit as a proportion of GDP during the forecast period.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits of several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits in some states, such as Himachal Pradesh (4.4% of GDP), will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will maintain inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%, throughout 2020-24. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
We anticipate that accelerating consumer price inflation in the first half of 2020 will challenge the RBI's adherence to its inflation-targeting regime. However, it will be keen to support economic growth and to keep its policy rate unchanged rather than embark on a policy-tightening cycle. The RBI has also created a long-term repo operation and tweaked the regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of its accommodative monetary policy. The central bank will, nevertheless, undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023-24, the RBI will return to a neutral stance.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth Real GDP grew by an average of 4.8% year on year in April-September 2019 (the first half of 2019/20). This compares with growth of 7.5% in the same period of the previous fiscal year and is the slowest rate of increase recorded for the first half of any fiscal year since 2001. Weak consumer sentiment and tepid investment were the main reasons for the slowdown. We expect the economy to grow by an average of 5% in the second half of 2019/20, bolstered by the positive effects of monetary policy easing that was adopted earlier in the year and fiscal stimulus measures adopted in September 2019. Overall, we expect the economy to grow by 4.9% in 2019/20. Growth in private consumption will be constrained by a strong pick-up in consumer price inflation, which will reduce consumers' purchasing power.
The effects of successive cuts to the RBI's policy interest rate in 2019 will continue to be felt at the start of 2020/21. This, coupled with the lingering effects of September's fiscal stimulus measures, will help to underpin growth. However, an outbreak of the novel coronavirus in parts of Asia adds uncertainty over sluggish exports and manufacturing (although India would tend to be less affected, as its economy is not as export-oriented as those of its peers). We forecast that real GDP growth will average 6.3% per year in 2021/22-2024/25. An anticipated tightening of monetary policy in 2021-22 will weigh on business and consumer sentiment; however, the rapid pace of real GDP growth warrants the adoption of a tightening stance. Progress on structural reforms will be too slow to give real GDP a significant boost.
In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential, owing to structural limitations in areas such as land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agriculture sector's contribution to GDP will continue to decrease over the forecast period. Public investment in agriculture will be aimed at short-term gains rather than fostering improved productivity.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 5.7% in 2020 as a whole, compared with 3.7% in 2019. Price pressures will abate from the second half of this year as forthcoming harvests boost food supplies. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in late 2021 will offset the inflationary impact of continued strengthening in oil prices in 2022, keeping average consumer price growth steady at 3.5%, just below the midpoint of the RBI's 2-6% target range. As oil prices stabilise in 2023-24 and the central bank accords a higher priority to containing inflationary pressures, consumer price inflation is expected to ease to an annual average of 3.2%.
The increasing cost of raw materials will drive up producer price inflation slightly in 2020, to 2.2%. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.6% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2019, along with high political risks associated with the removal of J&K's special constitutional status and changes to the citizenship law, have weighed on the exchange rate. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate on an annual average basis to Rs70.6:US$1 in 2020. However, the rate of depreciation will be shallow as the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) loosens monetary policy further.
In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly to an average of Rs70.3:US$1, owing to the RBI's tightening efforts, which will lead to policy divergence with the Fed. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-23 amid rising oil prices. We expect the currency to appreciate slightly in 2024, owing to an easing of external payment pressures. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable during our forecast period, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Stronger investment from 2020 and higher oil prices from 2021 will increase the import bill, causing the trade deficit to widen. Merchandise export growth will be tempered by supply-chain disruptions caused by the outbreak of the coronavirus in China, but is expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in global commerce. However, India's export manufacturing sector will be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, narrowing to 1% of GDP in 2021 before widening to 1.4% of GDP in 2023-24.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2020-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$60bn by 2024, from an estimated US$46.8bn in 2019. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in July-August 2019, owing to the imposition of higher taxes on foreign institutional investors. These tax changes were later rolled back as part of the government's efforts to revive the economy. We therefore expect these inflows to remain positive in 2020-24 as investor confidence is restored.

Full text: - Despite the country's socioeconomic collapse, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, will retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. We do not expect the US government to renew waivers on Chevron and other US oil companies in July. This, together with the latest sanctions on Rosneft Trading (a subsidiary of the Russian-controlled oil giant) will lower global demand for Venezuelan crude and, in turn, force a reduction in domestic crude production over the coming quarters. Moreover, given that it will lose control over the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure in 2020 to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- The government has recently allowed the official exchange rate to float, which has alleviated pressures on its foreign-exchange reserves. Furthermore, de facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding, which aids price stability and therefore increases the availability of some basic goods. These measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela comes in 82nd of 82 countries globally in the business environment rankings for 2020-24, from 80th in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Limited rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain subdued, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions remain on private-sector access to foreign currency.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour creates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts. New government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2022-24: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but risk of water and electricity rationing remains.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) will retain power, despite severe economic and international pressure. Mr Maduro has remained in office amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. The imposition of US sanctions has taken a dramatic economic toll on Venezuela, in particular by causing a collapse in oil production. However, in recent quarters a shift towards Asian markets has provided some stability to oil production, as has support from Russia and Cuba to circumvent US sanctions. In addition, the regime continues to benefit from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities. These sources of US dollars have prevented sanctions from fatally wounding the regime's patronage system. It is this patronage-along with strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces (and purges within its ranks)-that has allowed the regime to manage internal dissent.
The opposition led by the president of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in early 2019 after abortive dialogue efforts and, in particular, after a failed uprising in April. International pressure has plateaued as the Lima Group (a multilateral body of mostly Latin American nations set up in 2017 to discuss the situation in Venezuela) and the Organisation of American States seem to have exhausted most of their diplomatic ammunition.
US sanctions remain a source of pressure: in February the US imposed sanctions on Rosneft Trading, a subsidiary of the Russian-controlled oil giant. These fresh sanctions will add further pressure to the regime's internal finances. However, this is somewhat offset by continued large-scale emigration, which has benefited the regime. The exodus has eased pressure on Mr Maduro and increasing inflows of workers' remittances provide the regime with hard currency. Furthermore, the population has grown protest-weary, and the economy has stabilised in relative terms. De facto dollarisation has brought about an improvement in price stability and, combined with a de facto lifting of price and foreign-exchange controls, has increased the availability of some basic goods.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is still a high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this-military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as low. Although a return to the negotiating table is possible, we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis. We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The risks of such a political transition will be particularly high in 2020. We expect the US administration led by Donald Trump to refuse to grant an additional sanctions waiver to Chevron and other US oil services firms in July. This will further weaken oil production in the short to medium term and test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. Perhaps most important, however, is the fact that the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly-the only remaining legitimate body-in January 2021, assuming that the regime engineers rigged elections in late 2020. Without such power, the possibility of a transition towards an opposition-led or mixed administration would plummet. Mr Maduro understands that the legislature's (and therefore Mr Guaidó's) power depends on its legitimacy, which explains why the regime sought to hijack the annual election of the speaker of the National Assembly in early January. Mr Guaidó was ultimately reselected as leader of the legislature, maintaining his legitimate claim as head of the executive branch for a second consecutive year.
Mr Guaidó and the opposition will be under pressure to try to force a regime change before the forthcoming elections; the prospect of the PSUV clinging to power permanently could prove a trigger for a renewed popular uprising. In such an environment, and if sanctions bite further, pragmatists within the government and the military could finally turn on Mr Maduro, paving the way for some sort of political transition. The country's crumbling infrastructure could also act as a trigger for regime change. A particularly dry summer (January-April) could exacerbate what is already likely to be a difficult season in 2020, leading to severe electricity and water shortages, with the prospect of protests against the regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch On the assumption that the Maduro regime clings to power, legislative elections will take place in December. These elections will be neither free nor fair, and the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America (under the Lima Group banner) to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The latest US sanctions on Rosneft Trading seek to further complicate transacting Venezuelan crude oil. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and thus on its patronage system) so that Mr Maduro is forced to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future. We expect the US not to renew waivers in July that would allow Chevron and other US oil companies to continue operating in Venezuela. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given Mr Trump's aversion to such adventurism. However, if tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure the long-term future of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. Russia is helping PDVSA to circumvent US sanctions (and profiting from it); however, we believe that Venezuela is increasingly becoming a liability for the Russian government. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends Given our view that Mr Maduro will retain power for the duration of our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. In recent months, there has been evidence of attempts to tighten monetary policy in order to rein in hyperinflation and abandon foreign-exchange controls (official exchange rates are in line with the black market). De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. De facto elimination of a host of controls is also occurring and has had a beneficial impact on the availability of goods. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the survival of the regime. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the present regime. In this environment, domestic supply will be persistently weak.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow sharply in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, growing remittance inflows and the collapse of domestic demand will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. At present we assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. The country's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US federal appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US, which does not recognise Mr Maduro as the legitimate president, currently considers Citgo and its Caribbean facilities to be under Mr Guaidó's purview. As a result, the latest sanctions from the US Treasury department include provisions forbidding the transfer of Venezuelan assets, thus shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors. We expect the Trump administration to keep these measures in place during 2020. However, once the PSUV retakes control of the (currently legitimate) National Assembly, Citgo assets will no longer be safeguarded. Furthermore, despite being in default on all its global bonds, the Maduro regime might seek to cut unorthodox deals with bondholders, such as debt-for-oil arrangements.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. A significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of 2019 and a strong contraction in domestic demand have had a temporary steadying effect, which slowed hyperinflationary pressures in 2019; we expect this trend to continue this year. Nevertheless, the underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of more than 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect a further decline of 20.5% in 2020. This will be driven by weaker private demand, owing to falling real incomes, continued migration, and-most importantly-a further contraction in oil output. We forecast that economic growth in 2021-24 will contract at an average annual rate of 4.5%-a more moderate rate of decline than in previous years, assuming a stabilisation of oil output. Private consumption will contract further in 2020 as unemployment, violence and falling incomes continue to force mass emigration, further weakening domestic demand.
In addition to the latest sanctions on Rosneft, we forecast that the US will prohibit Chevron and other American oil companies from operating in Venezuela. These moves will weaken demand for Venezuelan crude and prompt PDVSA to reduce its oil production. Although some volatility is envisaged, we expect oil output to decline gradually to 600,000 barrels/day by end-2020. In the medium term, we expect oil output to continue to fall-albeit more gradually-owing to serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or in finding qualified staff) and to a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude. Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24, on the back of moderately higher global oil prices, and as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. In addition, import compression will continue, which means that net exports will partly offset chronically weak internal demand.
There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which are based on the assumption that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of this improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, currency constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were published recently by the BCV, but there is a significant divergence between these figures and data from other sources. Amid persistent questions regarding the data, we will for now continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit will cause inflation to come down from the hyperinflationary rates of recent years. Nevertheless, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, as well as the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or the introduction of a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. With few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime announced a loosening of currency controls in mid-2019. Although this is a positive move, access to US dollars via formal means is limited, as significant barriers remain in place that, in practice, restrict access to dollars. We continue to believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On February 17th the official exchange rate was BsS73,380:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS77,142:US$1. The premium (currently at 5%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period, on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019). A continuation of these trends will allow Venezuela to post a current-account surplus in 2020 as well.
We expect the current account to remain in surplus during the forecast period, averaging 4.1% of GDP in 2021-24. The trade surplus will recover gradually as international oil prices increase moderately and the country steps up exports to Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Global data US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
Domestic data Budget balance: non-financial public sector
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsS:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation

Abstract: Real GDP growth will slump to 4.9% in 2019/20, owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government to serve out its second five-year term, which expires in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration in 2020-24.
- Relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24; trade tension will ease in the early part of the forecasting period as the two countries strive to ratify a limited trade deal. Despite efforts to normalise relations, ties with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's rising influence in South Asia. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained in 2020-24. Small-scale military exchanges cannot be ruled out, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- The budget deficit will remain wide as a percentage of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21-24/25 (April-March), as the government will continue to spend heavily on infrastructure and subsidy payments. However, we do not expect it to implement additional fiscal stimulus.
- Real GDP growth will slump to 4.9% in 2019/20, owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Economic growth will recover to an annual average of 6.3% in 2020/21-2024/25.
- We expect consumer price inflation to approach the upper bound of the central bank's 2-6% target range in 2020. The key driver will be a sustained recovery in domestic demand, as well as lagged agricultural production. Inflation will then stabilise below 4% in 2021-24, because of the tightening cycle embarked upon by the Reserve Bank of India (the central bank). Our forecasts assume normal monsoons.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate slightly against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs70.6:US$1. The currency will remain weak in 2021-24, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and high domestic inflation.
- India will remain dependent on imports for its fuel and capital goods needs. The merchandise trade deficit will therefore widen during the forecast period. Business process outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score rises over the forecast period owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or merger-and-acquisition activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Restrictions on foreign investment in multi-brand retail are partially removed.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: India and the US ratify a limited trade deal. Bilateral tensions ease as the countries move towards the implementation stage.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues persist in public-sector banks.
The labour market 2020-21: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2022-24: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by regional standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or by purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.
