Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's domination of the central government at any point during its full term (2019-24). This will ensure continuity in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the 2019 election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised around the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts. The PMO and the national security advisor, Ajit Doval, played a key role in the outgoing government, and we believe that they will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Social unrest will pose a threat to political stability during the forecast period. Clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups, notably Muslims. Violent protests are continuing across India following the enactment in December of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019, with some fearing that the change will erode secularism and others concerned about unchecked immigration. State governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, although some may not implement the changes to the citizenship law.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a key concern in the early part of the forecast period. The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state sparked protests. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders, further unrest cannot be ruled out. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shut-downs, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be to gauge support for the BJP in the state assembly elections. However, the results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important. We believe that the BJP will perform poorly in the upcoming state elections in Delhi (February) and Bihar (later in the year).
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half the total number of seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of a few more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) could secure a simple majority in the upper house. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan will be exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August to revoke the special status granted to J&K. Shortly after the revocation was announced, Pakistan downgraded its diplomatic ties with India, and India responded in kind. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
A coming limited trade deal between the US and India may address impending issues between the two countries, but it will not solve systemic structural trade conflict. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence.
China's sway in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One area of priority will be resolving bad debt problems in the banking sector that have held back lending to business. In the budget delivered in July 2019, the government announced plans to provide Rs700bn (US$10bn) to help to shore up public-sector banks in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March). We believe that this sum will help to address balance-sheet problems. It will also improve liquidity in the banking sector. However, given weak business sentiment, this initiative is unlikely to have led to a significant increase in lending.
We expect incentives to be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: tourism, construction, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a point of contention with countries such as the US in 2020-24. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Nevertheless, we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the Bharatmala roads project and the Smart Cities Mission-will remain a priority, partly as a response to the rapid pace of urbanisation, and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects will face financing difficulties, as they envision a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The government announced a slew of fiscal stimulus measures in August and September 2019 in response to weak GDP data for the second quarter of that year. The measures included initiatives for ailing sectors of the economy, such as automotive, banking and housing. Notably, the government also gave companies the option to pay corporate tax at a lower rate of 22% (25.2% including various surcharges), from 30% previously. This was backdated to the start of fiscal year 2019/20, in order to spur private-sector activity.
Fiscal stimulus measures and the revenue foregone owing to the corporate tax cut will leave a large hole in government finances. We expect the fiscal deficit to widen to the equivalent of 3.9% of GDP in 2019/20. As the economy recovers, the government will attempt to consolidate the fiscal finances, leading to an improvement in the budget deficit to 3% of GDP by 2022/23. Thereafter, spending pressures will increase in the run-up to the parliamentary election in 2024, resulting in a widening of the budget deficit in 2023/24. Our forecast assumes no more tax cuts in 2020/21-2023/24.
Efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will, nevertheless, continue over the forecast period; India's tax/GDP ratio remains relatively low compared with those of its regional peers. Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the government, which will seek to expand public welfare schemes. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. We believe that the government will succeed in raising tax compliance, which will help to prevent a significant swelling in the budget deficit as a proportion of GDP during the forecast period.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits of several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits in some states, such as Punjab, will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will maintain inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%, throughout 2020-24. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
We anticipate that accelerating consumer price inflation in the first half of 2020 will challenge the RBI's adherence to its inflation-targeting regime. However, the central bank will be keen to support economic growth and keep its policy rate unchanged rather than embark on a policy-tightening cycle. It will, nevertheless, undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023-24, the RBI will return to a neutral stance.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth Real GDP grew by an average of 4.8% year on year in April-September 2019 (the first half of 2019/20). This compares with growth of 7.5% in the same period of the previous fiscal year and is the slowest rate of increase recorded for the first half of any fiscal year since 2001. Weak consumer sentiment and tepid invest-ment were the main reasons for the slowdown. We expect the economy to grow by an average of 5% in the second half of 2019/20, bolstered by the positive effects of monetary policy easing earlier in the year and fiscal stimulus measures adopted in September 2019. Overall, we expect the economy to grow by 4.9% in 2019/20. Growth in private consumption will be constrained by a strong pick-up in consumer price inflation, which will reduce consumers' purchasing power.
The effects of successive cuts to the RBI's policy interest rate in 2019 will continue to be felt at the start of 2020/21. This, coupled with the lingering effects of September's fiscal stimulus measures, will help to underpin growth. At the same time, a gradual recovery in global trade growth and brightening prospects for the global economy will help to lift exports and investment spending. We forecast that real GDP growth will average 6.4% per year in 2021/22-2024/25. An anticipated tightening of monetary policy in 2021-22 will weigh on business and consumer sentiment. However, the recovery will be at a sufficiently rapid pace to warrant the adoption of a tightening stance. Nevertheless, progress on structural reforms will be too slow to give real GDP a significant boost.
In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential, owing to structural limitations in areas such as land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agriculture sector's contribution to GDP will continue to decrease over the forecast period. Public investment in agriculture will be aimed at short-term gains rather than fostering improved productivity.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We have revised our consumer inflation forecast for 2020, following a modest upward revision to our global oil price forecast for the year. We believe that the lingering adverse effects of an extended monsoon in 2019, which negatively affected crop yields, will exert upward pressure on overall prices in the early months of 2020. We now expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 5.7% for the year as a whole, compared with 4.7% previously. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in late 2021 will offset the inflationary impact of continued strengthening in oil prices in 2022, keeping average consumer price growth steady at 3.5%, just below the midpoint of the RBI's 2-6% target range. As oil prices stabilise in 2023-24 and the central bank accords a higher priority to containing inflationary pressures, consumer price inflation is expected to ease to an annual average of 3.2%.
The increasing cost of raw materials will drive up producer price inflation slightly in 2020, to 1.9%. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.6% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2019, along with high political risks associated with the removal of J&K's special constitutional status and changes to the citizenship law, have weighed on the exchange rate. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate on an annual average basis to Rs70.6:US$1 in 2020. However, the rate of depreciation will be shallow as the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) loosens monetary policy further.
In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly to an average of Rs70.3:US$1, owing to the RBI's tightening efforts, which will lead to policy divergence with the Fed. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-23 amid rising oil prices. We expect the currency to appreciate slightly in 2024, owing to an easing of external pay-ment pressures. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable during our forecast period, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Stronger investment from 2020 and higher oil prices from 2021 will swell the import bill, resulting in a widening of the trade deficit. Merchandise exports will grow at a faster pace than imports over the next five years, but India's export manufacturing sector will be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, narrowing to 0.9% of GDP in 2021 before widening to 1.4% of GDP in 2023-24.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2020-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$60bn by 2024, from an estimated US$47bn in 2019. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in July-August 2019, owing to the imposition of higher taxes on foreign institutional investors. These tax changes were later rolled back as part of the government's efforts to revive the economy. We therefore expect these inflows to remain positive in 2020-24 as investor confidence is restored.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Domestic data GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown
Population: IMF, IFS
Public finance: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by the GOI's annual budget papers
Oil production: Oil & Gas Journal; Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Inflation, exchange rates and money supply: IMF, IFS; Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE; RBI, WSS
Yield on 91-day Treasury bills: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE
Short-term benchmark interest rate: World Bank, India CEM; IDBI prime lending rate
Direction of trade: GOI, Economic Survey (annual)
Composition of trade and the current account: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE or RBI, Annual Report
Foreign direct investment (FDI): IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; includes reinvested profits
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Abbreviations CEM: Country Economic Memorandum
GOI: Government of India
IDBI: Industrial Development Bank of India
IFS: International Financial Statistics
MRIE: Monthly Review of the Indian Economy
RBI: Reserve Bank of India

Full text: - Despite the country's socioeconomic collapse, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, will retain power throughout 2020-24. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions, and their impact on oil production, the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. We do not expect the US government to renew waivers on Chevron and other US oil companies in July 2020; this will destabilise crude production, at least in the short term. Moreover, given that it will lose control over the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure in 2020 to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- The government has recently allowed the official exchange rate to float, which has alleviated pressures on its foreign-exchange reserves. Furthermore, de facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding, which aids price stability and therefore increases the availability of some basic goods. These measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in the business environment rankings for 2020-24, down from 80th in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens, despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Limited rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain subdued, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions remain on private-sector access to foreign currency.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour creates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts. New government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2022-24: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but risk of water and electricity rationing remains.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that the military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), will retain power, despite severe economic and international pressure. Mr Maduro has remained in office amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. The imposition of US sanctions has taken a dramatic economic toll on Venezuela, in particular by causing a collapse in oil production. However, in recent quarters a shift towards Asian markets has provided some stability to oil production, as has support from Russia and Cuba to circumvent US sanctions. In addition, the regime continues to benefit from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities. These sources of US dollar have prevented sanctions from fatally wounding the regime's patronage system. It is this patronage-along with strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces, and purges within its ranks-that has allowed the regime to manage internal dissent.
Internal and external efforts to oust Mr Maduro are fading. The opposition, led by the president of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in early 2019 after abortive dialogue efforts and, in particular, after a failed uprising in April. International pressure has plateaued as the admini-stration of the US president, Donald Trump, has shifted its attention to the November 2020 US presidential election and to other foreign policy targets, chiefly Iran and China. Meanwhile the Lima Group (a multilateral body of mostly Latin American nations set up in 2017 to discuss the situation in Venezuela) and the Organisation of American States (OAS) seem to have exhausted most of their diplomatic ammunition. Large-scale emigration has also benefited Mr Maduro. The exodus has eased pressure on the Maduro regime, and increasing inflows of workers' remittances provide the regime with hard currency. Furthermore, the population has grown protest-weary, and the economy has stabilised in relative terms. De facto dollarisation has brought about an improvement in price stability and, combined with a de facto lifting of price and foreign-exchange controls, has increased the availability of some basic goods.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is still a high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this-military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as low. Although negotiations sponsored by Norway are likely to resume (it is unclear when), we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis. We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The risks of such a political transition will be particularly high in 2020. We expect the Trump administration to refuse to grant an additional sanctions waiver to Chevron and other US oil services firms in July. This will again destabilise oil production in the short term and test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. Perhaps most important, however, is the fact that the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly-the only remaining legitimate body-in January 2021, assuming that the regime engineers rigged elections in late 2020. Without such power, the possibility of a transition towards an opposition-led or mixed administration would plummet. Mr Maduro understands that the legislature's (and therefore Mr Guaidó's) power lies in being legitimate, which explains why the regime sought to hijack the annual election of the speaker of the National Assembly in early January. Mr Guaidó was ultimately reselected as head of the legislature, maintaining his legitimate claim as head of the executive branch for a second consecutive year.
Mr Guaidó and the opposition will be under pressure to try to force a regime change before the upcoming elections; the prospect of the PSUV clinging to power permanently could prove a trigger for a renewed popular uprising. In such an environment, and if sanctions bite further, pragmatists within the government and the military could finally turn on Mr Maduro, paving the way for some sort of political transition. The country's crumbling infrastructure could also act as a trigger for transition. A particularly dry summer (January-April) could exacerbate what is already likely to be a difficult season in 2020, leading to severe electricity and water shortages, with the prospect of protests against the regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch On the assumption that the Maduro regime clings to power, legislative elections will take place in December 2020. These elections will be neither free nor fair, so the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America (under the Lima Group banner) to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The most important of the US sanctions is a freeze on Venezuelan assets abroad, which will further complicate the regime's attempts to sustain the current patronage system; in September the US also introduced a travel ban on senior Venezuelan officials. Moreover, we expect waivers that allow Chevron and other US oil companies to continue operating in Venezuela not to be renewed in July 2020, given the approaching US presidential election. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given Mr Trump's aversion to such adventurism. However, if tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure the long-term future of PDVSA, the state oil company. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. Nonetheless, Russia is believed to be helping PDVSA to circumvent US sanctions (for a fee). However, Russia's interest in Venezuela is mainly geopolitical, not economic. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends Given our view that Mr Maduro will retain power for the duration of our forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. In recent months there has been evidence of attempts to tighten monetary policy, in order to rein in hyperinflation and abandon foreign-exchange controls (official exchange rates are in line with the black market). De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. De facto elimination of a host of controls is also occurring and has had a beneficial impact on the availability of goods. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the survival of the regime. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the present regime. In this environment, domestic supply will be persistently weak.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow sharply in 2020, and that the public debt/GDP ratio will remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, growing remittance inflows and the collapse of domestic demand will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. At present we assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. The country's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US federal appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US, which does not recognise Mr Maduro as the legitimate president, currently considers Citgo and its Caribbean facilities to be under Mr Guaidó's purview. As a result, the latest sanctions from the US Treasury department include provisions forbidding the transfer of Venezuelan assets, thus shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors. We expect the Trump administration to keep these measures in place during 2020. However, once the PSUV retakes control of the (currently legitimate) National Assembly, Citgo assets will no longer be safeguarded. Furthermore, despite being in default on all its global bonds, the Maduro regime might seek to cut unorthodox deals with bondholders, such as debt-for-oil arrangements.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. A significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of 2019 and a strong contraction in domestic demand have had a temporary steadying effect, which slowed hyperinflationary pressures in 2019; we expect this trend to continue this year. Nevertheless, the underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of more than 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect a further decline of 20.5% in 2020. This will be driven by weaker private demand, owing to falling real incomes, continued migration, and-most importantly-a further contraction in oil output. We forecast that economic growth in 2021-24 will contract at an average annual rate of 4.5%, a more moderate rate of decline than in previous years, assuming a stabilisation of oil output. Private consumption will contract further in 2020 as unemployment, violence and falling incomes continue to force mass migration, further weakening domestic demand.
We expect the US's decision to prohibit Chevron and other US oil companies from operating in Venezuela to curb oil production at the Petropiar joint venture (between Chevron and PDVSA) in the Orinoco Belt. The impact on oil production will be limited in the short term; after the ban PDVSA could take full control of the venture or assume joint control with other partners, most likely a Russian oil company, Rosneft. Even so, we expect oil output to slip to just 600,000 barrels/day in 2020. Under PDVSA control, crude production would fail to reach previous levels. In the medium term we expect oil output to continue to fall-albeit more gradually-owing to serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or in finding qualified staff) and to a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude.
Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24, on the back of moderately higher global oil prices, and as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. In addition, import compression will continue, which means that net exports will partly offset chronically weak internal demand.
There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which are based on the assumption that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of this improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, currency constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were published recently by the BCV, but there is a significant divergence between these figures and data from other sources. Amid continuing questions regarding the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit will cause inflation to come down from the hyper-inflationary rates of recent years. Nevertheless, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, as well as the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or the introduction of a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. With few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime announced a loosening of currency controls in mid-2019. Although this is a positive move, access to US dollars via formal means is limited, as significant barriers remain in place that in practice restrict access to dollars. We continue to believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On January 24th the official exchange rate was BsS74,580:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS77,102:US$1. The premium (currently at 3%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period, on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019). A continuation of these trends will allow Venezuela to post a current-account surplus in 2020 as well.
We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, averaging 4.2% of GDP in 2021-24. The trade surplus will recover gradually as international oil prices increase moderately and the country steps up exports to Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.
